PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Rt Hon. Sir Billy Snedden) took the chair at 10.30 a.m., and read prayers.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: BEAZLEY; CHILD; DARLING; DAWKINS; JONES; YOUNG
PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:
Tertiary Education
To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. This Petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

(i) the proposal to introduce fees for higher and second degrees will mean that access to post-graduate and recurrent education will be limited to the rich; Australian research and ability to cope with technological change will suffer; this proposal must be seen as a step in the direction of the introduction of fees for all tertiary students.

(ii) the proposed introduction of a loans scheme for students will mean graduating with a heavy debt burden or being denied a tertiary education if loans are refused because a student is seen as a 'poor risk' (particularly affecting women and those doing non-vocational courses); only the rich will be able to get a tertiary education without course restrictions and the burden of indebtedness.

(iii) in regard to the proposal to restrict eligibility for TEAS and the foreshadowing of reviewing TEAS levels only in the light of the availability of loans it should be noted that any further downgrading of TEAS, which is already inadequate, can only further limit access to education.

(iv) the proposed restriction of Adult Secondary Assistance to those needing qualification for employment will severely restrict access to a full high school education and necessary bridging education to tertiary education for those who left school early.

(v) the proposal not to fund 30 Colleges of Advanced Education if they are not rationalised is an attack on teacher-education. Given that 70 per cent of teacher-education students are women, these cut-backs will have a disastrous effect on women's access to education. This attack will create teacher shortages in the mid 1980s, restrict access to education now and endanger the future quality of teaching available to Australian children.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
(1) post-secondary tuition fees not be introduced for any courses or for any category of students.
(2) that the TEAS scheme be extended so as to more fully meet the real financial needs of students.
(3) that a comprehensive loans scheme not be introduced.
(4) that there be no restriction of Adult Secondary Assistance.
(5) that the proposal not to fund 30 Colleges of Advanced Education unless they are rationalised be rescinded.
And your petitioners as in duty bound shall ever humbly pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beazley,Mrs Child,Mrs Darling,Mr Dawkins,Mr Barry Jones and Mr Young.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: DARLING; DAWKINS; JONES; KENT; MCLEAY; MOUNTFORD
PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

(i) the financial situation of students enrolled at Australian post-secondary institutions is already extremely difficult (as indicated in the Commonwealth Department of Education's 1979 survey of student incomes and expenditure) and any substantial increase in the financial commitments of students would gravely worsen their financial difficulties.

(ii) the imposition of post-secondary tuition fees of comparable levels to those imposed prior to 1971 would force many currently enrolled students to discontinue their studies and deter many persons willing and able at present to undertake post-secondary study from doing so.

(iii) those students and potential students from social groups currently under-represented and disadvantaged in the post-secondary education system would be most severely affected by the reintroduction of fees for post-secondary education.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
1. post-secondary tuition fees not be re-introduced for any courses or for any category of students
2. the visa charges upon private overseas students be removed immediately
3. the Minister for Education immediately clarify the Government's attitude to the reintroduction of post-secondary tuition fees.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Darling,Mr Dawkins,Mr Barry Jones,Mr Kent,Mr Leo McLeay and Mr Mountford.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: DUFFY; HOWE; INNES; JENKINS; MILTON; THEOPHANOUS
PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Bases in Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners believe that:

We the undersigned believe it is the duty of our government to promote peace. We believe the greatest threat to peace lies in the division of the world into two blocs grouped around the United States and the Soviet Union. These two blocs are locked into an escalating arms race. Unless this can be halted, it will inevitably destroy people of both sides.
We therefore call upon our politicians to work towards:
a non-aligned foreign policy
non-nuclear Indian and Pacific Oceans
the nuclear disarmanemt of the two major power blocs
the development of exchanges of people, information and ideas between the two blocs;
and to oppose:
the creation of foreign bases over which the Australian citizen will have no control
the use of military facilities on Australian soil for nuclear armed planes and submarines
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Duffy,Mr Howe,Mr Innes,Dr Jenkins,Mr Milton and Dr Theophanous.

PETITION.TITLE: Trans-Australia Airlines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth.
Many Australians depend almost exclusively upon Trans-Australia Airlines for the provision of essential air services.
The Federal Liberal Party policy objective of selling Trans-Australia Airlines within 4 years is contrary to the national interest.
Sale of Trans-Australia Airlines would inevitably result in-
(i) the creation of a private monopoly of major airline services in Australia;
(ii) higher domestic air fares.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will reject outright any proposal to sell Trans-Australia Airlines.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beazley,Mr Charles Jones,Mr Leo McLeay,Mr Morris and Mr Mountford.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

That funding in the area of children's services, which has been reduced by almost 40 per cent in real terms over the last five years, should be restored forthwith to at least the real value of funding allocated in the 1975-76 budget, and further, that annual budget allocations in the area of children's services should be spent in full for the purposes designated.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Les McMahon and Mr Mountford.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Superannuation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That we the undersigned are strongly opposing the proposed taxation scheme of the Australian people's superannuation moneys being 30c in the dollar after termination on retirement.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House take action.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Child Care Expenses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
A substantial contribution to Australia's economy by the payment of taxation and to the quality of life of fellow Australians, is made by parents in the work force who have pre-school children.
Taxation relief for adequate child care is necessary to enable these parents to avail themselves of child care facilities in order to take paid employment.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that taxpayers who incur child-care expenses in order to earn income should be able to have those expenses exempt from income taxation in the same way as other taxpayers can deduct business expenses from their assessable income.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Excise on Beer
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. The club industry in Australia is long-established and a valuable part of the community of this nation, providing places where the people may partake of the three basic needs of life: a place to eat, a place to drink, a place to sleep.
2. The club industry is accepted throughout the nation as occupying an important place in the social and economic activities of Australia.
3. The club industry is entirely within the private sector and makes a contribution to the government in taxes of various kinds.
4. The club industry has a need to sustain an appropriate level of turnover and growth, to make profit, and to sustain and improve the level of employment.
5. The club industry of Australia is gravely concerned at published reports that the Government intends to increase excise charges on beer in the forthcoming Budget.
6. Sales of beer constitute the major source of income of most of the industry.
7. The very steep rises in beer excise in 1975 and 1978 severely retarded the growth of the Australian club industry.

8. Any further increases in excise on beer in the 1981 Budget would further retard the industry at a time when growth is essential to maintaining economic viability and the ability to serve the constantly growing needs of the community.
9. Such is its significance as a community requirement, beer occupies a place on the Consumer Price Index, and any alteration to its cost to the community would have an inflationary effect.
10. Any increase in excise would result in and force the club industry to pass on such increases to the consumer by way of higher prices for beer.

11. Higher excise would be only the starting point for an upward spiral in beer prices because of the presence of other factors, such as State Licence Fee taxes, which are directly linked to excise rates.
12. The club industry of Australia already is gravely handicapped by heavy excise and other tax imposts, its growth is at a standstill; and, inevitably must decline if beer excise is increased.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Honourable Members of the House of Representatives:
1. Recognise the importance and place of the Australian club industry in the social and economic life of the nation.

2. Accept that the viability of the club industry is essential to the maintenance of employment opportunities and stability of the industry is essential to enable it to continue to provide for the club needs of the nation in this period of growing population and increasing tourism.
And further, that Honourable Members of the House of Representatives resist and reject any move to increase excise on beer.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Moranbah: Day Care Centre
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the need for a Neighbourhood Day Care Centre in the new Mining Town of Moranbah has been well established and acknowledged by the Office of Child Care, and should therefore receive high priority.

Your Petitioners therefore hereby pray that the Federal Government provide sufficient increase in the coming budget, for the allocation of Child Care, to ensure construction of a Neighbourhood Day Care Centre in Moranbah.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Excise on Beer
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. The hotel industry in Australia is long-established and a valuable part of the community of this nation, providing places where the people may partake of the three basic needs of life: a place to eat, a place to drink, a place to sleep.
2. The hotel industry is accepted throughout the nation as occupying an important place in the social and economic activities of Australia.
3. The hotel industry is almost entirely within the private sector and makes a large contribution to the government in taxes of various kinds.
4. The hotel industry has a need to sustain an appropriate level of turnover and growth, to make profit, and to sustain and improve the level of employment.
5. The hotel industry of Australia is gravely concerned at published reports that the Government intends to increase excise charges on beer in the forthcoming Budget.
6. Sales of beer constitute the major source of income of most of the industry's 5811 hotels in Australia.
7. The very steep rises in beer excise in 1975 and 1978 severely retarded the growth of the Australian hotel industry.

8. Any further increases in excise on beer in the 1981 Budget would further retard the industry at a time when growth is essential to maintaining economic viability and the ability to serve the constantly growing needs of the community.
9. Such is its significance as a community requirement, beer occupies a place on the Consumer Price Index, and any alteration to its cost to the community would have an inflationary effect.
10. Any increase in excise would result in and force the hotel industry to pass on such increases to the consumer by way of higher prices for beer.

11. Higher excise would be only the starting point for an upward spiral in beer prices because of the presence of other factors, such as State Licence Fee taxes, which are directly linked to excise rates.
12. The hotel industry of Australia already is gravely handicapped by heavy excise and other tax imposts, its growth is at a standstill; and, inevitably must decline if beer excise is increased.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that Honourable Members of the House of Representatives:
1. Recognise the importance and place of the Australian hotel industry in the social and economic life of the nation.

2. Accept that the viability of the hotel industry is essential to the maintenance of employment opportunities and stability of the industry is essential to enable it to continue to provide for the hotel needs of the nation in this period of growing population and increasing tourism.
And further, that Honourable Members of the House of Representatives resist and reject any move to increase excise on beer.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Department of Business and Consumer Affairs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That grave concern has developed within sections of the Australian community following the announcement of the Government's decisions to:
Abolish the Prices Justification Tribunal despite representations from the ACTU and other organisations,

Reduce the activities of the Trade Practices Commission by more discriminatory investigation of complaints, reduced adjudication work, less educational work, and less monitoring of safety and information standards,
Reduce staff in the Trade Practices Division of the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs,
Reduce staff in the Industries Assistance Commission
Reduce staff in Industries Assistance Division of the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will reverse these regressive and highly provocative decisions which abrogate the Government's role in consumer protection and reduce staff in vital areas of public service.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

(i) the financial situation of students enrolled at Australian post secondary institutions is already extremely difficult (as indicated in the Commonwealth Department of Education's 1979 survey of student incomes and expenditure) and any substantial increase in the financial commitments of students would gravely worsen their financial difficulties.
(ii) The imposition of tuition fees for second degrees and post graduate degrees will deter many able persons from enrolling-such courses and further preserve higher education for the rich.

(iii) The introduction of a loans scheme, subsequent review of the level of TEAS and the tightening of the eligibility criteria for TEAS will cause great financial hardship and will deter students from enrolling in tertiary institutions.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
1. post-secondary tuition fees not be reintroduced for any courses or for any category of students.
2. the visa charges upon private overseas students be removed immediately.
3. the Government reverse its decision to introduce a loans scheme and instead increase and extend TEAS scheme.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Overseas Aid
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That Australia, as an affluent and developed nation, should be able to expend more of its resources on the alleviation of human suffering and deprivation in other less developed countries.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government will:
Increase overseas aid to 0.7 per cent of Australia's GNP.
Increase to 4 per cent the proportion of overseas aid channeled through recognised non-government organisations such as world vision.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care Services: Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we strongly condemn any action taken by the Federal Government which will lead to the destruction of the Free Hospital and Medical Services of the State of Queensland.
And your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That the Parliament reject the proposed health cost sharing arrangements between the Commonwealth and the State governments and guarantee the maintenance of the present scheme whereby all Queenslanders who wish to avail themselves of these services may do so.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Curfew at Eagle Farm Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That noise levels created by aircraft using Eagle Farm Airport already constitute an annoyance and inconvenience to those residents living near the airport and along flight paths. That relaxation of the Eagle Farm Airport curfew to allow any aircraft including TAA's airbus to fly into and out of Eagle Farm Airport between 11 p.m. and 6 a.m. would-
(a) substantially increase the inconvenience and annoyance caused by aircraft noise because the operation of aircraft at this time would seriously disturb people's sleep;

(b) contradict and negate a commendable undertaking made by the Commonwealth Minister for Transport, the Hon. Ralph Hunt, in reply to a question on notice in the Parliament, that the curfew will remain on the runways at the existing site at Eagle Farm Airport.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government will not approve the application of TAA-or any other airline-to relax or withdraw the curfew at Eagle Farm Airport.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That public investment in tertiary education in the form of Federal Government funding is an investment in Australia's future and enables Australia to meet the demands of technological innovation.
That grave concern has been generated as a result of the Government's decisions to:
(a) abolish the Education Research and Development Committee;
(b) terminate special support for educational research;
(c) scale down in-house and contracted research activities of the Department of Education;
(d) scale down participation in international education activities, particularly UNESCO and OECD;
(e) further tighten already restrictive eligibility guidelines for TEAS;
(f) supplement TEAS assistance by means of a loan scheme;
(g) phase in tuition fees for students undertaking degrees and diplomas subsequent to an initial tertiary qualification;
(h) reduce grants to universities and colleges to take account of fee income;
(i) completely abolish 30 colleges of advanced education and
(j) scale down various engineering schools in colleges of advanced education around Australia.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will rescind these regressive decisions and desist from obvious attempts to pave the way for a complete re-introduction of tertiary fees.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Service Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That, as ex-servicemen are eligible to receive a service pension five years earlier than other Australian males are eligible to receive an age pension, subject to certain conditions, so too should the age at which the means test is applied to pension increases be reduced for service pensioners by five years to age 65.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will, in recognition of the service they have performed for their country, and because of reduced life expectancy as a result of that service, reduce the so-called means test free age limit for service pensioners from 70 years to 65.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Crown Property: Municipal Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the concentration of Commonwealth and State property in the City of Fremantle constitutes a burden on ratepayers to a degree not experienced by most municipalities in Australia.
That the non-payment of general rates by the Commonwealth and State Government imposes a 39 per cent higher rate in the dollar on Fremantle ratepayers.
That the 1980/81 Western Australian Grants Commission allocation to Fremantle of $460,000 does not adequately compensate for a loss of rate revenue conservatively estimated at $900,000.

That we support the efforts of the Fremantle Council to correct this inequitable treatment of its citizens and to resolve the contradiction whereby land owned by the Crown does not pay rates but property leased by the Crown includes a rate component.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That the Government give immediate effect to Recommendation 14 of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation Report of May 1978 which calls upon ''. . . the Commonwealth Government to recognise explicitly its obligation to compensate municipalities for loss of general rate revenue as a consequence of Commonwealth Government immunity in respect of Crown property'' and that Commonwealth statutory Authorities ''. . . be required as a matter of course to follow overall Commonwealth Government policy''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed New Constitution
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we believe that Australia's constitution is undemocratic and should be replaced by a democratic constitution, particularly as regards the new standard for regulation of vitamin and mineral supplements.
We believe:
1. This legislation will curb our individual freedom to care for our own health according to need, environment, climate, etc.
2. These substances have proven their efficacy in maintaining health rather than destroying it and should remain freely available.
3. Why curb these substances while other noxious and toxic substances are freely available to the obvious thorough detriment of our society-e.g. commercial alcohol and tobacco.

This new constitution should be drafted at a representative directly elected people's convention following extensive public debate, and then put to a referendum of the people. The petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament, as a matter of urgency, will help to promote such public debate and will arrange for the holding of such a people's convention and referendum.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Soviet Passenger Cruise Vessels
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

Owing to an overwhelming and continuous demand by the Australian people for a cruise service within the economic scope of the working man and his family, we request the Government to lift the ban placed on Soviet Passenger Cruise Vessels entering Australian Ports.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Women's Centres
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should take action as it deems appropriate to ensure the continuing functioning of the Betsy Women's Refuge and the network of shelters in Australia.

We ask that the Federal Government acknowledge that 'Betsy' and its counterparts provide housing and care for women and children in violent situations, and the Government agree to meet the financial responsibilities for continued and effective Refuge functioning.
The Federal Government should be informed that one in every five applicants are not accommodated at the Betsy Refuge due to overcrowding or full occupancy.
We therefore petition for full and adequate funding, and as petitioners for this we humbly pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Toxic Shock Syndrome
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned by the threats to women's health and lives posed by Toxic Shock Syndrome, and urge the following steps to be taken as a matter of urgency:

(1) Tampons, sanitary napkins, vaginal deodorants and similar sanitary products to be re-classified under Therapeutic Agents (not under 'Cosmetics' as at present), in order to bring them under the scrutiny of the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee. We believe manufacture must be under the strictest hygienic conditions.

(2) After re-classification, we urge an immediate government-funded inquiry into all aspects of manufacture and content of these products. This must lead to: (i) contents of product and instructions for correct usage to be shown on packaging; (ii) removal of synthetic fibres, chemicals or ingredients that are potentially or actually harmful to users.

(3) Allocation of extra funding for ongoing research by the National Health and Medical Research Council into these products, results of this research to be made public to ensure all health workers and potential users are fully informed. This campaign of public education would necessitate multilingual distribution of the information where appropriate.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take immediate and positive action to avert possible threats posed to women's health by implementation of the above measures.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:
1. Note that legislation establishing plant variety rights in other countries has had adverse effects, namely:

(a) Virtual monopoly control of seed production has passed into the hands of a few large international corporations seeking to profit from the exclusive rights over plant genetic materials created by such legislation.

(b) The varieties of seeds available have been restricted mainly to hybrids which will not reproduce truly and will not grow without the aid of artificial fertilizers and pesticides, thus maximising corporate profits without regard for the interests of growers and consumers.
(c) The genetic diversity of crops has been eroded, rendering them vulnerable to disease and other environmental threats.

2. Recognise the maintenance of the genetic diversity of plant varieties is crucial to the continued well-being of the Australian nation, and take all necessary steps to preserve and promote such genetic diversity as a public resource and to prevent exclusive control over plant genetic material from falling into private hands.

3. Defend the vital interests of Australian farmers and gardeners, independent Australian seed companies and their employees, and consumers of Australian farm and garden produce, by rejecting any proposal to legislate for the establishment of plant variety rights in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Trade Unions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we are gravely disturbed by the actions of militant unions, the ACTU and the failure of the President of the ACTU to assist positively in settling the dispute which has caused massive losses to Qantas our national airline, and we applaud the action of the Government in using RAAF planes to rescue Australians stranded abroad.

Your petitioners therfore humbly pray that the Federal Parliament and the Government should be of firm resolve not to permit such unions to hold the country to ransom and continue to take a forceful and resolute stand against such union militancy.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Garden Island, Western Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Rt. Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Western Australia respectfully showeth:

That although cottages Numbers 11, 12, 13, and 14 on Garden Island in no way impede construction at H.M.A.S. Stirling, they are now required by the Department of Administrative Services to move by 30th June, 1981.
Your Petitioners humbly pray that:
Cottages Numbers 11, 12, 13 and 14 on Garden Island be allowed to remain and to move only when the remaining northern end cottages do so.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Excise on Beer
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of the Division of Parramatta respectfully showeth.

That beer is the drink of the working man and that any increase in the excise on beer will place it in the luxury bracket and beyond the means of ordinary people. Australians are already the highest beer taxed people in the world; further increases in beer prices will both harm the brewing industry and fuel inflation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government not proceed with any proposals it may have to increase the excise on beer in the 1981/82 Federal Budget as such a move would be unacceptable to all beer drinking voters.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Staging of American B52 Bombers
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned in the Northern Territory respectfully showeth:
That the proposed use of Darwin Airport as a refuelling and Rest and Recreation base for American B52 bombers:

Jeopardizes the welfare of the citizens of Darwin and of all Australians, in that it establishes a stronger potential of Darwin being a nuclear target in any conflict between the U.S.A. and another power.
Impedes the sovereignty of the Australian nation in that Australian citizens would have neither control nor knowledge of whether B52s:
(a) Carried nuclear weapons
(b) Were engaged in bombing missions against another State.
Violates the Australian people's independence and links this nation irreconcilably with United States foreign policies thereby destroying the potential for independent Australian defence policy.

Violates democratic procedures in committing the Australian nation to participation in future wars without due consultation and informed assessment by Australian citizens and further increases the militarisation of the Indian Ocean thereby increasing the likelihood of super power conflict in this region.
Jeopardizes the welfare of the Citizens of Darwin, in that noise pollution and the threat of accidental radioactive fallout will increase substantially to the residents.
Negates the potential of the Australian nation to establish itself as a nation of Peace in the Pacific region and violates Australia's commitment to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty.

Your Petitioners therefore pray that the Members of the House of Representatives will ensure that the Prime Minister withdraw the offer of Darwin, or any other location in Australia, as a base or depot for American B52 Bombers. And that furthermore will ensure that any request of such usage by the U.S. Government be rejected.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nana Glen: Telephone Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The signatures on this petition indicate the disgust felt by the citizens of Nana Glen and surrounding areas towards the non-service received by Telecom Australia.

Since 1974, the communications system of this area has steadily deteriorated, while the growth rate has increased to such a level that the school enrolment has gone from 47 to 95 pupils in the same period.
With new residents receiving telephone connections as well, the congestion problem has also increased.

'A major project, necessary to eliminate the congestion problem, is programmed for completion in December 1980, this will provide an additional twelve trunk circuits between Nana Glen and Coffs Harbour.'
The above quote, was taken from correspondence received from the District Telecom Manager, Grafton, dated 10th October 1980.
The effect of this major program is yet to be seen, if it was ever implemented.
Although this is a rural area, we were under the impression that, as Australian ratepayers, we were entitled to a communications system as advanced as our urban counterparts.

Our system is medieval, and in 1981 is a disgrace to the Government of Australia. Do we have to experience a tragedy in our community to receive the service Telecom boasts of, or is this boast just a case of misrepresentation?
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that on the next day of sitting I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House calls on the Federal Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to effectively intervene on behalf of the Aboriginal people of Yarrabah and neighbouring communities (a) to prevent proposals that land traditionally held by them be developed for tourist purposes and (b) to provide effective Federal land rights legislation which will enable Queensland Aborigines and Islanders to pursue land rights claims in their own right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that on the next day of sitting I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in view of the continuing problems facing Australian Vietnam veterans, their wives and families allegedly caused by numerous herbicides, pesticides and other chemicals used in the Vietnam war, the rising costs of the Commonwealth Institute of Health epidemiological study and the difficulty of establishing control groups for study, this House calls on the Government to establish immediately an independent judicial inquiry to allow all of the scientific and medical evidence already available to be properly tested.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. In view of the considerable strain that would be placed on Australia's armed forces by an open-ended commitment to a Sinai peacekeeping force of half a battalion or full battalion strength, will the Minister oppose such a commitment? Does he remain committed to his often stated priority for the defence of Australia and his planning of force levels, equipment and structure? Will he in this context define Australia's area of strategic interest?

—As to the last part of the question asked by the honourable gentleman, that has been defined on a number of occasions by me in this House in the last 12 months. As to the other aspects of his question, when I first came into this House it was clearly laid down that questions of policy directed to Ministers were not answered, as such. The honourable gentleman has asked for information relating to Government policy.

—Is the Prime Minister aware of reports from Argentina indicating that our Deputy Prime Minister has stated that Australia would not take part in a peacekeeping force in the Sinai? Was such a statement made? Is such a statement a correct assessment of Australia's position on this matter or is the Government's current position the same as that outlined by the Minister for Foreign Affairs in his statement to this House on 26 May?

—When I first saw that report this morning I believed that it could not be correct because it did not represent Government policy which, as the honourable gentleman rightly has indicated, was outlined by the Minister for Foreign Affairs in a definitive statement to this Parliament. That statement indicates the serious nature of the question before the Australian Government and the nature of arguments both for and against Australia's participation which have to be weighed with the utmost seriousness before a final decision is made one way or the other. The Press Secretary of my colleague the Minister for Trade and Resources was in touch with him earlier today and I understand that a notice has already been put up in the Press Gallery indicating that the report was incorrect.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. In view of Israel's reprehensible action in Iraq, will the Prime Minister deny the supply of Australian forces to a non-United Nations force in the Middle East?

—I think it is generally realised that what has happened in recent days, or even hours, in the Middle East will only add to tensions. I would have thought that many governments would want to do all they could to reduce tensions. Israel and Egypt have been in pursuit of peace between them. Ten years ago that would have been regarded as an impossible achievement, but it has been advanced by the Camp David Accords. They may not have gone as far as many people would like; nonetheless the situation is a vast improvement on the state of open hostility and warfare that had existed between Israel and Egypt in the past. If things can be done to advance the cause of peace in the Middle East, I believe that any government should weigh the consequences seriously. There should not be a necessary connection between the events of the last day or two and the furtherance of the Camp David Accords. I hope that honourable members of this House will be able to keep the two things separate in their own judgments.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Acting Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I refer to my speech in this House on 13 May concerning the refusal of the Polish authorities to permit the immigration to Australia of the wives and children of recent Polish refugees in Australia. Can the Minister inform the House whether any progress has been made in negotiations between the Australian and Polish governments on this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House is well aware of the interest and concern of the honourable member for Wentworth in this matter. The House is also aware that the Government is currently accepting approximately 4,500 East European refugees in this financial year. This is the highest intake of the program which has been running for some years and which has always included a high proportion of Polish refugees. At the time the refugees are interviewed by Australian immigration authorities they are advised to expect considerable difficulties in the achievement of family reunions in the event of their settling in Australia. This is not the making of the Australian Government but rather reflects difficulties that members of the refugee families can expect in being granted exit authorities by the Polish Government. Reports received by the Government early this year suggested that since the events of late 1980 the Polish authorities were becoming more liberal in the issue of passports for travel to Western countries. According to one recent report, the number of travel documents issued so far this year is 45 per cent higher than in the corresponding period last year. However, it now appears that this general liberalisation is not always being extended to the families of people whom the Polish Government regard as being illegally abroad.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government has received complaints that passport applications are being refused and of attendant difficulties being experienced by family members of Polish refugees. The House can be assured that the Government is concerned about an early and acceptable solution to the problem of family reunions and is conscious of the anxiety of members of the Polish community. We will continue to make representations to the Polish authorities in such cases where these are seen to be helpful and appropriate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister will recall that in a cable to General Haig the Minister for Foreign Affairs stated that the area to be covered by the Sinai multilateral military force is beyond the area of direct strategic concern to Australia. In the same cable he also drew attention to the commitment of Australia to providing troops for a United Nations force in Namibia. I ask the Prime Minister: Is it appropriate that Australia should commit its limited military resources to an area which the Government indicates is of limited or no strategic concern to Australia and for a purpose that the Foreign Minister informed General Haig the Government did not consider necessary?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not comment on the substance of questions based on communications between my colleague and Secretary of State Haig. I am disturbed at the persistent thrust of questioning by members of the Opposition. Quite plainly the Middle East area has been disturbed by hostilities for decades. We know quite well that a major disturbance or difficulty, a further movement by the Soviet Union from Afghanistan to Iran using what it has gained in Afghanistan as a foothold, would have possibilities of enormous consequence for the whole world. Whilst that area might be beyond Australia's direct strategic area of concern-let me emphasise the word 'direct'-it is quite clear that events could happen in the Middle East which would be of vast consequence to all the Western world, including Australia, and of vast consequence to the peace of the world. It is against that background that I think any Australian government ought to look seriously at the arguments for and the undoubted arguments against any possible Australian involvement. There are legitimate and honourable arguments on both sides of this equation. It comes, finally, therefore, to a matter of judgment by the Australian Government as to what is in the best interests of Australia and of our contribution to peace.

ANSWER.PARA: We have been involved in other areas beyond our direct strategic interest. We have said that we are prepared to contribute to the United Nations peacekeeping force in Namibia. That is not in our direct area of interest, but it will help to advance the common cause of peace and well-being of peoples if the United Nations proposals for Namibia can be put into effect. That will involve a multination peacekeeping force. On many occasions we have been involved in areas beyond our direct strategic interest because we have a concern for the well-being and peace of mankind.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, that was a very statesmanlike reply, to the previous question. Does the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment recall that some years ago, at the time of the referendum to choose a national tune, the nation was advised that in due course a suitable form of words would be chosen? Is the Minister aware of my forwarding to his predecessor several word form suggestions received by me from people right across the nation and my asking his predecessor whether we are awaiting a revolution before something is done? Can I inform my constituents that the present words are now official, or has the Government something else positive in mind? If so, when will the long awaited decision be made?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am aware and other members of this House are well aware that in 1977 a poll was taken to get the view of the Australian people as to which tune they preferred for a national tune. The majority of people at that poll indicated that they wanted the tune known as Advance Australia Fair. Since that time there have been many suggestions as to which words should be used, for there are at present no official words for that tune. In 1979 the Government established the National Australia Day Committee and sought from that Committee its views on the words which might be used for the tune. That Committee considered the traditional words by P. McCormick. It also sought the advice of the Literature Board of the Australia Council, and a contemporary poet was asked to put forward some suggestions. Many suggestions were received from people around the country.

ANSWER.PARA: I am aware of the great interest of the honourable member for Fadden and constituents within the electorate of Fadden whose words he has sent to me for consideration. There are continuing representations on the matter. I am aware that there is great interest in a decision as to what words should be adopted, and the matter is under consideration. I am not in a position to indicate when a decision can be reached as to what will be the official words. When that decision is reached one would hope that a conclusion can be achieved resulting in words that will be generally acceptable to the Australian people.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Is it still the Australian Government's view, as stated in a cable to United States Secretary of State Haig on 27 April, that European Community countries have a major stake in a peaceful settlement in the Middle East? Is it also still the case, as stated in that cable, that the Australian Government is particularly concerned that no major European countries appear to be under active consideration as possible participants in the proposed United States-organised peacekeeping force in the Sinai? In the event that Australia agrees to join the peacekeeping force, does this reluctance by nations with an established stake in Middle East peace to endorse the American proposal expose an Australian contingent to the charge that it is a mere rump force and part of a United States strategic ground presence in the area? In view of these considerations, and in view of the serious escalation of violence in the Middle East arising from the Israeli raid on Iraq, will the Government declare unequivocally that Australia will not take part in the Sinai peacekeeping force and become embroiled in a situation that is becoming increasingly dangerous?

—It seems that today the Opposition has a series of prepared questions with which it will continue despite the answers in relation to this matter given by the Prime Minister and by the Minister for Foreign Affairs before he left Australia. Australia's attitude towards the peacekeeping force has been elaborated inside and outside this House. A series of questions has been asked in relation to it. Our attitude is utterly clear and we do not propose to depart from that stated attitude.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Primary Industry. I refer to his answers to previous questions in which he indicated that he would make a full report to Parliament on matters raised as a consequence of the audit inspection of the accounts and records of Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd when all inquiries were completed. I ask: Did the Minister announce that he would table papers relating to this matter? Can the Minister inform the House of the current position in regard to the matter?

—I had hoped to be in a position to table the relevant documents and make the appropriate statement today. Unfortunately, as late as last night the Australian Federal Police informed my Department that one or two aspects of the investigation required further work. Therefore, I am not in a position to make the relevant statement. Of course, when the appropriate time comes I will table the relevant papers and make the appropriate statement.

—My question, which is directed to the Prime Minister, follows his answer to the question asked by the honourable member for Perth. In view of the statement allegedly made yesterday in Argentina by the Deputy Prime Minister, previous statements made in Singapore by the Deputy Prime Minister that sending arms to Afghanistan guerrillas would be helping subversives, and statements made in Cairo opposing an Australian participation in the Sinai force, will the Prime Minister consult with his Minister for Health to ensure that the Deputy Prime Minister is swabbed for foot in mouth disease before re-entering Australia?
—Order! I call the honourable member for Mitchell.

—Has the Treasurer noted the intention of the Queensland Government to avoid demands on infrastructure borrowing by having private enterprise build a power station complex? Is the decision an example that other States could follow? What would be the effect on the economy of States seeking alternative methods of financing projects rather than borrowing funds themselves?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen some Press reports this morning of a disposition on the part of the Queensland Government to encourage private enterprise to construct some power stations in that State. Not having seen the fine print of the decision, all I can say at this stage is that, if in fact the Queensland Government in future is going to adopt the practice of encouraging private enterprise to do things that private enterprise is able to do, this Government can only welcome that decision. As honourable gentlemen will know, projects such as power stations, if undertaken by private enterprise, are subject to the test of profit, which is a very important consideration so far as undertakings of this type are concerned.

ANSWER.PARA: As the honourable gentleman will know, the Commonwealth has invited the States to examine what parts of proposed infrastructure projects could be carried out by private enterprise. We understand that that matter is currently being considered by the States. I can further say in reply to the honourable gentleman only that, if indeed the Queensland Government has decided to place a greater emphasis on encouraging private enterprise to undertake these things, that is to be welcomed, and if in fact it is carried through to action it is an example that could properly be followed by other States.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Prime Minister recall a secret cable from the Minister for Foreign Affairs to the United States Secretary of State, Mr Haig, on 27 April? I ask whether the Minister for Foreign Affairs said, inter alia:

QUESTION.PARA: Our initial view is that if we received such a request--
That is, to participate in the Sinai multinational military force-
and if we agreed to make a contribution there could be advantage in such a request coming in the name of Egypt and Israel, being the countries on whose territory the force is to operate.
I ask the Prime Minister whether the Minister also said in that cable:

I realise that the previous American Administration made a commitment to establish the force but I would be glad to know whether you would see any difficulty in the formal request coming in the name of your two partners.

I ask the Prime Minister: Why is it necessary to resort to this sort of deceit against the Parliament and the public, redolent in some important ways of the manner in which a previous conservative government of which he was a member--

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the honourable gentleman not to comment in relation to past events. He will proceed with his question.
—I will put it as a direct question. Does he agree that this sort of deceitful tactic is redolent in some important ways--
—Order! The honourable gentleman is not entitled to use the word 'deceitful' in the course of his question.

—I am sorry. Does he agree that this undesirable device is redolent in some important ways of the manner in which a previous conservative government of which he was a member incited United States military escalation in the Vietnam war and then contrived an invitation from the then South Vietnamese Government to participate in that military engagement?

—The honourable gentleman has more than once in this Parliament tried to peddle that kind of argument. But let me say only that I would have thought that any Australian government would want to know quite plainly, since the Camp David Accords relate to peace between Egypt and Israel, that if there were to be a peacekeeping force the total membership of that force would be completely acceptable to both Egypt and Israel. The best way to achieve that is quite plainly to follow the course that the Minister for Foreign Affairs outlined. But at the same time that communication makes it perfectly plain that no decision has been made. The response of the Secretary of State to that also acknowledges quite plainly that no decision has been made by the Australian Government, as indeed it has not up to this point. I have no doubt that the attempts by the Leader of the Opposition to relate the circumstances in the Middle East to circumstances in Indo-China will be noted.
—Mr Speaker, on a point of order-
—This will not be a point of order either because the Leader of the Opposition--
—This is misrepresentation. This is end-of-term dishonesty.

—Order! The right honourable gentleman will resume his seat. The Leader of the Opposition is entitled to speak only if he has a point of order, not if he has an objection to what is being said. Is it a point of order?

—It is a point of order. I am claiming that there is a misrepresentation. I am drawing a parallel between the behaviour of the Government then, a decade and a half ago, and now. I am not relating it necessarily to the circumstances in the Middle East. It is a pity that the Prime Minister could not be a little honest for a change.
—There is no point of order.

—The honourable gentleman can ask his left wing questions, but when he asks those left wing questions he needs to understand that he will get the appropriate response. The attempt by the Leader of the Opposition to equate circumstances in the Middle East with circumstances as they then existed in Indo-China will be noted very clearly by many tens of thousands of people in this country.
—I raise a point of order. The Prime Minister is trying to re-erect a defence for the very devious device he is resorting to.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat. He knows there is no point of order.
—I am not talking about circumstances in the Middle East; I am talking about the devious behaviour of the Prime Minister.

—I wish to draw to the attention of the Leader of the Opposition that he is bound by the Standing Orders, as is every other member of the House. I certainly give him greater tolerance than any other member of the House, but I ask him not to transgress upon my tolerance. He knows the Standing Orders, and what he has been saying is not a point of order at all.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Transport, concerns developmental work at Townsville airport. Did the 1980-81 Budget allocation of $5m allow for certain planned work to be undertaken to provide initial facilities for the introduction of international services at Townsville airport? Has the cost of the works escalated to $5.6m and has the additional $600,000 been provided by the Government? Have any of the works been abandoned? Are the works to be completed in about mid-July, as provided for in the main project contract? Is the Government considering financing additional work not originally planned last year? Will the Government go ahead with planning and providing new domestic airport facilities at Townsville?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure of the over-run of expenditure at the Townsville airport, if there is any over-run, but I would like to assure the honourable member that none of the works referred to has been abandoned. Construction is proceeding to schedule. Only one or two minor items are expected to be completed beyond the end of July. All the initial works have been completed or will be completed by then, to facilitate the limited number of international flights from and to Townsville at the present time. A number of other works are currently being considered by the Department. One of them is the construction of additional apron for domestic air services. There is provision for a shelter between the international airport and the domestic facilities and additional car park facilities for international traffic. Quite a lot of planning is being done to improve the total facility at that airport.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government, in the course of its budgetary considerations, will take a decision on the level of expenditure and the level of priority which will be accorded to that expenditure within the overall expenditure for airports throughout Australia. I might say that the Government is facing a very substantial capital outlay in airport expenditure right around Australia. The latest estimates indicate that it could be somewhere between $1,300m and $1,400m over the next decade in order to accommodate the wide-bodied jets and to provide upgraded facilities at some of our major capital city airports. Townsville, now being an international airport, will of course be receiving the priority necessary to maintain a growing degree of traffic from that airport. I would like to thank the honourable member for Herbert, as the local member for that area, for the co-operation that he has given me in relation to plans that have been developed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Prime Minister: Is it a fact that Mr Turnbull, the Director of Regional Administration of the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs, refused to co-operate with the New South Wales Health Commission in a study of the effects of unemployment on youth? The basis for the refusal was: 'It is departmental policy not to co-operate with researchers'. Is it also a fact that the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs even questioned whether Mr Chris Lennings, a psychologist working with the Marrickville community health centre, could hand out questionnaires outside Commonwealth Employment Service offices? Can the Prime Minister advise the House whether this new policy of secrecy has been introduced only since the honourable member for Kooyong resigned as Minister for Industrial Relations?

—It is extraordinary that one has to wait until the last day of this parliamentary session to receive a question from the Opposition that relates to employment, unemployment or the employment difficulties of Aboriginals or disabled persons. But at least we now have one question, the first question for the session. Let me say that there is no policy of secrecy in this matter at all. With respect to the--
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The Minister's statement is completely wrong. I asked a question on employment last week.
—There is no point of order. I suggest to the Minister that he remain relevant to the question.

—The honourable member's question was ignored by everyone in the House and the media, so far as I recall. I repeat that it is extraordinary, when the Government emphasises the importance that it attaches to employment and unemployment issues, that one should see a complete lack of interest by the Opposition in these subjects. With respect to the specific question raised, there is certainly no policy of secrecy in this matter. I will raise with my officers the specific matters which the honourable member raised about New South Wales. If there is any information that is appropriate I will certainly pass it on to the honourable member.

—Can the Minister for Administrative Services advise the House of the progress and achievements of the Federal-New South Wales police task force established in 1979 by the Commonwealth and New South Wales governments following the recommendations of the Williams and Woodward royal commissions into drugs? In particular, can he give details of the costs incurred in mounting this task force and the number of officers involved?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman The Hon K.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Organised crime, and particularly drug trafficking as a part of that organised crime scene, presents very large problems to this Government and to various State governments. Therefore, the Commonwealth Government, in co-operation with State governments, is determined that it will develop its policing agencies, particularly the Australian Federal Police, so that the people involved in organised crime and drug trafficking can be sought out and eventually brought to justice. The formation of the joint task force with the New South Wales Government was a joint initiative following the Woodward and Williams royal commissions. The honourable member asked about the number of people involved. We have 15 Australian Federal Police officers attached to the task force, as well as three administrative officers who are provided by the Department of Administrative Services. I am told that the net cost up to the end of this financial year is estimated at about $380,000. That is after allowance is made for the cost-sharing arrangements between the two governments.

ANSWER.PARA: The methods that have been used by the task force are those that were recommended by Williams and Woodward. Basically, the task force is targeting its efforts on those people who are central to drug trafficking or drug trafficking groups. Of recent months the Commonwealth directed that the task force extend its activities to looking into drug trafficking associated with the Nugan Hand bank and people involved in drug trafficking who may have had associations with the Nugan Hand bank. The work of the task force will take a long time. I am advised that up to 1 May the task force can claim the following achievements: Five groups involved in the importation of heroin have been broken up. Another four groups supplying heroin have also been broken up, as well as a minor group that has been supplying morphine. In all, a total of 66 offenders have been charged on a total of 186 counts, including 40 persons in relation to the importation and supply of heroin and three in relation to the supply of morphine. Until 21 April this year a total of 718.5 grams of heroin had been seized by the task force.

I reiterate that the commitment of the Government, in co-operation with State governments, to attacking those people involved, particularly those central to organised crime, is something that we intend to pursue with all the vigour we can. I have spoken about only one task force. Other task forces have been established or are intended to be established with the New South Wales and Victorian governments. I hope that as the months unfold the sort of success that the New South Wales-Commonwealth task force is having will also be evident in those task forces.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Communications aware of commitments made by his predecessor to establish an Australian Broadcasting Commission frequency modulation radio station in the area near Port Pirie to provide an FM radio service to the northern areas of South Australia? Have these plans been either deferred or scrapped as a result of the activities of the razor gang? If so, when is it anticipated that the station will be established to provide this service to this area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a result of the Broadcasting and Television Act amendment a capacity has been provided to the Government to allocate FM commercial stations throughout regional areas of Australia. It is my intention, once the legislation has passed through Parliament and been proclaimed, to produce a policy proposal, which will be distributed for public information, on the general ambit of the program for extension of FM broadcasting beyond the city areas, where it is now operating on a commercial basis. The next stage certainly will take into account the area to which the honourable gentleman referred. I am aware that there are pockets in that area where significant difficulties are experienced in getting adequate alternative channels on most household radio sets. At the same time, public broadcasting licences are also being issued in a number of areas.

ANSWER.PARA: There is no impact at all, either on the issue of public broadcasting licences or on commercial FM licences, from anything that was decided in the Review of Commonwealth Functions. Our intention is to proceed with those in due course, and I hope that before too long there can be a reasonable extension to the honourable gentleman's electorate. The Australian Broadcasting Commission FM stations depend on the overall funds to be provided for the ABC. As I indicated in this House yesterday, they are matters that are still to be concluded in discussions between the ABC and the Government and, of course, will be announced in this Parliament in the Budget context.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Treasurer to questions that were asked in this House last week concerning further amendments to section 26E of the Income Tax Assessment Act. The Treasurer will be aware that there is a similar concern by other employee taxpayers, particularly those staff engaged in sugar mills, who were notified by the Taxation Office on 5 September 1980 that, pending further clarification of the basis of valuing subsidised housing accommodation for income tax purposes, as an interim measure tax would be based on the values applying before the valuation made in 1977-78. Can the Treasurer advise whether, in the absence of any review, notification or amending legislation, the values previous to 1977-78 will be applied in the income tax assessments of these taxpayers for the year up to and including 30 June 1981?

—The Commissioner of Taxation has informed me that the interim arrangements to which the honourable member for Dawson referred in his question, and which base pay-as-you-earn deductions in respect of those employees on values prevailing several years ago, will continue pending the introduction of the legislation.

—I refer the Prime Minister to his statement that the 'system of public funding of political parties is corrupt'. Is the Prime Minister aware that the system of funding of political parties applies in the United States, Canada, France, Austria, West Germany and Sweden, amongst other countries? If the Prime Minister is aware of these things, does he believe that all these countries have a corrupt electoral system? If he does believe this, will he assure the House that he will not raise these questions when he visits these countries and thus make Australia look mean in the eyes of the other countries?

—What I have said, of course, is that the legislation in New South Wales will be corruptive and corrosive, and it is. It means quite plainly that every time Mr Wran cannot build a pre-school and cannot do something for a school or hospital he is saying that the funding of the Australian Labor Party with taxpayers' dollars is more important than that pre-school, that women's refuge and all the rest. If that is Mr Wran's and the Labor Party's exhibition of political priorities, quite plainly it is not ours. In addition to that, the Wran socialist legislation establishes an inspectorate which will make it possible for the New South Wales Government to discriminate against individuals and corporations that provide funds to other political parties. It will also make it possible for the New South Wales socialist Government to give that information to trade unions, which would then use their undoubted power to destroy the corporations that might be involved. The purposes of this legislation are certainly of very doubtful merit. They will be corruptive of the political processes in New South Wales. They represent a condemnation of the political priorities of the Wran Government. The most insidious part of the legislation is the establishment of the inspectorate, which will be able to look into the books of political parties, with the resulting invasion of privacy involved and then the possible use of the information that will be thus gained.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. It is a good point of order, Mal. Just wait and hear it.
—I call the honourable member for Port Adelaide on a point of order.

—I asked the Prime Minister whether he believes that the systems applying in all the countries I mentioned are corrupt. As President Reagan received $US21m for his election, is President Reagan corrupt? Is President Mitterrand corrupt?
—Order! The honourable member for Port Adelaide will resume his seat. There is no point of order.

—My comments have related to the New South Wales Government's legislation and the intent of that legislation. The Australian Labor Party ought to be ashamed indeed of this use of public funds. We are debating the political systems in this country, not those in some other country where different customs and practices prevail.
—Order! I ask honourable members on my left to remain silent while the answer is given.
—How could we expect them to remain silent when they know quite well that the purpose of the legislation is indeed corrupt?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members, I present the report of the Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission, together with typewritten copies of consultants' reports on: Audience research studies, parts 1 to 3; financial management ABC records; ABC engineering services, parts 1 and 2; industrial relations and staff management, parts 1 to 3. Bulk copies of the report are available in limited numbers in the Table Office. Limited copies of the consultants' reports are also available now in the Parliamentary Library and the Table Office. Final printed versions of the consultants' reports will be made available as soon as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Mr Killen) proposed:
That the House take note of the papers.
Debate (on motion by Mr Hurford) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Corio has indicated he wishes my indulgence.

—Yes, Mr Speaker. I wish to raise with you a matter which is of some concern to honourable members. It was reported in the weekend Press that every member of this Parliament was provided with a new refrigerator last week. I ask whether you could have some investigations carried out to find out where those refrigerators went.
—I do not need to carry out any investigation to know that that report is incorrect. I did not see the report, but if it were so reported, it is totally incorrect.
—For the information of honourable members, I present the resolutions of the one hundred and tenth meeting of the Australian Agricultural Council, February 1981.

—Pursuant to section 50 (1) of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976, I present a report by the Aboriginal Land Commissioner on the Finniss River land claim, together with the text of a statement by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs relating to the report.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL COMMITTEE ON DISCRIMINATION IN EMPLOYMENT AND OCCUPATION

TALKER.NAME: Mr N. A. BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members, I present the seventh annual report of the National Committee on discrimination in Employment and Occupation for 1979-80.
—Pursuant to section 162 of the Superannuation Act 1976, I present the annual reports of the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust and the Commissioner for Superannuation for 1979-80.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDICATIVE PLANNING COUNCIL FOR THE HOUSING INDUSTRY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members, I present the Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry report 1981. I seek leave to make a statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Indicative Planning Council is an independent and authoritative advisory body which forecasts short, medium and long term trends in the housing industry. Membership of the Council is drawn from builders' and industry organisations, organisations in the housing finance sector, trade unions, the real estate industry, materials suppliers, the Reserve Bank of Australia, Commonwealth departments and individuals prominent in the housing industry. Council Chairman, Professor Noel Drane, is Professor of Economics at Macquarie University, Sydney. Besides the national Council, committees operate in each State and the Australian Capital Territory. It is impressive to see the way that members of the industry with such varied backgrounds have worked hard together to produce such a timely and relevant report. Sectional interests have been set aside so that an impartial overview of industry prospects could be compiled. I thank Council members, and particularly the Chairman, for their work.

SPEECH.PARA: The report concludes that due to the impact of the resources boom, higher overseas migration and the emerging widely-based recovery in the economy, demand for housing will show a gradual increase over the coming three years. Further growth in demand is likely during the 1980s. The report also predicts that housing activity will increase not only this financial year but also in 1981-82. Dwelling completions are forecast to increase from 129,300 in 1979-80 to 135,500 in 1980-81 and to 139,000 in 1981-82. Dwelling commencements, after showing strong growth in 1979-80, will increase to 136,000 in 1980-81 and 139,000 in 1981-82. Such forecasts, which are good news for the housing industry, are given added weight by the calibre and composition of the Council. But the Council also notes that this relatively strong picture for activity is dependent on housing finance institutions being able to compete for funds at interest rates which do not choke off demand.

The council also recognises that the national picture hides wide variations at the State and regional level. In 1981-82 activity is expected to increase markedly in Victoria, Western Australia, the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory, remain buoyant in Queensland, show some recovery in South Australia, remain stable in Tasmania and decline marginally in New South Wales. The capital investment surge, particularly in resource related projects, is identified as a major influence on housing activity during the 1980s. It will bring significant benefits to the housing industry but also may create problems. The main message contained in the report is that the health of the housing industry will depend upon sound policies and planning by all levels of government, designed to ensure that the industry is a beneficiary not a casualty of the resources boom. The resources boom is already placing large demands on the capital market. The industry is facing competition from semi-government authorities borrowing to finance resource related projects and infrastructure development.

The Commonwealth Government has sought to restrain its own demands on the capital market by reducing overall public sector borrowing and by reining in the deficit. But the Commonwealth Government cannot expect to be able to overcome all the problems on its own. We will lead the way but planning, co-operative effort and far sighted policies are required from all levels of government. State Governments should examine their expenditure plans critically to ensure they do not siphon off too large a share of available finance and labour. They should plan adequately for the housing and social facilities they need before they permit massive development.

If all governments do not discipline their own demands and those of their authorities, housing borrowers could be crowded out and the building industry dealt a damaging blow. I hope this is borne in mind by States when they come to the Loan Council discussions on 19 June. At the same time State Governments should be aware that unrealistic interest rate ceilings imposed on permanent building societies are hindering the flow of funds to these institutions. Neither the permanent building societies nor any other financial institutions are guaranteed a share of available funds.
