TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received advice from the Leader of the Government in the Senate nominating Senator Teague to be a member of the Joint Committee on the New Parliament House, and from the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate nominating Senators Colston and Sibraa also to be members of that Committee from 1 July 1981.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lusher Mr S.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Expenditure I present the report of the Committee entitled 'Commonwealth Government Purchasing', together with a transcript of evidence and minutes of proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask for leave to make a short statement in connection with the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report is the result of the Expenditure Committee's largest inquiry in terms of the amount of information examined and the length of the inquiry. It arose out of concerns expressed to members of the Committee by companies supplying goods to the Commonwealth. The main complaints were of delays in awarding contracts and paying for goods. After a preliminary hearing in September 1978, a sub-committee was established on 25 October 1978 to examine the efficiency of administrative procedures and the effectiveness of the purchasing program in meeting its objectives. I would like to thank my colleague the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) for his tireless and thoughtful contribution as Chairman of the Sub-committee. He was a member of the Sub-committee from its inception. I must also thank the other member of the Sub-committee, the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay), and former members of the Sub-committee, particularly the former member for Henty, Ken Aldred, and the former member for Grayndler, the late Frank Stewart. I was also a member of the Sub-committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Expenditure on purchases of goods and services by the Commonwealth Government is a mess. In 1980-81 the estimated net expenditure, less the salaries and wages of those conducting purchasing, is $4,461m which is over 12 per cent of estimated Commonwealth outlays. In addition, the Committee has calculated there are about 2,000 purchasing staff with salaries totalling over $25m in the current financial year. Although responsibility for purchasing is dispersed throughout the Commonwealth Government the prime responsibility lies with the Purchasing Division in the Department of Administrative Services. It became apparent to the Committee that the Department of Administrative Services has made significant advances in its operations since the Scott committee completed its inquiry into Commonwealth purchasing in 1974, although some deficiencies remain. By contrast, in other departments and authorities there are many elements of purchasing which have glaring weaknesses. The exceptions to this broad criticism are the trading authorities-that is, those engaged in commercial competition-where purchasing sections appear to be in generally better shape. The Committee believes in many departments and authorities the attention of senior management is confined to matters directly related to the department's area of interest with the result that ancillary matters, including purchasing, receive less attention.

The Committee has made 54 recommendations affecting all stages of the purchasing process. The main categories of recommendations are aimed at making purchasing more efficient by avoiding unnecessary expenditure, paying less for goods purchased and reducing staffing requirements. Other recommendations are designed to improve public accountability, examine the effectiveness of programs and improve the management and use of resources. Over the course of the inquiry the Committee looked at a wide range of examples of government purchasing and uncovered many areas of bureaucratic absurdity. The purchase of crockery was an example of this. The House may be interested in brief details of what the Committee learned from evidence on that subject, particularly in relation to the problem of overspecification.

Whilst some departments and authorities judged that commercially available crockery if made to hotelware standard was acceptable, others demanded from suppliers the most stringent tests; so much so that until recently the Department of Veterans' Affairs considered Australian produced crockery unacceptable for its requirements. This meant that the Department of Veterans' Affairs paid 40 per cent to 100 per cent more for crockery than other departments with similar crockery usage. In relation to the Department of Defence, there were two crockery specifications-a 12-page one for other ranks and sergeants messes and an 18-page specification for the officers mess. Included were detailed engineering drawings for the manufacture of a crockery impact machine to test crockery for breakage.

The Committee has already achieved some results from the inquiry process itself. The Committee has been successful in having one piece of red tape removed. During the inquiry the Committee found that departments had to obtain approval from the Public Service Board when purchasing office machines. This seemed unnecessary and created inordinate delays. The rules were changed so that only in cases of large value purchases of office machines and for some specified categories did departments need to seek approval from the Public Service Board. Also, a series of threshold levels within the tendering process have been raised in line with the Committee's earlier discussion with the Department of Administrative Services.

Before concluding, I wish to pay tribute to the work of Kevin Newbold and Bob Harlow who were the clerks to the Sub-committee. The report owes much to the consciencious work of these two able young men over the course of the inquiry. This has been a long and exhaustive inquiry. The Committee believes its findings and recommendations will assist in more efficient and more effective purchasing. As I indicated earlier, we are talking about $4.5 billion in total and over 12 per cent of the Commonwealth Budget. We look forward to the response of the Government to this report and hope that there will be a broad measure of agreement with the recommendations we have made. I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave- As my colleague the honourable member for Hume (Mr Lusher) has said, the report on Commonwealth Government purchasing is the result of an exhaustive and comprehensive inquiry. Fifty-four recommendations are included covering all aspects of purchasing. If the Government implements the recommendations, which I trust it will, there should be a significant improvement in the efficiency and effectiveness with which Commonwealth goods are purchased. There were 236 submissions to the Committee and 75 witnesses appeared before the Committee. Members of the Committee, the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay) and the honourable member for Hume, made tremendous contributions to the work of the Committee and in the final stages of preparation of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The Sub-committee Chairman during the last Parliament was the former member for Henty, Mr Ken Aldred. He was the main force behind the inquiry and I believe its success is due in considerable measure to the energy he put into it. The late Frank Stewart, the former member for Grayndler, was also on the original sub-committee when it was formed on 25 September 1978. It is hoped that the report reflects the feelings of these two former members. I also wish to make special and favourable mention of the work of the clerk to the Expenditure Committee, Mr M. E. Aldons, and the clerks to the Sub-committee, Mr R. S. Harlow and Mr K. Newbold. Their dedication, their efficiency and their attention to detail has made this the effective report I believe it to be.

The expenditure on purchases by the Government is significant, as has been mentioned by the honourable member for Hume. This is referred to in paragraphs 12 and 13 of the report. The Joint Committees of Public Accounts and Foreign Affairs and Defence have recently published reports on the purchase of computer and defence equipment respectively. Consequently the Expenditure Committee did not subject these areas to the same degree of scrutiny as it did other areas. The Committee determined the essential elements for effective and efficient purchasing in the Commonwealth. Together these constitute a model of how purchasing should be conducted. In the report these are examined in the logical sequence in which goods are purchased, from deciding what and how much is needed, to ensuring the quality of the goods supplied.

The Committee has been anxious not to try improving purchasing by adding more rules, regulations and controls. Rather, it has devised simpler, cheaper and more effective ways of getting goods for the Commonwealth. The Committee does not recommend a central purchasing body for the Commonwealth but suggests that all departments take advantage of the expertise in purchasing built up in other departments, particularly the Department of Administrative Services. The major category of recommendations is designed to reduce costs of goods purchased. The Committee has recommended greater use of government bulk purchasing power. Although the Department of Administrative Services has already made advances in this direction, a lot more needs to be done. The Commonwealth, as previously indicated, is a major purchaser and as such should be able to use its bulk to get better prices, for instance in hospital supplies.

In Canberra almost $1m is spent on warehousing facilities for centralised purchasing within the Capital Territory Health Commission, but each hospital still has its own purchasing staff, storage, accounts, et cetera. Much of the purchasing is conducted in ignorance of where other hospitals are buying their goods and for how much. This relates also to the States. The Committee found a great deal of support for centralising purchasing within the CTHC, but so far nothing has been done.

The Committee has recommended that a more careful analysis be made of the buying of goods rather than leasing or hiring. There is a temptation to lease because of short term advantages, whilst committing the Commonwealth to high long term payments. For example, the Committee estimated that for the major brand of photocopiers used in the Public Service, the saving by buying rather than leasing would be $1.4m over the life of the machines. There are also recommendations on program effectiveness. The Government has a commendable policy of giving preference to Australian-made goods to aid industry recovery, increase employment and improve productivity. However, the Committee felt there were problems. For instance: Firstly, protection provided is small in aggregate; secondly, it discriminates in favour of industries which are major government suppliers; thirdly, it does not focus on employment; fourthly, the costs of policy are unknown and, fifthly, it has not been subject to in-depth review.

The Committee believes there is an urgent need both for improvements in the collection of information on benefits and costs of Australian preference and for a detailed review of the impact of these programs. The Committee has been concerned for suppliers of goods to the Commonwealth, especially small businesses. The Committee has recommended that unsuccessful tenderers be advised more thoroughly as to why they were unsuccessful. The Committee has also recommended two-phase tendering be introduced so that every firm does not have to supply detailed tenders initially.

The Committee also inquired into the payment of accounts for purchasers and felt that, through a previous Government instruction, this process had been shortened. Other recommendations simplify and shorten procedures, thereby reducing staff requirements; for example, revised quality control procedures which would reduce Government inspections and place a greater reliance on the firm's quality control. Again I pay tribute to the co-operation of the Committee members and of those witnesses who appeared before it in the genuine hope, I believe, that answers and suggestions could be given to improve this major part of Government involvement.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I commend this report to the Government. The honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) has spoken at length on the recommendations in the report, and I believe he should be congratulated on producing such an excellent report. He is the longest serving member of a rather lengthy inquiry. When one looks at the members who have come and gone from the Standing Committee on Expenditure over the years the inquiry has continued, it is obvious that the honourable member for Dawson would know more about government purchasing than most people presently in this Parliament. As has been said earlier, this report points out most vividly that purchasing on behalf of the Commonwealth Government is in an absolute shambles, and no department shows that more than the Department of Defence. I believe that the Committee's report highlights the same problems in the Department of Defence as those shown by the Katter Sub-committee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. I think that the sooner the Government tightens up the procedures of Commonwealth Government purchasing, the sooner the wastage in that area of Commonwealth expenditure will be removed. I conclude my remarks by congratulating Bob Harlow, the Expenditure Committee officer who finally put together the report. That work will stand as an example of some of the good work parliamentary committees can do to assist the Government and the bureaucracy to fulfil their functions.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND DEFENCE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence I present the Committee's report entitled 'Power in Indo-China since 1975', together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-This report fol- lows the decision by the Committee, in November 1979, to inquire into 'The changing power structure in Indo-China since 1975 and its effects on Australia and the region'. Sub-Committee A undertook the reference and, in the course of the inquiry, submissions were received and evidence heard from a wide variety of individuals and representatives of organisations. These include nationals and diplomatic representatives of the Indo-Chinese countries, Australian academics with expert knowledge of the region, representatives of Commonwealth departments, and United Nations representatives. Five members of Sub-Committee A individually visited the region between 1979 and 1981, which has provided the Committee with valuable first-hand information, especially regarding the refugee situation and conditions in Kampuchea.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the Committee's recommendations in the report tabled today is that the Government should encourage further and continuous study of this volatile region, which is likely to become more important to Australia's future. In this way, the Australian public can become aware of the many political, military, social and economic factors contributing to the present instability of the region, and public interest in events in the region will be stimulated.

The very large Indo-Chinese refugee problem which has arisen in recent years has had direct consequences for Australia since over 50,000 Indo-Chinese refugees have been accepted for resettlement here since 1975. The humanitarian aspects of the Indo-Chinese refugee situation, and Australia's role in assisting the refugees, is currently being examined by the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence and has not been studied in depth by this Committee. The existence of a very large body of refugees is also a major cause of instability in the region, particularly in the Thai-Kampuchean border area. The Committee therefore recommends that, working through United Nations organisations, the Government should press for the establishment of some form of administrative machinery on the Thai-Kampuchean border so that those refugees seeking a new life in another country can quickly and permanently be separated from short-term refugees who intend returning to Kampuchea.

The Indo-Chinese refugee problem is a tragic by-product of the recent political and military upheavals in the region, which are documented in the report tabled today. The most widely known of these events is the virtual destruction of Kampuechea's social fabric, as a direct result of the policies of the Democratic Kampuchean Government-better known as the Pol Pot regime. Between April 1975 and the end of 1978, it would appear that the DK leaders caused the deaths by massacre or starvation of as many as one to two million Kampucheans. Also, the events taking place in Kampuchea resulted in large numbers of Kampuchean refugees fleeing to Thailand and Vietnam. The report notes that there have been few regimes this century so reviled as the so-called DK Government. The Committee recommends that the general abhorrence felt in Australia towards that regime should be kept in mind when considering Australia's attitude towards the Indo-Chinese region, and that Australia should discourage diplomatic support for the Democratic Kampuchean regime. The Committee does not, however, support the recognition of the People's Republic of Kampuchea-Heng Samrin-whilst Vietnamese military forces are present in Kampuchea.

Following the Vietnamese invasion of Kampuchea and the overthrow of the DK Government in January 1979, there was a new outflow of Kampuchean refugees into Thailand. The movement of Kampucheans towards the Thai border greatly increased in the second half of 1979, after the onset of a disastrous famine in their devastated country. By the end of 1979, there were over a quarter of a million Indo-Chinese refugees and displaced persons in Thailand, including 119,000 Kampucheans who arrived in the last months of the year. In addition, approximately another quarter of a million Kampucheans were camped near the Thai-Kampuchean border. In recent months, the international relief agencies and the Food and Agriculture Organisation of the United Nations-FAO-have expressed a belief that the worst of the food shortages in Kampuchea may now be over. The country is still far from self-sufficient in food production, but, due largely to the international aid effort in 1979-80, the food situation has greatly improved. This improvement is reflected in the fact that, in recent months, people have been returning to their farms and villages from the temporary settlements along the Thai-Kampuchean border. However, the FAO's reports have stressed that the country's economy is still so fragile that famine conditions could easily return if drought or floods occur, or as a result of political or military upheavals, or if there is an abrupt end to international aid.

In the interests of encouraging stability in the region, every effort needs to be made by the international community to prevent the re-occurrence of famine in Kampuchea. The Committee therefore recommends that Australian humanitarian aid to Kampuchea should continue. The refugee problem that has arisen in the last six years is also related to events in Vietnam and Laos, and to policies adopted by the governments of those countries. These policies and their consequences are described in the report tabled today. Over 100,000 Laotians had fled their country by the end of 1977, and the outflow has continued since then. In 1978, nearly 200,000 Vietnamese of Chinese origin fled over the Vietnamese border into China, while almost 90,000 Vietnamese boat people, among whom Vietnamese of Chinese origin predominated, arrived in South East Asia that year, followed by a further 160,000 in the first half of 1979. The exodus of Vietnamese-Chinese by land and sea in 1978 and 1979 brought accusations from the international community that the Vietnamese Government was deliberately and callously driving out the country's Vietnamese-Chinese minority. As a result of international criticism, the Vietnamese Government undertook to reduce the outflow of boat people, and the numbers leaving by sea dropped substantially in the second half of 1979. Since mid-1980 the numbers of boat people reaching countries of first asylum in South East Asia began to rise again, and this trend has continued in 1981. According to figures released by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, approximately 11,150 Vietnamese fled in April, compared with 5,154 in March.

One of the most notable developments in Indo-China since 1975 is the emergence of Vietnam as a strong military power. This development is one of the main causes of the present instability in the region, and has tremendous potential for causing instability in the future. The Committee recommends that any Australian foreign or domestic policy decisions concerning future developments in the region should take into account the existence and capacity of this power. Vietnam's emergence as a military power has also been responsible for a near breakdown in its relations with the Association of South East Asian Nations, especially Thailand. Vietnamese forces have clashed with Thai troops a number of times in the ill-defined Thai-Kampuchean border area, and both sides engaged in heavy fighting during the Vietnamese military incursion into Thailand in June 1980. Prolonged confrontation has not yet occurred between the opposing forces along the border. However, as long as Thai and Vietnamese forces continue to face each other across the border there is a constant possibility of renewed armed conflict.

Recently, there has also been a resurgence of serious fighting in the Sino-Vietnamese border, where China is currently reported to have some 250,000 troops deployed, and Vietnam a similar number. As the report tabled today indicates, Vietnam is apparently determined to maintain its present domination of Indo-China, even at the cost of conflict with China. Under the so-called Twenty-five Year Treaties of Friendship and Co-operation signed with Laos in July 1979 and Kampuchea in February 1979, Vietnam has legitimised her military presence in those countries, under the guise of defence co-operation. Currently, there are 40,000 to 50,000 Vietnamese troops in Laos and some 200,000 troops in Kampuchea. Consequently, Laos and Kampuchea must now be regarded as client states of their powerful neighbour. The Committee is concerned at this situation and recommends that Australia should support policies which would result in the independence of Vietnam, Laos and Kampuchea, based on democratically elected governments. The Committee also recommends that economic aid should not be given by Australia to Vietnam until it withdraws its military forces from Laos and Kampuchea.

Vietnam's domination of Indo-China entails her continuing dependence on the Soviet Union for large-scale military and economic aid. The Soviet Union has been able to utilise its relationship with Vietnam to obtain access to port facilities and thus increase its own presence in the region. The physical presence of Soviet advisers in Vietnam and the Soviet naval presence, particularly in such major ports as Da Nang, appears to have expanded considerably since February 1979. Vietnam has apparently become an important staging-cum-naval observation post or depot for Soviet naval operations in the South China Sea. To China, this no doubt appears part of what is seen as a Soviet plot to encircle her on all possible borders. A reduction in the tensions in the Indo-Chinese region will not be achieved easily. The Committee believes, therefore, that Australia must face the prospect of continued instability in the region, coupled with the very real prospect of renewed armed conflict there.

The Committee recommends that Australia should make strenuous efforts to promote regional solutions to Indo-Chinese problems and, in the interest of peace and stability in the region, attempt to decrease the involvement of the super-powers. The Committee further recommends that the Government should utilise its relationship with ASEAN to encourage all forms of dialogue between ASEAN countries and Indo-China which may help decrease tension in the region and promote a peaceful settlement of the conflict in Kampuchea. Australia should also continue to lend its support to international efforts aimed at decreasing regional tension.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morrison The Hon W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I think the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence is well worthy of note. As with most committees of this Parliament there are a large number of areas of agreement among the membership of this Committee. There is agreement by all members of the Committee on a bipartisan basis of the denunciation of the Pol Pot regime of Democratic Kampuchea. I think that is recognised in recommendation No. 4 of the report. There is also bipartisan support for and bipartisan statements on condemning the Vietnamese invasion of Kampuchea. I point out that as far as the Opposition is concerned the invasion of any other country, whether it be of Afghanistan by the Soviet Union or the raids carried out yesterday by Israeli forces on Iraq, is to be condemned. I think that point is registered in the report as far as the Vietnamese invasion of Kampuchea is concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: There is also agreement that the Heng Samrin regime in Kampuchea is dependent on the continued presence of Vietnamese forces. In Committee discussions there was a slight difference in emphasis on how we should handle the question of the Heng Samrin regime. My colleague the honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley) moved a motion in the Committee, which I was very happy to support, stating that the recognition of the Heng Samrin Government ought not to be entertained at this stage, that clear evidence should be presented that the Heng Samrin regime is independently capable of controlling Kampuchea before such recognition was granted. I believe that was a very sensible motion. It was in slight contradistinction to the recommendation that was carried and included in the Committee report. All in all the areas of agreement were large. The one area in which there was difference was on the question of resuming aid to Vietnam. This is in curious distinction to the position taken on the continued humanitarian aid to Kampuchea. We certainly see some contradiction in the views of Committee members on this subject.

I would like to draw the House's attention to the dissenting report on recommendation No. 3 which starts at page 93 of the report. I point out that the dissenting report was signed by one of the Government members of the Committee-Senator Sim. What we were seeking to do in that dissenting report was to point out that although the decision to terminate the aid program to Vietnam was understandable-it was only a very small aid program-we believe by the continuance of that policy we will deny Australia an identifiable position in the discussions and negotiations which will have to be undertaken in order to bring a sense of peace and a resolution of the very complex problem in the Indo-China area. I commend to the House the consideration of the dissenting report.

I think some matters of grave concern flow from the report. One that is particularly topical is the attempt by the Singaporean Government to create a third force. I noticed in the newspaper today a report of a threat by the Singaporean Minister for Foreign Affairs which is directly relevant to the matters discussed in the report of the Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee. It was reported that if Australia did not vote in favour of the Pol Pot regime that would be a black mark, to use Mr Rajaratnam's phrase, against Australia. The Committee report indicated that back on 4 February Singapore is alleged to have asked Australia to provide active support for the third force. That support was to be in the form of money and arms. It was an attempt to create a force to counter the Heng Samrin regime by military means. First of all, we can say that no such official approach was received, and the report underlines that fact. If such a request were ever received I hope that the Australian Government would treat it with the contempt it deserves.

The report categorically states in recommendation No. 4, after pointing out the abhorrence felt in Australia for the Pol Pot regime of Democratic Kampuchea, that we should discourage diplomatic support for the Democratic Kampuchean regime. I hope that the Government will take note of the recommendation that we should take no actions in the international field to give any support or succour to the Pol Pot regime. This will be a complete denial of the propositions put forward by Singapore. I do not think we are being anti-ASEAN-that is, the Association of South East Asian Nations-when we take that position because it is well known that Singapore and Thailand take a particular position in relation to Kampuchea. This position within the ASEAN context is not shared by Malaysia and Indonesia, which countries have very grave reservations about the proposals put forward by the Singaporean Government.

I think one of our other concerns is the ambivalent position of the Australian Government in relation to its policy on Kampuchea. On 14 October 1980 Australia cast a deceptive, certainly misleading, vote in the United Nations where the Australian delegation was instructed to vote for the credentials of the Pol Pot regime. In fact this meant that for the succeeding year until the next meeting of the credentials committee of the United Nations-in September or October this year-Australia will have continued to give international respectability to the Pol Pot regime. The Government has stated in international forums that it will not vote for the Pol Pot regime. I point out that by the Government's vote back in October 1980 it has committed itself to that course. It has taken that position and I hope it will continue to observe it. Its position has not yet been tested. I think the Government, in light of the recommendations of this bipartisan Committee report, should act in conformity with the abhorrence expressed in the report for the Pol Pot regime of Democratic Kampuchea and with its view that we should not provide diplomatic support for the continued recognition of the Pol Pot regime.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Mr R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I will confine my comments to the interpretative aspects of the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence which were the most controversial and on which the Committee was most divided. I have a particular interest in the recognition issue because I think I was the first member of this Parliament to call for Australia to withdraw its recognition of the Pol Pot regime. I did this in the form of a question to the then Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Peacock) in the House of Representatives on 29 April 1976. My call for derecognition was based on the horrendous atrocities being committed by that regime. It seems to me that we have an enormous problem in establishing criteria for recognition, and maintaining consistency in the application of such criteria. At the moment there appears to be a constant dilemma between granting or withdrawing recognition on pragmatic grounds-based on whether or not a certain government or regime is in control of a country-or granting or withdrawing recognition on moral grounds, that is, whether or not a particular government is acting humanely and according basic human rights to its citizens. If it is not, should we apply our own standards and perceptions to that regime when considering our diplomatic relationship to it?

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that if we apply one principle to the total exclusion of the other, we are in some difficulty and if we apply a combination of both we can be seen to be inconsistent. For example, if we derecognise Pol Pot-as I have long believed we should-on moral grounds, perhaps one could legitimately ask: 'Where does one draw the line?' Totalitarian governments of the Left and the Right account for most of the governments around the world. They are governments such as that in the Soviet Union which do not grant basic human rights to their citizens. If we apply this moral principle exclusively we would recognise very few countries at all, which might be unwise on both diplomatic and strategic grounds.

On the other hand, do we recognise a government which, whether we approve of it or not, does happen to be in control of a particular country? If so, why is the Government of Taiwan not recognised, or the previous Administration in Rhodesia? After all, the regime in Taipeh is the Government of Taiwan and has perpetrated much less undesirable policies than, say, Pol Pot whom we have long continued to recognise. I am not advocating recognition of any particular nation. All I am saying is that we appear to be inconsistent in our approach to this whole question. This poses a serious dilemma which should be canvassed by this Parliament. Adherence to any one principle at the exclusion of others certainly creates difficulties. If recognition is based solely on moral grounds it can ignore our best foreign policy and political interests. If it is based solely on whether or not a regime effectively controls a particular country, then this can offend our moral sensibilities and harm our own political interests at the same time. If we are to grant recognition firmly in accordance with one criterion or another, very fine judgment will be required.

Perhaps the old adage that there are no permanent friends, no permanent enemies and no permanent alliances but only permanent interests is the best and most practical guiding principle in such matters. The Committee's recommendation No. 4, in which it is basically said that Australia should not recognise any regime in Kampuchea at present, has my support and certainly seems sensibly to embrace both of the recognition principles I have mentioned.

The matter of aid to Vietnam was the subject of a dissenting report. I support recommendation 3 of the report. I say this for a number of reasons, most of which are contained in the report. Firstly, as stated in the report, Vietnam has frequently been referred to as the Prussia or Sparta of Indo-China. In fact in proportion to its population Vietnam has one of the largest armed forces in the world; secondly, Vietnam has some 200,000 troops still in Kampuchea; thirdly, Vietnam has 40,000 to 50,000 troops in Laos; fourthly, increasing military and economic aid has been given to Vietnam by the Soviet Union which is now re-equipping and re-arming the Vietnamese armed forces; and fifthly, Vietnam, following its reunification after some 40 years of warfare which had destroyed the country's economic infrastructure, made a conscious decision of its own to further its military imperialism in the area at the expense of economic development and the furthering of the living standards of its people.

Given these reasons, together with the fact that Vietnam deliberately destroyed an important base of its economy by expelling the Chinese middle-class-the nation's merchants and entrepreneurs-and given that our report states that the economic aid it now receives from the Soviet Union has allowed it to divert its domestic national resources to military expansion, I find it impossible to justify Australia's giving economic aid to Vietnam. More aid would simply allow Vietnam to divert more resources to military expansion in the region, with the endorsement and support of the Soviet Union. To give economic aid under these circumstances to a country over which we have no influence, to a country which has itself decided to give priority to military expansion rather than economic development and to a country which has strategic interests clearly against our own best interests in the region, would be absurd. I therefore support the Committee's recommendation not to give aid to Vietnam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I would like to add a few words to the debate on the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. I am one of those whose views on the derecognition of Pol Pot preceded those of the honourable member for Perth (Mr McLean). I opposed the original recognition back in 1975.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important to note that the report was unanimous on all recommendations except recommendation No. 3. Whilst there was some disagreement, not so much on the original Sub-committee but on the full Committee, the members of the Committee as a whole presented a dissenting report only on the question of aid. Let me make my position quite clear on that matter. I would support aid if I thought for one minute that it would lead to a split between Vietnam and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, or even to a withdrawal from Kampuchea and Laos by the Vietnamese. I believe there is no evidence whatsoever for this hope. I think at present our aid to that area is being given to the thousands of refugees from Indo-China many of whom are still in refugee camps. Large numbers have come to Australia.

The question of the recognition of the Heng Samrin regime has not produced a minority report, I believe the people who support the recognition of Heng Samrin in Vietnam are the same people who gave us Stalin, Pol Pot and the Ayatollah Khomeini. Every time they thought they were improving the set-up in the country. They thought they were improving the situation in the Soviet Union by supporting Stalin, they thought they were improving the situation in Kampuchea by imposing Pol Pot on the country and they thought they were improving the situation in Iran by supporting the Ayatollah. In many cases within a very short time of those people taking over in those countries it became quite clear that they were changes for the worst. Very few people would now argue-I do not think anybody in the Australian Labor Party would argue-that Stalin was an improvement on Kerensky and, after all, the communists overthrew Kerensky and not the czar; very few people would argue that Pol Pot was an improvement on the type of government in position in Kampuchea or that the Ayatollah was an improvement on the Shah, however bad the previous rulers were.

I think that appeasement has not paid off vis-a-vis aggressors. It did not pay off before the Second World War and it has not paid off since the Second World War. I strongly support the proposition that we give no aid to countries if they behave in an aggressive fashion towards their neighbours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to make a short statement on the same matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave not granted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr West) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Government to instigate a Federal inquiry into the environmental value to Tasmania and Australia of its south-west wilderness area and the most appropriate way of preserving the area consistent with Tasmanian State development.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Mr S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —South-west Tasmania, including the wild rivers area of the Gordon, Franklin and Olga systems, is arguably Australia's most beautiful area and it is certainly our last great wilderness. The Franklin River, Australia's last wild river, runs from the Cheyne Range across flats, around 5,000 feet mountain peaks, through 3,000 feet gorges and turbulent rapids to the Gordon River and to the sea. I have been to the area four times since last December. Already the upper Gordon has been flooded and so has Lake Pedder. Now a new Tasmanian Hydro-Electric Commission integrated hydro scheme is proposed to flood the Franklin River and the lower Gordon in ignorance of its grandeur in the best Hydro-Electric Commission tradition that no Tasmanian river, regardless of its environmental value, shall flow to the sea without first passing through a power turbine. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has previously recognised the value of this wilderness to the nation and to the world.
—Tell that to the men who work down there. The people get cold down there.
—Tell the workers that.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, perhaps you could call these Tasmanian recalcitrants to order so that they might learn something about their own State. They are in complete opposition to their own Prime Minister. In 1978 the Prime Minister contacted the Tasmanian Premier, Mr Lowe, advising that nominations were being called for the World Heritage List. He suggested that south-west Tasmania be considered for listing. After a long time-I admit it was a long time-the Tasmanian Government advised the Prime Minister last year that the request had been acceded to. Now the Tasmanian Government has gone one step further and has proclaimed an extension to the South West National Park along the Franklin River which is to be named the Franklin Wild Rivers National Park. It is expected that this area will also be added to the south-west nomination for the World Heritage List.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite the delays, two clear facts emerge. Honourable members should take note of them. The Prime Minister says he wants the south-west of Tasmania to be part of the World Heritage List-correctly so-and the Tasmanian Government agrees with him. But a political crisis has erupted in Tasmania to match the environmental crisis which has resulted from the Hydro-Electric Commission's plans to dam the Gordon River below the Franklin River. Despite the apparent agreement between the Federal Government and the Tasmanian Government, the Tasmanian Opposition, using its stooges who are in the majority in the Upper House, has set out clearly to frustrate the wishes of an elected State government to save the Franklin River by imposing an environmentally destructive HEC plan upon Tasmania and Australia. What is the Federal Government's position now? What initiatives has it taken? What initiatives has the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Wilson) taken, given the environmental value of the area and given a clear Federal Government involvement resulting from its requirement to authorise the immense Loan Council borrowing programs that will be needed to construct the dams? Tasmania is split four ways. Honourable members opposite who are trying to interject, such as the deposed Minister and the little Aussie battler who does not even know what is going on in his State, should listen to this for a change.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the phoney from Denison.

—And the phoney from Denison. Where is the Minister? Is he here? He has ducked the issue as usual. Why is he not handling the debate. I do not think the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment who is sitting opposite me will have had time to acclimatise himself. Tasmania is split four ways. The conservationists want no more dams. The Hydro-Electric Commission's integrated plan involves three dams, one on the Gordon below the Franklin, one on the upper Franklin and one on the King River. The Government proposes to dam the Gordon above the Olga and the King River at a later stage. The fourth option is the amendment to the Government's proposals by the Upper House which has proposed a variation of the hydro scheme which involves the damming of the Gordon below the Franklin. That is essentially the same as stage one of the hydro scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very interesting to examine the huge capital investments involved. These commitments compare with a very low comparative power output. I will give honourable members the figures. The total hydro scheme would cost approximately $810m in real terms to produce only 340 megawatts of power. It would flood the Gordon River for 37 kilometres above the Franklin and would flood the lower Franklin for 35 kilometres. The Government's scheme would cost $611m to produce 180 megawatts of power. The select committee's program, which still involves the damming of the Franklin, would cost approximately $650m and produce only 230 megawatts. The unit cost of energy from the Government's proposal is only 0.22c a unit more than the upper House program. I will give a cost comparison with coal-fired power generation. The power stations at Eraring, Bayswater and Mount Piper in New South Wales will cost an all-up total of $2.6 billion and produce 6,600 megawatts of power. Loy Yang A and B power stations in the Latrobe Valley in Victoria will cost $3.2 billion and produce over 4,000 megawatts of power.

There are unanswered questions regarding Tasmania's future power requirements and the capacity of hydro-electric schemes to meet them. Tasmania's average current power output is now 1,033 megawatts. After completion of the Pieman scheme for a cost of over $500m, a further meagre 135 megawatts will be added to make a total capacity of 1,168 megawatts. The upper House scheme would add a mere 230 megawatts giving a total capacity of 1,400 megawatts. The Government's scheme would give a total Tasmanian capacity of 1,340 megawatts. The integrated hydro scheme, if completed, would give the State 1,500 megawatts of power in all. The Hydro-Electric Commission forecasts a total Tasmanian requirement of 1,650 megawatts within 20 years. If the Commission's assessments are correct, even if it has its way and floods the Franklin, the Gordon, the King and every other dam and creek in Tasmania, there will still be a shortfall on its own estimation by the year 2000 A.D. The Directorate of Energy in Tasmania has produced a report that the Hydro-Electric Commission is greatly underestimating the demand for electricity, particularly future bulk industrial use. If the Directorate of Energy is correct, there could be an even larger shortfall even if the Franklin were dammed. On the other hand, those who favour no more dams and a policy of co-generation, including the use of the 370,000 tonnes per year of wood wastes, energy conservation and perhaps thermal power, argue that the Hydro-Electric Commission's figures are grossly over-stated and involve an exaggerated HEC projection rate of increase of 7 per cent a year.

There are three separate positions. The Directorate of Energy is saying that Tasmania needs more power than the Hydro-Electric Commission estimates, the Commission is taking the middle ground and the conservationists are on the base line taking basically a no-growth position. The conservationists could be right. On the other hand, the Directorate of Energy could be right. There needs to be an inquiry. The conservationists say that in 1970 the Hydro-Electric Commission predicted a need for almost 1,500 megawatts of power by 1980 and that that was a projection error over the last 10 years of almost 50 per cent. Those are facts and figures. Either the HEC's projections are grossly over-estimated and the proposed expensive low power yield hydro schemes are unnecessary, or the HEC and the even more bullish State Directorate of Energy are correct. That would mean that hydro power in Tasmania would have a limited scope in satisfying rising demand and in no way could satisfy Tasmania's requirements. If this is true, perhaps now is the time to break with hydro power and look at alternatives such as conservation, co-generation, thermal power stations and an undersea cable from Victoria delivering power as part of an interstate energy grid.

There is a very strong case on environmental, economic and employment grounds to develop either a 200 or 400 megawatt coal-fired power station in northern Tasmania using local coal from the Fingal Valley or imported coal from New South Wales. Current economically recoverable reserves in Tasmania are approximately 130 million tonnes. The demand for a 400 megawatt power station is 1.5 million tonnes of coal per year. Such a station could be constructed for $240m. It could be expected to employ 300 people during the construction period and provide 120 permanent operational jobs compared with only 30 permanent jobs for the HEC's integrated scheme. Although hydro power is cheaper than coal-fired power, over a long period this is greatly offset by the hydro power's greater capital costs and the increased long term employment opportunities with coal-fired power. Last December the State Liberal dominated upper House amended the State legislation put up by the Tasmanian Government by seeking to impose its own scheme to dam the Gordon and Franklin Rivers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. The upper House in Tasmania is an independent House.
—There is no point of order.

—Before the suspension of the sitting for luncheon I was saying that the upper House in Tasmania is frustrating the wishes of the elected government in Tasmania. I said also that the hydro-integrated scheme, which the upper House wishes to implement, must not proceed in Tasmania. We have heard arguments-I have no doubt that I will hear them from the Minister-that the Government should not intervene in Tasmania, that this is a State issue. We do not agree with that. Whatever scheme is passed in Tasmania, that Government will be requiring funds from this Federal Parliament through the Loan Council, or it will be requiring Federal assistance to compensate for the saving of the wild rivers area. Those are clearly matters that should be determined by Federal inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: Another option, which could be the long term answer, is an interstate power grid to link Tasmania with three mainland States. This would obviate the necessity for each State electricity commission to construct its own electricity empire based upon providing for maximum peak demands. A proposal from the Institute of Engineers is currently being studied by the Ziedler committee. That proposal suggests that reserve capacity in four States could be reduced by between 20 per cent and 30 per cent of maximum demand and total savings of some 2,500 megawatts could be introduced in four States in the next decade; that is, a power station the size of Eraring in New South Wales, or over seven times the output of the entire Hydro-Electric Commission integrated scheme in Tasmania-the destroyer of the Franklin River. If we linked up the Latrobe Valley with Bell Bay by undersea cable as part of such a scheme, this would cost approximately $230m. I repeat that it would cost $230m to save the Franklin and $810m to flood it.

We are dealing now with a subject of immense importance-the energy and economic future of Tasmania, the need for rationalisation of our eastern States' electricity system, and the need to preserve a magnificent area of national and world significance. We have a federal Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act which allows the Federal Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, who is sitting at the table, to set up a public inquiry to examine developments of national significance or where the Commonwealth has an interest through the issue of export licences or Loan Council funds. After all, if any new hydro scheme proceeds in Tasmania the Loan Council will provide the majority of funds.

There is a need to save south-west Tasmania, and it has all of these federal connotations. The Opposition knows that the Prime Minister and the Government are on record as wishing to save south-west Tasmania for the appreciation of many generations of future Australians. The House of Representatives Standing Committee on the Environment supports a Federal inquiry; so does the Opposition and, from my information, so does the Government of Tasmania. Now that the Tasmanian Opposition has attempted to flood the Franklin on two occasions there should be a Federal inquiry to assess once and for all Tasmania's future energy needs, the best way of satisfying them, and whether the people of Australia-besides the people of Tasmania-want to save the Gordon-Franklin system for all time. Mr Deputy Speaker and Tasmanian members of Federal Parliament, let the Franklin River run wild and free.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Home Affairs and Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —In this matter of public importance the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr West) has drawn attention to the beauties of south-west Tasmania. There is no argument about the environmental value of south-west Tasmania. Only recently the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), in response to a question from the honourable member for Cunningham, reaffimed the Government's view when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The south-western wilderness area is land of great beauty. It is unique; it is irreplaceable.
He went on to say:
I hope it can be listed on the World Heritage list.

He pointed out that in his view it was a good thing that Mr Lowe, the Premier of Tasmania, had made a decision to seek the nomination of this area on the World Heritage list. The area is part of a national park.

The Commonwealth has taken a number of steps in recognition of the value of south-west Tasmania. In particular, we have consistently maintained that the Government is prepared to assist Tasmania to establish in south-west Tasmania a national park of world significance. We have listed south-west Tasmania in the register of the National Estate, and the effect of that registration is to impose obligations on Commonwealth Ministers and authorities. The House would be aware, of course, that that legislation does not impose any legal obligation on State or local authorities. That is a matter for the Government of Tasmania to determine. We have suggested-we are pleased to know from the Tasmanian Government that it now agrees with us-that south-west Tasmania should be nominated on the World Heritage List.

The Tasmanian Government is unsure about what it wants to do in this area. It has not made up its mind as to the values it places upon south-west Tasmania. The honourable member for Cunningham, in bringing forward this matter of public importance for debate today, and in urging this Government to set up an inquiry when a whole range of other inquiries are already going on, is trying to camouflage the Tasmanian Government's desire to proceed with a hydro-electric proposal. At the same time, he is seeking support from many whose concerns are far broader than that, who would like to see the whole area brought within a national park and placed on the World Heritage List.

Within the Commonwealth of Australia, land use decisions are largely matters for State governments. This issue is primarily a matter of concern for Tasmania. At the present time Tasmania has not made a final decision as to what it wants to do in terms of land usage in the area of south-west Tasmania. In recognising the great value of that area from an environmental point of view, the Commonwealth has given support to Tasmania in its provision of $350,000 for a resources survey. The object of that resources survey is to provide a basis for future decision making by the Tasmanian Government in the administration and management of the area, including the wilderness values which may require reservation and management as a national park. The Government has assisted also in the commissioning of aerial photography of the area to assist in the definition of key habitats for endangered fauna and flora and by funding some research into the ecology of the lakes in the region.

The final report of the resources survey is expected to be relaxed in the near future. When that survey has been released, all governments, according to their responsibilities, can then make a determination as to the future moves they might wish to make taking into account the information that is brought to our attention in that survey. It will be a matter of great interest to the Commonwealth to learn from the Tasmanian Government its assessment of that report. Further Commonwealth assistance for the management and administration of the park has been requested by the Tasmanian Government. The Commonwealth has undertaken to consider these requests by the Tasmanian Government in respect of specific proposals associated with the protection of the region when the report of the resources survey has been assessed. Concerning the proposed hydro-electric development in south-west Tasmania it should be appreciated, as I have already mentioned, that land management and land use decisions are generally matters for State governments, except where Commonwealth-owned land is involved. The Commonwealth Government, therefore, believes that the decisions on the development of State-owned land in south-west Tasmania are largely the responsibility of the Tasmanian Government.

It is true that the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation tabled its report in August 1980 on south-west Tasmania and hydro-power development. The Committee, amongst other things, recommended that the Commonwealth seek advice as to whether the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 applies to proposed hydro-electric developments in south-west Tasmania and, if there were such proposals as defined under the Act, that the Act be invoked. The Government is considering these recommendations and in due course an announcement will be made to the Parliament on the outcome of the Government's considerations. But, as Tasmania indicates to us its views as to what it is proposing to do, those changed views of the Tasmanian Government need to be taken into account.

Honourable gentlemen will be aware of the continuing uncertainty in Tasmania on which a hydro-electric power proposal, if any, is to proceed. Pending resolution of differences between the two Houses of Parliament, it is quite proper, I believe, that the Commonwealth should reserve its decision until it knows what the Tasmanian Government has in mind. On 30 April 1981 the Premier of Tasmania advised that the Franklin-Lower Gordon-Wild Rivers National Park had been proclaimed. This park encompasses areas of the Franklin and Olga Rivers as well as the lower part of the Gordon River. In addition, the proclamation provides for the extension of the south-west national park to include the catchment area of the Davey River. It would appear that this proclamation has excluded one of the hydro-electric options under consideration-the one favoured by the Tasmanian upper House.

The area affected by the Gordon above Olga proposal has not yet been included by the Tasmanian Government in the area either within the south-west Tasmanian national park or the wild rivers national park. The honourable member for Cunningham did not indicate whether he believes that that area should be included in one of those parks. So he brings before this Parliament a matter of public importance on the pretence that he is concerned about the whole of the south-west Tasmania region and then spends a large part of his time in support of a hydro-electric development proposal in the Olga above Gordon section of the river.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what I said. I said we need a federal inquiry to determine the energy future of Tasmania.

—At the present time it is a matter for the Tasmanian Government to determine what its own policies are with regard to its energy future. That is true of other States. When they have development projects in mind they determine their own priorities. When they have made their decisions, and there is an involvement by the Commonwealth Government as a result of those decisions, it is then proper for the Commonwealth to give concern under its own legislation and to take into account the national interest. So what the honourable member for Cunningham is endeavouring to do is to move from Tasmania a decision which is a decision for the Tasmanian Parliament, the Tasmanian Government and the Tasmanian people. When they have made up their minds what course of action they wish to take in this regard it will be proper for that decision to be assessed in the manner that takes into account the Commonwealth's legislation.
—They have already decided and are being frustrated by the upper House.
—They are not being frustrated in any way at all.
—They are being frustrated.

—If they are being frustrated they are being frustrated in accordance with the appropriate political processes applying within Tasmania. In view of the continuing uncertainty as to the intentions and the capacity of the Tasmanian Government about the future in south-west Tasmania, it has not been appropriate to respond to the recommendations following the inquiry conducted by the House of Representatives committee. To date there is no proposal. If the Tasmanians were to find that their energy needs were not dependent on hydro-development in the region there would be no circumstance which would give rise to the question of the applicability of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. It would be interesting to learn what environmental value Tasmania places on the south-west wilderness area and its views as to the appropriate way of preserving the area. I was interested to hear that it had extended the south-west park and had declared the wild rivers park.

SPEECH.PARA: It is up to Tasmania to determine whether it has in mind proceeding with the hydro-electric proposal in the Gordon above Olga area, and when that decision is taken it will be proper for the Commonwealth to consider its position. Of course, Tasmania, like the Commonwealth, is awaiting the outcome of the report of the committee looking into energy resources in south-east Australia. Whilst this report is directly concerned with the possibility of further integrating existing and planned electricity systems between the States, the further development of electricity supply systems within a particular State are also being considered. The committee's report may have a significant bearing on the future power development proposals in Tasmania and the economic, social and environmental impacts of possible alternatives including the linking the Tasmanian power grid with the mainland grid and matters of energy conservation.
I conclude my remarks by once again drawing the attention of the House to the terms in which this matter is being debated this afternoon. The terms of the matter of public importance are:

The failure of the Government to instigate a Federal inquiry into the environmental value to Tasmania and Australia of its South-West Wilderness area and the most appropriate way of preserving the area consistent with Tasmanian State development.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is under threat, Ian. You are the Federal Minister for the environment.
—If it is under threat it is under threat because of the decisions of the Tasmanian Government and the Tasmanian political processes.
—The people in the upper House won't pass the Bill. They want to dam the Franklin.
—Well, it is a matter for the Tasmanians. But the Tasmanian Government wants to dam another part of the area.
—The Minister will address the Chair.

—They want to dam the Franklin. It is not a matter for debate today as to which would be the preferred areas in which to dam rivers in the south-west of Tasmania. What the Government is concerned to do is to recognise in the way that we have in the past the important environmental value of the whole of the south-west Tasmania region. We have set in motion inquiries such as the inquiry into energy in south-east Australia. We have provided funds for Tasmania to carry out resource investigations. We have urged the Tasmanian Government to list the whole area on the World Heritage list. So the ball is very much in the court of the Tasmanian people and the Tasmanian Parliament and, through the Tasmanian Parliament, the Tasmanian Government. So until the Tasmanian Government comes forward with a proposal, it is not appropriate for the Commonwealth to indicate what its views are. When a proposal comes forward that involves any development in south-west Tasmania that is the time for an assessment to be made as to the effect of that development on that wonderful rivers area in south-west Tasmania.
—You are evading your responsibilities.

—We are not evading responsibilities in any way at all. The responsibilities, if being evaded, are being evaded by Mr Lowe, the Premier of Tasmania, and his parliamentary colleagues. It is time that his Government made a determination as to whether or not it wishes to proceed with any development in south-west Tasmania.
—Order! The Minister's time has expired. The discussion is concluded.

DEBATE.TITLE: PROVISION OF ARMY HOUSING, TOWNSVILLE, QUEENSLAND

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the Committee has duly reported to Parliament: Provision of army housing at Townsville, Qld.

The proposal is to provide 120 married quarters for soldiers of the Third Task Force. The need for this housing results from the Government's decision to expand the Task Force to carry out its new function as an operational deployment force. In reporting favourably on the proposal the Committee has indicated its acceptance of the need for additional housing in Townsville and has recommended the construction of these 120 houses subject to the reservations expressed in its report. The Committee has made a number of comments and specific recommendations in its conclusions and throughout the body of its report has made several other observations. These recommendations and observations not only concern the Townsville project but provide constructive comment for administrators in the provision of defence housing generally throughout the Commonwealth. They relate amongst other things to the provision of some villa type medium density housing; the need for liaison with representatives of Service families about defence scales and standards and the need for putting more emphasis on safety, comfort and variety of design for Service housing.

I can assure the Committee and this House that careful consideration will be given to the views expressed throughout the report both for the Townsville project and housing projects generally. The estimated cost of the proposal examined by the Committee was $5.35m at February 1981 prices. The Committee has recommended construction of the work in the reference and if the House agrees to support this motion, detailed planning can proceed in accordance with the recommendations of the Committee.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the Committee has duly reported to Parliament: Redevelopment of Australian Antarctic bases.

The proposal is for the progressive replacement of buildings and the provision of facilities needed to support current research programs in Australia's Antarctic Territory. The redevelopment will be carried out over a 10-year period and will involve replacement of accommodation which is sub-standard and whose structure has deteriorated to a state where continued maintenance is no longer economical or practicable. The replacement of buildings will occur at Casey, Mawson and Davis stations. The proposal comprises construction or replacement of facilities including: Living and sleeping quarters; store, workshop and administration buildings; laboratories and scientific support facilities; powerhouses; engineering services including electricity reticulation; water supply and sewage disposal; and general siteworks.

In reporting favourably on the proposal the Committee has made one recommendation that the timing of the construction of the recreation buildings for Mawson and Davis be put back from the 1984-85 program year to 1986-87. The purpose of this change is to give higher priority to scientific buildings and the Committee's recommendation is acceptable to the Government. It is noted that in the body of its report the Committee has made a number of useful observations. They include reference to such topics as the use of hydroponics in the stations, questions of air travel and wharfage facilities and conditions of service in Antarctica. These matters have been noted and will be further considered in the development of the construction program. The estimated cost of the civil works component of the proposal examined by the Committee was $35m. Additional costs of $23.14m will be incurred for plant and equipment, logistic support and shipping. The Committee has recommended construction of the work in the reference. If the House agrees to support this motion detailed planning can proceed in accordance with the recommendations of the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to register the fact that to the best of my knowledge no notice was given to the Opposition of the intention of the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr McVeigh) to move that motion, nor of the content of the motion. Under the circumstances we are not disagreeing with the motion because of the type of program which exists this afternoon. This procedure was agreed to wholeheartedly and was supported. It is a little disappointing when someone gets up and passes such a ridiculous comment.
—Order! I feel that the Minister has made his point.
—I did not make any ridiculous comments. I do not take kindly to that kind of throw-away line. The fact is that this matter does not appear on today's daily program.
