TALKER.NAME: Mr MOORE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, may I have your indulgence to suggest that the House have a general debate covering this Bill and the Bounty (Textile Yarns) Bill as they are associated measures. Separate questions will, of course, be put on each of the Bills at the conclusion of the debate.
—Is it the wish of the House to have a general debate covering both measures? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford Mr C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bounty (Printed Fabrics) Bill and the Bounty (Textile Yarns) Bill provide for substantial payments of subsidies for the textile yarns and printed fabrics industries. Because they are so important and because so much of the revenue of this nation is appropriated in this way I believe, in spite of the late hour, I am obliged to give the matter full attention and to make a speech that would be made even if the Parliament were not in its dying hours. As we do not intend to divide the House on the Bills I hope that any honourable member who has to catch a plane will do so in the heavy knowledge that I will not be bringing down the Government on this measure. The total full year cost of the assistance will be about $73.5m. The Opposition supports these Bills because they are consistent with our approach to industry policy which recognises, in contrast we believe to the Government approach, the mutual roles of government and the private sector-the necessary partnership.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bills will result in lower prices for textile products in Australia. The level of assistance granted is very high-indeed, these bounty payments are the highest of any industry enjoying such payments-but the effective rate of assistance provided appears to represent some overall reduction from the previous levels of protection afforded by tariffs and import quotas. As such, we of the Labor Opposition see these provisions as representing an appropriate commitment to change in the textile industry and in Australia's economic structure generally at the same time as recognising the necessity for government action to avoid unnecessarily disruptive increases in import competition. But while these Bills are consistent with the Labor philosophy they frankly and ironically point to the sheer inconsistency of the Liberal-National Country Party Government's attitude to matters such as this. The present Government parties went into the election last year making various promises for increased government programs, extolling the virtues of economic policies-the ones they had been applying-and saying nothing about the irrational cutbacks, the decisions to increase taxes or the rhetoric about small government that we have heard since.

Government party members approached the people in, I believe, a cowardly way because they were not, as I said, consistent. They misrepresented their own position as well as that of my party. Now we hear nothing but talk of cutbacks in the Government sector, small government and leaving it to the private sector. But here the cowardice of the election year is replaced by the different policies of the post-election year. This is not a government committed to cutting the public sector. What it really is doing is effecting a redistribution within the community. A revolution of the rich is going on around us while the Government is pleased to delay programs of assistance for disabled people, while it is happy to reduce the quality and raise the cost of health care, while it seeks to cut government commitment to welfare housing and education. It nevertheless actively pursues measures to increase assistance to business and industry. There is the inconsistency.

As I said, Labor supports these Bills, and it supports the provision of reasonable assistance to industry. We are consistent in this attitude because we believe those other areas which I mentioned ought also to receive assistance. I repeat that we are consistent in this attitude because we believe in a co-operative approach between business and government. Just as we accept government responsibility for the welfare of Australians we accept the vital government role in industry. At the same time we are committed to planning and, where necessary, regulation in the private sector to achieve those objectives which are the basis of those plans. That is the quid pro quo. The current Government provides all of the assistance but none of the vitally needed planning or the regulation to achieve objectives.

I am reminded again of the famous phrase of the former honourable member for Fremantle who said that members among the conservative parties are very keen on socialising the losses but capitalising the gains. Of course, there are some exceptions. Parliament heard this morning from the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr McVeigh) about the Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry. That Council provides an example of what is needed. How inconsistent it is, however, that the Minister in his statement should say:
Planning, co-operative effort and far-sighted policies are required from all levels of government.

Yet, at the same time, he is one who supports the nonsense of the small government rhetoric. We should not let the fact that this is the jester from among the Government Ministers disguise the inconsistency of remarks like that and the malice of the Government's neglect to welfare housing needs. So it is with this Government's approach to industry. The fact is that the Government's policies have been a complete failure. Production in manufacturing industry today is no higher than it was six years ago, in spite of such a large increase in population which should have been responsible for an enormous increase in production by now. The risk of inflation is just as great as ever and for that reason the Government's only response is to cut back as soon as there is any evidence of recovery. That is what is happening in the Australian economy right now.

The confidence being instilled by expanding Government spending is being stalled in its tracks right now with high interest rates and squeezes on the monetary system. Hesitancy and recession are again evident in the manufacturing sector. The Government's approach is fundamentally wrong. Australia and Australians will not benefit from setting the public and private sectors apart. It must be recognised that each has a joint role to play, one which involves co-operation and co-ordination. Only on this basis can non-inflationary growth and an increased commitment to the underprivileged be achieved. I assert that only if the Labor Party's approach is adopted to government, to industry and to social development can Australia fully utilise its vast natural advantages.

Our attitude to these Bills reflects our consistent approach. We are concerned that the 6,000 to 7,000 workers involved in these industries can maintain their jobs. We want to ensure that Australia retains employment in manufacturing because we know that at the very most the resource based development will generate directly and indirectly only about one-third of the jobs needed to employ our growing work force. At the same time this Bill is a rare one from this Government in that it results in lower prices and provides a prospect for further decreases in prices as a result of increased efficiency. It achieves this by reducing an indirect tax in the tariff previously struck for these goods.

The Government rarely looks at its own full scope and responsibility for reducing inflation. Indeed, at least one-quarter of Australia's inflation is directly attributable to the actions of the Government. Most of the rest results from a failure to pursue a responsible prices and incomes policy in the context of economic growth. Instead the Government uses a restrictive monetary policy and public sector penny pinching. The result is that there is no attitude of conciliation in our community and there is no increase in the productive capacity of our industries.

Whenever there are signs of growth the inevitable result under this Government's conservative approach is increased inflation. It takes an international energy crisis to achieve any sign of recovery. Most sectors of the economy face continued recession. It was the textile industry's good fortune that the decisions on its future were made in the months leading up to an election. This Government committed itself to uncharacteristic measures at the time. The Bills that we are debating now are part of those measures and part of the seven-year program for the textile and clothing industries. Indeed, although these Bills do not cover footwear, problems in the footwear industry were looked at at the same time.

The Bounty (Printed Fabrics) Bill provides for the payment of bounties to the producers of lightweight woven printed fabrics used in making up garments. Existing quotas and tariffs protecting the industry will be removed from 1 January 1982, the date of commencement of the bounty period. The existing assistance arrangements provide an effective rate of protection of 150 per cent to the industry. The bounty is to be paid at a rate of 70 per cent of value added based on factory cost. This is an apparently narrower basis for bounty calculation that than used by the IAC but it is one we support. It is not known how many employees are affected by the Bill, but the total is probably less than 200 persons. The numbers employed have sharply fallen in recent years and will probably fall further as a result of the Bill.

Imports currently supply about half of the market. Nine companies manufacture printed fabrics, all of whom are located in capital cities. They include the Beech, Colortex, Australian Textile Printing, Vida Turner and Frenchprint companies in Melbourne; UTA in Hobart, Actil in Adelaide and the Tennyson and Hescham companies in Sydney. The cost of the scheme is about $2.5m per annum-the provisions of the next Bill will cost much more-which is probably a greater subsidy per worker than the wages paid to those workers. As I have indicated, the Opposition supports this Bill.

The Bounty (Textile Yarns) Bill also implements part of the Government's seven year scheme for the textiles, clothing and footwear industries, which scheme was announced last year. The Bill provides for the payment of bounties for the production of most yarns which are used in the production of fabrics. The rate of bounty payable will range from 33 per cent to 59 per cent on the basis of value added based on factory cost. Again, this is a narrower base than that used by the IAC, and hence it is difficult to assess the likely implications of these measures. The rate of assistance appears to be lower than initially suggested but higher than ultimately recommended levels. It is lower than that which applies at this time.

Bounty on cotton yarns is to be increased from the current 33 per cent to 43 per cent, following industry claims that the rate initially determined would result in disruption. It is impossible to tell whether the rate of bounty will be adequate, and we urge the Government to adopt a wait and see attitude; in other words, to monitor very closely the effect of this Bill. The Government should be willing to review rates at a later stage if they are inadequate to maintain employment at reasonable levels.

The level of employment in the yarns industry is not known with precision, but is in the order of 6,000 persons. The Fibremakers and Bradmill companies are major producers. Some of their operations are in regional areas which have no alternative employment opportunities offering. At least 35 companies make yarns in Australia and not all of them are in regional areas. But, all of them give employment in particular to migrant workers and others who would not have other job opportunities.

The impact of the provisions of the Bill, since they relate to the removal of tariffs and quotas for the industry, are likely to be negative, although no estimate of the loss of employment is available. It should be noted that rapid productivity improvement is occurring in the industry and on this basis 22 per cent of the work force will be lost over the next five years. I only hope that we will shortly have a change of attitude on the part of the present conservatives who rule us and that we will have a more expansionary economic policy in the context of an incomes policy so that we do not go ricocheting back into inflation. I hope this occurs, in particular in the context of this speech so that alternative job opportunities are created at a greater rate. That is badly needed when we see that, even in industries such as the textile, clothing and footwear industries, in spite of the large amount of funds made available in legislation such as this that employment is actually dropping. The full year cost of the scheme in the second Bill to which I have referred is estimated at $71m, which implies a subsidy of over $10,000 per worker. In spite of that there will be a drop in employment in these industries. We badly need new job opportunities created in new industries and that will be done only if we have an expansionary economic policy. Once again, I state that the Opposition supports these two Bills.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford Mr C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This motion gives me an opportunity to say a few words about the Notice Paper and the mismanagement of the House in recent months. Organisationally, I think the session has been the worst in recent years. In fact we would have to go back to 1971 to find a year when the mismanagement was such. The reforms of Mr Fred Daly have been dissipated. It is no wonder that there is agitation for changed working hours which is, of course, manifested in the various ballot papers doing the rounds of the Parliament at present. Some of the sins of the mismanagement relate to facilities, the hours we work, the want of a proper committee system to scrutinise legislation properly, the absurdity of so many of the Standing Orders and the fact that the Standing Orders Committee has not met in spite of all the mouthing and rhetoric that there has been about the need to improve the workings of this Parliament and to achieve more respect in the community for it than has applied in recent years.

SPEECH.PARA: Furthermore, there are so many cases in which the Opposition has been given inadequate notice of what is coming before this House. The last example occurred just half an hour ago when an amendment was proposed to the Lands Acquisition (Northern Territory Pastoral Leases) Bill. It was not until the amendment was moved in this chamber that the Opposition heard about it. The pacing of the legislation has also been appalling. I refer to the lack of opportunity to debate some of the important issues in the nation. For instance, I place on record that neither of the two business Ministers in whose work I have a particular interest as shadow Minister for Industry and Commerce-I refer to the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch) and the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Moore)-has made a ministerial statement during this session about the state of industry and business. From November to April two pieces of major legislation were debated. In May, three pieces of major legislation were debated. In the 10 days of June, by any definition, at least 10 pieces of major legislation have been debated. That means that the average has increased from one piece of major legislation every six weeks of the parliamentary session to one piece each day.

On at least three occasions the Government has introduced measures late at night. I refer to a ministerial statement on interest rates made by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) at 10.55 p.m. on 2 December 1980 and the Airlines Agreement Bill and related Bills introduced at 10.53 p.m. on 28 May 1981 by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon). Also, the Petroleum Products Pricing Bill, bound up with the abolition of the Prices Justification Tribunal, was debated in the dead of night and was given a mere 52 minutes of the program. I could say a lot more but I will not do so because I believe that I have said enough to show just how inadequate the management of this House has been.

To conclude, it is worth remembering that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in his 13 page election speech with its 47 pages of attachments, made scores of promises. None of those gave a hint of the sort of major legislation to be dealt with in the dying days of this session. Instead of implementing his mandate, we have government by exhaustion. The Prime Minister has put enormous effort into looking after his own friends around the place, his mates-risking internal party problems to deliver on his deals with his backers. That has been characteristic of so much of the legislation that has come before the House, such as the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill which was brought back into this chamber in the last few moments. The Government, instead of implementing its mandate, has brought in legislation to help its friends. There have been delays in the legislative program because of the dissent and turmoil within the Government. That should not have been responsible for inadequate time and inadequate scrutiny being given to these major measures. I draw to the attention of the House, as we are discharging a number of items from the Notice Paper, one that stands in the name of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden). It is Notice No. 13. It has stayed on the Notice Paper since 25 November 1980. It reads:
To move-That a Joint Committee of the Parliament be established to inquire into and report on-
(1) the power, jurisdiction and effectiveness of the Australian Parliament;
(2) the privileges of the Australian Parliament;
(3) the proceedings and usage of the Australian Parliament;
(4) the machinery of the Australian Parliament, and
(5) the relationship of the media of mass communications to the Australian Parliament.

It is high time that we debated that matter in the hope of setting up such a committee so that we can improve conditions in this place and improve the scrutiny of legislation. This place might then be managed differently; there might be a reversion to the better management that applied after Mr Fred Daly brought in his reforms from 1972 to 1975.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourchier Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few remarks following the remarks made by the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Hurford). First of all, one should point out that the amendments to the Lands Acquisition (Northern Territory Pastoral Leases) Bill were circulated at 2.15 p.m. today. It is not the Government's responsibility to make sure that the shadow Minister is in the House when amendments are made available; it is his responsibility to be here when he knows that the legislation is on the Daily Program. I have some figures before me which relate to the criticisms made about the lack of work carried out by this Parliament. I will have them incorporated at the end of my speech. The figures compare the allocation of time for parliamentary debates in the Fifteenth Parliament, from 1937 to 1940, and the current Parliament, the Thirty-First Parliament. In that table three items come to notice. The amount of time allowed for debate on Bills in the Fifteenth Parliament was 66 per cent and the amount of time allowed for debate in the Thirty-First Parliament was 46 per cent. I do not think that is altogether a bad thing. Ten per cent of time was allowed for other major policy debates in the Fifteenth Parliament and 13 per cent of the time was allowed for other major policy debates in the Thirty-First Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition ought to be delighted about the fact that these figures show that this Government is prepared to give the Opposition ample time to talk. The amount of time allowed for debate of other parliamentary business in the Fifteenth Parliament was 26 per cent and the amount of time allowed for the debate of other parliamentary business in the Thirty-First Parliament was 41 per cent. 'Other business' includes debates on matters of public importance, the adjournment, Grievance Day, general business and debates on parliamentary committee business and questions. So I think that the Leader of the House (Mr Sinclair) and the Government are to be congratulated rather than criticised. They are trying to make the Parliament accessible for debate, not only on Bills, but also more particularly on some of the matters that are raised by the Opposition. About 90 per cent of matters of public importance raised in this place are formulated and initiated by the Opposition. I do not criticise that; it is proper. So the Opposition has had ample time to introduce matters of concern to it.

The honourable member for Adelaide mentioned a former honourable member, Fred Daly. I point out that at this time of the year the Labor Party, when in office, was able to get Bills through Parliament not because of the magnificent organisation of Mr Fred Daly but simply because he had absolutely no respect for Parliament. He introduced the guillotine at every opportunity. His record of guillotining Bills through this Parliament is one that I hope that this Parliament and this Government would certainly not want to emulate. We have not introduced the guillotine; we did not need to. For all the complaining by the honourable member for Adelaide, all legislation went through this House with the co-operation of the Opposition. I remember sitting here when Fred Daly was Leader of the House. We sat here very late at night. When an Opposition, whichever party it is, decides to consider a Bill clause by clause in the Committee stages the government of the day has no choice but to sit until that legislation is passed or introduce the guillotine. If Fred Daly was caught at a late hour putting a Bill through the House clause by clause we would inevitably sit late. Otherwise he would have no hesitation in ruthlessly introducing the guillotine which stifled proper debate in this Parliament.

Over the term of this Parliament and of the previous Parliament we have introduced the opportunity for honourable members to meet in committees so that more opportunity is given to them to investigate Bills, to report to the Parliament and to debate them. I think that the honourable member for Adelaide is being just a little bit happy that the end of the session is here and he is going away throwing one over his shoulder in having a dig at the Government when, in truth, he knows that this has been a well run and well organised Parliament, as it will be in the next session. This motion gives me an opportunity to mention a number of those who have made a significant contribution to the Parliament, some of whom will not be with us when the House resumes. There are, of course, in the other place, a number of retiring senators from all parties, some of whom have been here for many years. Indeed, Senator O'Byrne, the father of the Parliament, has been here, I understand, from a time not long after the end of World War II. There is no doubt that within his memory are a great number of changes that have taken place within the Parliament and recollections of personalities that have been associated in it. On behalf of the Government parties I extend our best wishes to him and to all of those from all parties who will at the end of June be finishing their Senate term.

There are a number of people within this House who also will not be with us when we resume for the Budget session. In particular I mention John Fox who has been the Parliamentary Liaison Officer for the last two years. Mr Fox came to the position from the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. He served his term here with due attendance to his responsibilities to both sides of the House. I commend him to his new appointment back within the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and wish him well in his future career. To Jeff Townsend, who is succeeding him, I extend a welcome on behalf of all honourable members and trust that his association with the Parliament will be as happy and as fruitful as the associations of his predecessors.

There are many who serve us silently within the Parliament. There are many whom we recognise yet, perhaps, rarely commend for the contribution that they make. I think it is worth while specifically referring to the Hansard reporters, the attendants and the police and all of those who, in their several ways, within the Joint House Department, make the functioning of this place possible. Among those who are predominant in serving the Parliament are the Clerks, who serve us within this chamber and who provide the assistance that enables us to avoid all the human frailties that occur from loss of memory of the Standing Orders or other procedural motions which otherwise might make it more difficult for the procedures of the Parliament to be effectively processed. Finally to you, Mr Speaker-and to all honourable members-on behalf of the Government parties I wish a safe journeying wherever you might be during the recess. I hope that there is an interesting confrontation between the two sides of the House when we resume in the Budget session.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford Mr C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition I extend my tribute to John Fox, the Parliamentary Liaison Officer. During my period as Manager of Opposition Business in this House I got to know John Fox's work well. I admired the way he carried out his duties. I also express the good wishes of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the present Manager of Opposition Business, Mr Lionel Bowen. I hope that we will see John Fox back in the Parliament from time to time. I hope he will get satisfaction from the new work to which he is turning. We extend a welcome to Jeff Townsend. Both the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and I have had a chance to work with Jeff for a couple of weeks now and we know that we will have a fruitful liaison with him in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: A great number of senators are retiring. There have been other occasions when we have paid tribute to them, but honourable members on this side of the House would like to put on record our feelings of warmth towards them and express the hope that they will all have a very long and happy retirement. I also pay tribute to everyone who works in this place. I am inclined to say that if it were not for Government members this would be an enormously attractive place to which we could come from time to time. Of course, I have my tongue in my cheek. If only the Government members behaved as well in the chamber as they do outside the chamber the whole atmosphere of the place would be enhanced. Nevertheless, having said that, I wish them a happy recess. I note that many of them are travelling overseas. Of course, there will not be nearly the same number from this side of the Parliament travelling overseas. I hope that those who do will have a fruitful time. Mr Speaker, we extend to you our best wishes for the recess and our thanks for the way in which you have conducted the business of the House.

Retail Industry
Motion (by Mr Sinclair) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The enthusiastic new member for Canberra wishes to speak in this adjournment debate. It is easy to see that I have not very far to go home. In the closing minutes of this session I would like to make a few points in relation to private enterprise in Canberra. I want to take this opportunity to outline how private enterprise operates in one particular industry in Canberra-the retail industry. It is not a pretty picture. The Canberra retail industry is characterised by one dominant firm, the Lend Lease Corporation Ltd, and its associated companies. This company has a stranglehold on the small traders as it controls every major shopping centre in Canberra except the Belconnen Mall. These shopping centres include the Woden Plaza, Cooleman Court, Manuka Village, Monaro Mall, The Boulevard, as well as other offices and buildings in the Australian Capital Territory. It would also be an interesting exercise to trace the shareholdings of Lend Lease in the major retail chains that are established in Canberra.

SPEECH.PARA: The major problem with Lend Lease in Canberra is the severe contractual provisions it is able to force on small business people as a result of its monopoly position in the local market. Firstly, in relation to rents, because of its dominance and influence in the industry in Canberra, Lend Lease is able to set extremely high levels of rents. In addition, high turnover rates are also applied. This means that Lend Lease has the right to go through the books of each trader every month to collect its percentage of the turnover-up to 10 per cent in some cases. The effect of this is that the trader's profit margins are constantly under great pressure and, of course, this is ultimately passed on to the consumer in higher prices. A further cost inflicted on these small businesses by Lend Lease is a percentage for promotional costs and the operating costs of the shopping centre. These costs are, of course, fully incorporated into rents, not added on afterwards.

At various times, traders have attempted to get Lend Lease to account for the amounts given for operating expenses and to tell them why income is not shown in relation to general recoverable expenses, but the traders have never received any satisfactory explanation. For example, in relation to the Woden Plaza, Lend Lease has refused to explain the purpose of its so-called 'sinking fund', the total monies accumulated in this fund, whether the sinking fund is used to offset repairs, the reasons for heavy repairs necessary to a new air conditioning system, and the cost of those repairs, the reason for significant amounts of painting-some of which has been done for the first time-and the heading under which these charges are included. The list goes on and on. The traders must pay whatever Lend Lease demands without any satisfactory accounting of these charges being provided. Of course, ultimately, it is the consumer again who pays for this in higher prices.

A further objectionable provision which Lend Lease enforces is to prevent shopkeepers holding meetings. Lend Lease has written to traders in the past asserting its right to enforce this provision. I hope that no honourable member in this Parliament would wish to defend such a blatantly undemocratic arrangement whereby small business people are prevented from holding a meeting to discuss their business affairs. This year, rents and contracts are being renegotiated for a further three-year period. In most cases, this is an ideal opportunity for the management failures of the past to be reviewed and for reforms to be implemented before a further three years of misery is foisted on Canberra's retail traders. Lend Lease has been able to get away with these unsavoury practices in the past because of its dominant position in this industry in Canberra. The small trader has nowhere else to go.

I think it is about time that people in this Parliament took an interest in the monopoly situation that has been established in the Australian Capital Territory. For years I have fought against this in an attempt to get a business leases review board established in Canberra. I hope that, before this Parliament again resumes for the Budget session, the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) will get together with the small business people and the builders, owners and management associations to get a fairer deal for small traders in the Australian Capital Territory.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Functions of Government Returned to the States

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McLean Mr R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister in Federal Affairs, upon notice, on 26 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What functions of government have been returned to the States since 11 November 1975.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: See the answer of 21 August 1979 given by Senator Carrick in reply to a similar question by Senator Wriedt (Senate Hansard, pages 49-52). The following additional information is provided:

Local government/municipal type services provided by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs to Aboriginal communities in the Northern Territory, with the exception of those on pastoral properties, were transferred to the Northern Territory Government from 1 Feburary 1980.

Funding provided under the Department of Aboriginal Affairs culture, recreation and sport program to the YMCA in the Northern Territory was transferred to the Northern Territory Government as from 1 February 1980.

Taxation, industrial and intellectual property jurisdiction was conferred on State and Territory Supreme Courts with effect from 15 May 1979, when the relevant provisions of the Jurisdiction of Courts (Miscellaneous Amendments) Act 1979 came into force. That Act also invested State and Territory Supreme Courts with jurisdiction in certain matters arising under the Financial Agreements (Commonwealth Liability) Act 1932 and the Overseas Telecommunications Act 1946, in which jurisdiction had previously been exercisable only by the High Court.

Responsibility for the Supreme Court of the Northern Territory was transferred to the Northern Territory Government on 1 October 1979 upon the proclamation of the Northern Territory Supreme Court (Repeal) Act 1979, which enabled the Supreme Court of the Northern Territory to be established under an Act of the Northern Territory.
The Supreme Courts of the States have been invested with federal jurisdiction to deal with chambers applications in matters pending in the Federal Court of Australia.
The functions of the Australian Legal Aid Office have been absorbed by the State Legal Aid Commission in Queensland.
Commonwealth legislation to extend State powers to the territorial sea, including the seabed, has been enacted and is to come into force on a day to be proclaimed.

Approvals of certain categories of new courses at colleges of advanced education, which previously had been given by the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission, are now the responsibility of State authorities.

The provision of education services and responsibility for education matters in the Northern Territory, with the exception of those of a national nature for which the Commonwealth has a continuing responsibility, were transferred to the Northern Territory Government on 1 July 1979.
Under the Transition from School to Work Program, responsibility for approval of program proposals for 1981 has been substantially devolved to the State level.
Responsibility for Northern Territory education buildings, design, construction and maintenance was transferred to the Northern Territory Government on 1 July 1979.
Minister for National Development and Energy-
The Bureau of Mineral Resources is in the process of transferring responsibility to the States and the Northern Territory Government for the revision of the 1:250,000 scale geological map series.

Powers and functions under the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967 in respect of the areas adjacent to the Northern Territory and to the Ashmore and Cartier Islands were transferred to the Northern Territory Government on 12 June 1979.

With respect to offshore mining to the outer limit of the 3 mile territorial sea and subterranean mining extending from the land mass, Commonwealth legislation to transfer responsibility has been passed but it has not yet been proclaimed. The legislation is part of the overall offshore constitutional package which awaits completion by the enactment of complementary State legislation.
All Commonwealth funding for the MITERS (Minor Improvements to Traffic Engineering and Road Safety) program under the Roads Grants Act 1980 ceased by 30 June 1980.
Transfer of 'State-type' aviation powers to the Northern Territory Government was effected on 1 June 1980.

The Navigation Amendment Act 1980 gives effect to the Commonwealth/State Agreement on Shipping and Navigation responsibilities that formed part of the Constitutional Offshore Settlement. The Act ensures that the Sates have responsibility for trading vessels on intra-State voyages, fishing vessels other than those on overseas voyages, pleasure craft, inland waterways vessels and offshore industry vessels whose operations are confined to the one State. The relevant provisions of the Act have been proclaimed and came into effect on 1 February 1981. Previously, the Commonwealth regulated some aspects of the navigation of these vessels.

Negotiations are nearing completion with the Northern Territory Department of Health concerning the transfer of responsibility for the cost of orthoses to non-repatriation beneficiaries resident in the Northern Territory to the Northern Territory Government.
In addition, the Prime Minister announced the early transfer of a number of functions to the States in his Ministerial Statement on the Review of Commonwealth Functions on 30 April 1981.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Wanniassa High School Buildings, Australian Capital Territory

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 26 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does his Department propose to extend the arrangements for the provision of accommodation for Trinity College and Cowman College, in the Wanniassa High School buildings, Australian Capital Territory, beyond 1981; if so, for how long.
(2) Does the arrangement represent a change in attitude by the Government on the utilisation of Government school buildings; if so, what change has been made.
(3) What costs are borne by the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority under this arrangement in terms of (a) heating, (b) lighting, (c) maintenance, (d) staff and (e) equipment.

(4) Was action taken to evaluate the effect of these arrangements on the curricula and educational opportunities offered to Wanniassa High School students; if so, what action and will he make available any studies or reports on this matter.
(5) What provision has been made for accommodation for community groups which would normally utilise school buildings, whilst non-government schools occupy parts of Wanniassa High School.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Government school buildings are provided primarily for education purposes. Use of portion of the Wanniassa High School building by Trinity College and Cowman College meets that criterion without effect on normal community access. In agreeing to this arrangement, which expires at the end of the 1981 school year, the ACT Schools Authority took into account the effect on curricula and education opportunities offered to Wanniassa High students. The two non-government schools meet all costs associated with their tenancy with the exception of structural maintenance which is a normal landlord cost.

It is unlikely that Trinity Christian School and Cowman College will be accommodated in Wanniassa High School in 1982 as development of that school will require additional accommodation. ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Agricultural Land: Purchases by Foreign Interests

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Wallis Mr L.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 26 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the concern expressed by rural organisations at the extent of the purchase of agricultural land by foreign interests.
(2) Are records kept which indicate the extent of these purchases.

(3) Are there any restrictions in force to control the purchase of agricultural land by foreign interests; if so, how do these restrictions compare with the restrictions that apply in countries such as New Zealand, Canada and the United States of America.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, I am aware that some rural organisations have expressed concern about foreign ownership of rural land. The Government respects such views and through its policy on foreign investment looks very closely at proposed acquisitions of rural land by foreign interests. Before any approval is given, other than in cases where the purchasers are Australian citizens resident abroad or genuinely intending immigrants, the parties must demonstrate that Australians have been given adequate prior opportunity to purchase the land if they wished to do so and that there will be benefits through development of the property or otherwise to Australia from the investment.

(2) The Foreign Investment Review Board keeps records of the proposals submitted for approval under the Government's foreign investment policy. These records do not, however, indicate whether the purchases take place. Similarly the Board's statistics do not record sales by foreign interests to Australians as these proposals do not require notification. I am forwarding to the honourable member a paper on foreign investment in rural land which outlines in some detail the Government's policy and provides detailed statistics.

(3) Acquisitions of rural properties by foreign interests generally involve acquisitions of assets of Australian businesses and, as such, these transactions fall within the scope of the Foreign Takeovers Act. Proposals notified in accordance with the Act are examined by the Foreign Investment Review Board to determine whether they would lead to benefits through, for example, development, marketing and employment opportunities, and to ensure that Australians have been given an opportunity to purchase the land.

The Government considers each proposal carefully on the advice of the Board and grants approval only where it is satisfied that the acquisition of land by the foreign person would not be contrary to the national interest.
I am informed that the approaches adopted by the other countries mentioned by the honourable member are:

Under the Land Settlement Promotion and Land Acquisition Act 1952, as amended, foreign interests are restricted from acquiring rural land, offshore islands and any land required for public use. The legislation aims to restrict absentee foreign ownership of certain types of land in New Zealand.

Restriction of foreign ownership applies to any land of two hectares (five acres) or over in area which is zoned for rural purposes, or is so zoned that farming of any kind is a predominant or conditional use in that zone.
However, acquisition of land by a foreign interest may be permitted if:
the acquisition is for experimental and research purposes which would benefit New Zealand; or
intended uses of the land, other than for agriculture, clearly show significant benefits to New Zealand and thus are in the national interest; or
an individual alien permanently resident in New Zealand farms the land exclusively for his own use and benefit and has the ability and means to achieve these purposes.

If land is part of the assets of a business, and where the consideration involved exceeds $NZ100,000, a non-resident has to notify full details to the Overseas Investment Commission of any proposal that would lead to the non-resident interests controlling 25 per cent or more of the voting rights of the business. Each proposal is considered by the Commission on its merits.

The Provinces have primary jurisdiction with respect to real estate and regulations vary according to the host Province. Some of them have fairly restrictive statutes. The regulation of foreign ownership of real estate may also fall within Federal Government responsibilities which are administered by the Foreign Investment Review Agency. Foreign acquisitions of real estate are subject to review to the extent that they represent the acquisition or control of a Canadian business.

Under the Agricultural Foreign Investment Disclosure Act 1978, all foreign interests who own or acquire United States agricultural land are required to report their holdings with the United States Department of Agriculture. This legislation is not intended to restrict or regulate land purchases or sales by foreign interests. It is aimed primarily at strengthening the efforts to monitor foreign investment in United States agricultural land.

The American States generally have no restrictions on ownership of land by resident aliens. However, nine States have laws that generally prohibit or restrict in a major way, non-resident aliens from owning real estate. Some of these States also have restrictions on ownership of land by resident aliens. An additional four States have laws that limit the total acreage that aliens can acquire or hold and the limits range from 5 acres to 500,000 acres. Six States, five of which are included in the nine States mentioned above, have laws that permit aliens to hold land for a limited duration or require aliens to dispose of all or part of their holdings within specified time periods if they do not become United States citizens or residents of the State.

The policies of these countries are related to their particular circumstances just as the Australian policy is aimed at meeting Australia's needs. This Government's policy and the way in which it is administered provide a reasonable basis for exercising supervision and, where necessary, restraint of excessive foreign investment in Australian land.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 11 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Were changes made in the method of transportation of deaf children attending the Page and Mawson Primary Schools in the Australian Capital Territory; if so, what were the reasons for the changes.
(2) Were consultations held with the parents and teachers involved in this matter.

(3) Is it a fact that under the new transport arrangements the children are unable to use seat belts and are not adequately supervised because the driver cannot communicate with them; if so, can the safety of the children be guaranteed.
(4) Will he take action to overcome the excessive length of time spent in travel for the children and the necessity for them to change buses.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. These deaf children form part of a group of handicapped children in the Australian Capital Territory who on an individual needs basis require school transport but who are not eligible for bus transport provided by the Capital Territory Health Commission. Because of difficulties associated with the then existing transport service which was provided by a local taxi co-operative, the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority invited public tenders for the provision of school transport for this group of handicapped children. A mini bus service was introduced at the beginning of the 1981 school year.

(2) Extended discussion and consultations took place prior to the decision to invite public tenders, between officers of the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority, and parents and teachers on questions of reliability, punctuality and safety. Various alternative modes of transport were examined. A questionnaire was sent to parents during the latter part of 1980 asking if they would be interested in transporting, with payment from the Authority, their own child and possibly other children. The responses clearly showed that generally parents were not in a position to transport their children on a regular basis, preferring the Authority to provide transport.

(3) Officers of the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority have recently completed a survey of the bus service and have reported to me that although the buses being used are not fitted with seat belts, their investigations revealed that satisfactory safety standards were being maintained. It was found that the behaviour of the children was generally good and that they were well controlled by the drivers, who despite some initial problems of communication, were able to exercise reasonable care and supervision.

(4) Yes. Additional vehicles have been provided to overcome the excessive length of time spent in travel and to eliminate the need to change buses. With the exception of students travelling from Tuggeranong Valley to Lyneham, no student should now spend more than 30 minutes on a journey to or from school.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Social Security: Payment of United Kingdom Pensions in Australia

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 24 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What arrangements are made for the payment of United Kingdom pensions in Australia.
(2) Does the Australian Government supplement the UK rate to bring it to the level of Australian pensions.
(3) If so, what exchange rate is used in determining the rate of payment.

(4) If the UK pensions are adjusted, is any consideration given to exchange rate fluctuations; if so, is any adjustment made by the Australian Government so that UK pensioners receive an equivalent rate.
(5) Are bank charges made for the exchange and conversion of UK pensions; if so, is the UK pensioner disadvantaged by any charge.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The United Kingdom Department of Health and Social Security pays pensions direct to eligible persons in Australia.
(2) Yes, for people subject to the reciprocal agreement on social security between Australia and the United Kingdom.

(3) It is impracticable to ensure that Australian pensions, when affected by United Kingdom pensions, are assessed on exchange rates applied by banks in day-to-day operations. For the purpose of calculating Australian pensions a notional exchange rate is set, based on the Commonwealth Trading Bank on-demand air mail buying rate, and monitored daily. The notional exchange rate is altered when the exchange rate between the Australian and United Kingdom currencies varies by 5 cents or more Australian per one pound sterling, and appears to be relatively stable. This method of assessment is currently being reviewed.

(4) For people in Australia, United Kingdom pensions are not adjusted, but paid at the rates in force when the recipient left the United Kingdom or at the time of grant, if later. As outlined in (2) and (3) above, the Australian Government supplements the constant rate (in pounds sterling) of the UK pension to bring it up to the current level of Australian pension by using the notional exchange rate.

(5) It is understood that some banks impose a charge for the conversion of English currency drafts. To the extent that anyone may be disadvantaged, this results from the method of payment of the United Kingdom pensions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 24 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say whether Australia is the only English speaking country which has not legislated for conditions in sheltered workshops.

(2) In this International Year of Disabled Persons, does he propose to recommend amendments to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act to ensure that persons employed in sheltered workshops gain the benefit of national wage case increases.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Commonwealth Government has no legislation governing conditions in sheltered workshops. I am, however, aware that some States have legislation which could be used to license, and thereby regulate, sheltered workshops. To the best of my knowledge the situation varies among other English-speaking countries.

(2) The Handicapped Persons Assistance Act, the legislation under which the Government subsidies sheltered employment services, does not prescribe working conditions for these facilities. Some control is exercised through requirements that sheltered workshops sign a written agreement when they are approved under the Act. The agreement specifies that approval is conditional upon, inter alia, payment of disabled workers according to the work they perform, and organisations' compliance with relevant State and Local Government requirements on building standards, health and sanitation, safety measures and conditions of employment.

In addition to a wage, the majority of disabled people in sheltered workshops receive Sheltered Employment Allowance. This allowance is paid at similar rates to the invalid pension and includes an income test free Incentive Allowance of $5 per week. Sheltered Employment Allowance is subject to the same terms and conditions as the Invalid Pension and undergoes regular adjustment in accordance with CPI movements. This is provided for by section 28A of the Social Services Act, the legislation under which pensions are paid. It is noteworthy that Australia's provisions in relation to Sheltered Employment Allowance were commented upon favourably at last year's World Rehabilitation Congress in Winnipeg, as a possible model for other countries.

Sheltered workshops also employ a number of able bodied people. The Government, under the provisions of the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act, subsidises the salary of any person employed in a workshop who is directly concerned with supervising or training handicapped people.
The indexing of wages for both handicapped and able bodied employees is a matter for decision by the management of each sheltered workshop.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Attachments for Television Sets for the Profoundly Deaf

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Adermann The Hon A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 31 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does he recall my representations to him concerning Seven Tel attachments for television sets which enable the profoundly deaf to call up printed information such as news, weather, cyclone warnings, police messages and other public information bulletins.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What action has been taken on the recommendation of the Commissioner for Community Relations contained in his 5th Annual Report for the year 1979-80 (page 63), that the Australian Taxation Office consider the whole question of concessional allowances paid in respect of dependants resident overseas.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: This matter was thoroughly examined in the Report of the Review of Post-Arrival Programs and Services for Migrants (the Galbally Report) dated May 1978.

The Review group, while recognising that many migrants feel a strong obligation to give financial help to family members in their home country, noted that provisions enabling migrants to send money out of Australia were generally adequate to meet any family obligations a migrant in Australia may feel. In recording its belief that it was an unreasonable burden on the Australian taxpayer to allow tax rebates for some of these overseas payments, the Review group noted that it was extremely difficult to check claims as to the existence of the people abroad in respect of whom rebates were claimed, and, more importantly, to take into account their income for the purpose of calculating the rebate.

After careful consideration of the Report and of all other relevant issues, including especially the substantial cost to revenue caused by the mounting abuse of the rebate attributable mainly to the difficulty in checking claims noted by the Review group, the Government decided to withdraw the rebate in respect of dependants resident overseas from 1 November 1978. This did not affect rebates for dependants temporarily overseas who continue to be residents of Australia for taxation purposes, or for wives and children awaiting migration to Australia.
No new aspects have been raised which would warrant reconsideration of the matter by the Government and the Australian Taxation Office must, of course, apply the law as it is enacted.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What action has been taken by his Department on the recommendation contained in the 5th Annual Report, for 1979-80, of the Commissioner for Community Relations (page 58) that public housing appropriate to the needs, values and lifestyles of Aboriginal people in all States and the Northern Territory should be provided.
(2) In what way would acceptance of this recommendation require changes in the policy or practices of his Department.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The 5th Annual Report of the Commissioner for Community Relations acknowledges that Aboriginals are eligible for housing assistance under general welfare housing programs. In this respect, general eligibility criteria apply to Aboriginal people along with any other groups of persons.

Aboriginals also receive special assistance by way of earmarked grants under Part III of the Housing Assistance Act 1978, and the Commonwealth-Northern Territory Housing Agreement in recognition of their special needs. Amounts of $21.06m and $22.10m were allocated among the States and the Northern Territory for this purpose in 1979-80 and 1980-81 respectively.

Administration of all welfare housing programs funded through the Department of Housing and Construction is the responsibility of the State Governments. The earmarked funds mentioned above are directed to special programs administered by State authorities in liaison with authorities having special interests in Aboriginal housing including the regional offices of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. The need to earmark funds to meet the special housing needs of Aboriginals will continue to be recognised in the proposed 1981 Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement.

In addition, the Commonwealth Department of Aboriginal Affairs has for many years funded a special program of grants to State Housing Authorities for housing for Aboriginals. In recent years this program has been controlled by the 1978 Aboriginal Housing Agreement. Participation of Aboriginals in policy formulation and management matters is encouraged under this Agreement. Under this program grants totalling $12.9m and $10.7m have been allocated for 1979-80 and 1980-81 respectively.

Further, the Aboriginal Housing Association program funded by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs allows Aboriginal communities to establish, plan and administer housing schemes. Funding totalled $20.5m in 1979-80 and is estimated to be $22.1m in 1980-81.

Aboriginal Hostels Limited, a company wholly owned by the Commonwealth Government, provides a home environment enabling Aboriginals to avail themselves of education, training and employment opportunities.
The Aboriginal Development Commission makes available concessional home purchase loans to eligible Aboriginals who cannot obtain home finance on the open market.

(2) Commonwealth grants for Aboriginal housing are directed to special programs for Aboriginals which are either administered by or in liaison with the Commonwealth Department of Aboriginal Affairs and with State Government authorities having well defined responsibilities. These practices are considered to be in accordance with the recommendation of the Commissioner for Community Relations.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 28 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to an article entitled The Prevention of Alcoholism: Epidemiological Studies of the Effects of Government Control Measures published in the British Journal of Addiction, 1975 Vol. 70, pages 125-144.

(2) If so, does the article produce a wealth of evidence that restricting sale times and outlets for alcohol is less effective in reducing community intake than cost maintenance through taxation policy.
(3) Does it also confirm that total intake, regardless of source, determines prevalence of alcohol-related illness.

(4) Will the Government undertake public education of these facts and pursue appropriate excise policies, unimpaired by budget-balancing or industry support considerations, as suggested in that article and in my request for submissions from his Department in support of such a policy when I was Minister for Health.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) No. It does show that regulation of the accessibility of alcohol is not a major determinant of alcohol consumption. Evidence is produced suggesting that alcohol consumption and the relative price of alcohol (the price of 10 litres of absolute alcohol divided by personal disposable income) vary inversely but this does not prove that price is a major determinant of consumption. The degree of affluence, as reflected in the disposable income, is probably more important.

(3) No. The article contains statistical evidence linking variations in the level of average consumption with variations in the level of occurrence of some chronic alcohol-related problems. These are only associations the meaning of which is uncertain, and no evidence is produced about the associations of variations in the level of average consumption and other alcohol-related problems.

(4) No. The Government's policy on alcohol-related health problems was detailed in the response to the Report of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare: 'Drug Problems in Australia: an Intoxicated Society?', tabled in the Senate on 19 March 1980 which stated that the Government favoured an overall reduction in alcohol consumption and that the Government would take health considerations into account in a budgetary context when setting tax rates on alcohol.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 30 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Government propose to tax money paid in compensation to victims of pneumoconiosis; if so, what estimated sum will it raise.
(2) Has section 23 of the Income Tax Assessment Act been effective since 1973; if so, why has the Government waited until now to enforce it.
(3) Is a massive social injustice being perpetrated by this occurence; if so, will he advise the Commissioner of Taxation not to proceed against this particularly disadvantaged group.
(4) How many persons are subject to paying tax on this compensation and what is their average age.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Income Tax Assessment Act requires a taxpayer to include in assessable income the gross income derived from all sources in or out of Australia. Because amounts paid by way of compensation to victims of pneumoconiosis are of an income nature they form part of a recipient taxpayer's assessable income. No details are available of the estimated amount of tax involved.

(2) Section 23 of the Income Tax Assessment Act provides for the exemption from income tax of specified classes of income. The section does not operate to exempt from tax amounts paid by way of compensation to victims of pneumoconiosis. The Commissioner of Taxation has, however, advised that in some cases in Western Australia the view was in the past mistakenly taken that these amounts did not constitute assessable income.

(3) Decisions of the courts have confirmed that compensation payments of the type referred to are assessable income. It would be necessary to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act to provide that the amounts be exempt from income tax.
(4) Statistics of this kind are not maintained.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hurford Mr C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 7 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the studies undertaken by Professor J. W. Nevile of the Centre for Applied Economic Research at the University of New South Wales show that a rise of one percentage point in the nominal rate of interest is enough to reduce investment in fixed capital by about $250m, in terms of April 1981 prices.
(2) Is there any substance to Professor Nevile's calculations.
(3) If not, what are the reasons.
(4) Is this apparent lowering of levels of investment due to high interest rates contrary to the medium and long term viability and efficiency of Australian industry.

(5) If so, what steps will he take to ensure not only that high interest rates do not produce further increases in the level of unemployment but also that they do not lead to industry being saddled with outdated and uncompetitive plant and capital.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (5) I understand that a paper by Professor Nevile entitled 'Inflation and the Incentive to Invest' refers to the impact that an increase in the nominal interest rate might have on business investment. I also understand, however, that the main point of the paper is to demonstrate the adverse impact that a rise in inflation has on investment, both through its effect on interest rates and through corporate profitability.

It is worth noting that simple regression results, such as those cited by Professor Nevile, do not in fact 'show' anything. They can at best provide only a broad guide to underlying economic relationships and cannot capture all the influences bearing on (in this case) private investment.

It may also be worth noting that if there is one thing that is abundantly clear about the Australian economy today it is that Australia is not suffering from any shortage of new investment at this time. On the contrary, business investment is likely to grow by around 20 per cent in real terms in 1980-81 and recent expectations data from the ABS point to further very strong growth in 1981-82.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Closure of Engineering Courses in Victoria

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 7 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was he and his Department asked to express an opinion on the closure of engineering courses at the Deakin University, Victoria, and at the Bendigo Institute of Technology, Victoria (Hansard, 30 April 1981, page 1843); if so, what advice was given.
(2) Has he had consultation with the Victorian Minister for Education about these courses.
(3) If so, did the Victorian Minister support the proposals to close these courses and if support was given, what reasons were advanced for this action.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Advice given to me by the Tertiary Education Commission (TEC) in its Report for 1983-84 Triennium included concern for the fragmentation of engineering programs in Victoria and the opinion that some rationalisation was required on the grounds of quality. When preparing its advice, the TEC had regard to the recommendations of the Victorian Post-Secondary Education Commission's Working Party on Engineering Education, released towards the end of 1980. In this Report doubts were raised on the continuation of certain engineering schools including those at Deakin University and Bendigo College of Advanced Education. This advice was made available to the Government before the decisions under question were made.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 6 May 1981:

(2) If not, what are the wholly-owned national airlines that enjoy exemption under this item.
(3) Could the wholly owned national airline of a Communist State enjoy exemption from Commonwealth sales tax under item 72A.
(4) Do any of Australia's principal trading partners grant immunity from any or all of their taxation laws to foreign government trading concerns.

(5) Does this provision give unfair advantage to certain international airlines; if so, what is the justification for certain airlines which are run as profit-making ventures, to be exempted from sales tax because they are owned by a foreign government.

(6) Will the Government give consideration to tightening up the regulations or the Act to ensure that foreign governments only enjoy exemption from taxation in matters directly affecting their diplomatic representation in this country and excluding their trading ventures.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am advised by the Commissioner of Taxation that the answer is no.
(2) This is not at this stage public knowledge and, in view of the secrecy provisions of the taxation laws, the Commissioner of Taxation is not prepared to supply the information.
(3) Yes, if on the facts of a particular case the doctrine of sovereign immunity applies.
(4) Recognition of the doctrine of sovereign immunity is not confined to Australia, but no information is available regarding its application by other countries.

(5) The extent of any sales tax advantage would depend on the kind and quantity of purchases of goods made in Australia and may, in practice, be of a relatively minor nature. The justification for any tax exemption is, of course, Australia's acceptance of the doctrine that one government should not seek to tax another. It is to be noted that the doctrine applies only to an arm of government; it does not apply in respect of corporations or other organisations owned by a government.
(6) It is the Government's practice to keep under review aspects of the tax laws on which it receives representations.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 25 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did he say in a speech delivered at the first International Conference on Technology for Development on 24 November 1980 that the CSIRO will provide a major impetus to Australia's micro-electronic industry.
(2) Is it a fact that the 1980-81 budget allocation to the CSIRO for the purpose of design of very large scale integration of the next generation of computer chip technology was $1.5 million.
(3) Is he able to state whether comparable expenditure in the micro-electronic industry in (a) Great Britain is $400m, (b) France is $270m, (c) Italy is $130m and (d) West Germany is $100m.

(4) Has his attention been drawn to the statement of Dr MacDonald of the University of Queensland in Search, Vol. 11, No. 11, November 1980, to the effect that the allocation to the CSIRO is a waste of effort given comparable expenditure in other countries and given also the isolation of this research effort from mainline computer research being carried out overseas.
(5) If so, and the position is as stated in parts (2) and (3), will he explain the relevance of his remarks referred to in part (1).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. In formally opening the 1st International Conference on Technology for Development I referred to my announcement that CSIRO would set up a research group to design very large scale integrated circuits (VLSI). Staff are now being recruited. I reiterate my view that this initiative will provide a major impetus to microelectronic technology in Australia. It will develop an indigenous design capability in Australia, and raise awareness of the enormous potential of custom chips in the late 1980s.

(2) No, it is not a fact. The CSIRO Executive has allocated $500,000 from the Organisation's 1980-81 Appropriation. The project will be financed at the level of $500,000 per annum for the next two years in the first instance. The amount envisaged is $1.5m in toto over 3 financial years.

(3) The comparison drawn between the expenditure of Great Britain, France, Italy and West Germany, and Australia is not valid. The European expenditure supports experimental and theoretical work concerning all aspects of the production of microelectronic circuits, including manufacture at the pilot plant scale. The CSIRO initiative will focus exclusively on the problems of chip design. CSIRO believes that an effort on this scale will be fruitful. In this matter they are not alone.
(4) Yes. I do not accept, however, the conclusions reached in this article. It is based on assumptions specific to the American situation.

(5) The facts as stated in 2, 3 and 4 above vindicate my confidence in the project. It is of considerable importance. CITA has identified microelectronics as a key area of modern manufacturing technology. The CSIRO initiative will give Australian industry access to an important sector of microelectronic technology.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Home Telephone Rentals: Department of Health

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many officers and employees of his Department have their home telephone rentals and/or charges (a) fully or (b) partially paid by his Department.
(2) What was the cost to his Department of this expenditure in 1979-80.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable gentleman's question is as follows:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Is it the practice of the Australian Telecommunications Commission to ascertain the telephone numbers of addressees of telegrams and to telephone telegrams through, even though a delivery fee has been paid; if so, what is the purpose of charging the delivery fee.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The telegram service offers a personalised message passing service and the fixed component of the telegram charge varies according to the sender's choice of method to be used in passing the message.

It is the practice in cases where the sender simply addresses a telegram to a residential or business address and pays the full charge rate for Telecom to deliver the message by the fastest means available. Quite often this is by telephone or telex. In these cases, the fee charged is not, therefore, for the physical delivery of the telegram but for transmission of the message by the fastest means possible. Should the addressee require a copy of the message which has been telephoned, it can be provided at no additional charge.

Where messenger service would provide the fastest means of delivery or if Telecom judges the messenger delivery would be more appropriate, say for telegrams concerning death, illness, or the like, then this means of delivery is used.

The sender, at the time of lodging a telegram, has the option of specifying messenger delivery by including the paid service indicator 'Messenger' before the address, and in such cases physical delivery of the message will be undertaken. However, in these circumstances it may not be practicable to pass the message to the addressee as quickly as when alternative methods such as telephone and telex are used.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) My attention has been drawn to the article.

In line with Directive 591 of 1976, STD barring has been introduced selectively in those Departmental offices where the switchboard equipment makes it possible. (2) Is there any basis to the thrust of these criticisms that section 50 of the Trade Practices Act as it is structured is almost totally ineffective;

(3) Will he take steps to ensure that the current dominance and control test is replaced by a provision, or a number of provisions, that effectively prevent mergers in substantial markets which have the effect of substantially lessening competition;

(4) Will he confirm the thrust of statements attributed to him upon his appointment that he favoured the curbing of monopoly power both through the Trade Practices Act and more direct forms of anti-monopoly regulation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware of some criticism made by Mr Ranald Macdonald of The Age newspaper;

(2) I understand that in making his criticism, Mr Macdonald was referring to the proposed takeover in 1979 of the Herald and Weekly Times Limited Group by the News Limited Group. In that case the Trade Practices Commission stated its intention to take proceedings for a contravention of section 50 of the Trade Practices Act to prohibit the takeover, but News Limited withdrew its offer before that action was taken;

(3) The present section 50 of the Trade Practices Act is the result of a considered decision taken by the Government when it implemented a substantial revision of the Trade Practices Act 1977. The Government has not since then changed its policy in relation to section 50. The Government is, of course, continuing to monitor all provisions of the Trade Practices Act;

(4) I believe, and it is the Government's policy, that the Government has a clear role to play in promoting and maintaining free and fair competition throughout the Australian economy and in preventing the abuse of monopoly power.
