QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 8 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can he state whether the substance Depo-Provera is recommended by any (a) professional, (b) academic or (c) government authority in Australia for contraceptive use.

(2) If so, (a) what qualifications are placed on its use, (b) are any contra-indications or recommended precautions especially applicable for patients who have difficulty in making an informed judgment for or against this use of the drug and (c) do any of these authorities recommend its use particularly for women who have difficulty in comprehending proper methods of use of alternative contraception.

(3) Will the Government take steps to ensure that (a) due precautions are not relaxed and (b) proper alternative contraception is available and adequately explained in particular to (i) the mentally retarded and (ii) Aborigines with limited understanding of contraceptives and of the English language and a high incidence of diabetes; if so, what steps will be taken.

(4) Will he seek the advice of the National Health and Medical Research Council on recommendations to the States for notification or other recording of contraceptive uses of Depo-Provera for statistical analysis of (a) safety, (b) side-effects and (c) reliability.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. However I understand Depo-Provera is used by Family Planning Associations, health authorities and private doctors in individual cases where a specific need exists for which no other contraceptive method is considered suitable.

(2) Those organisations which have approached my Department on the use of Depo-Provera as a contraceptive have been advised that the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee (ADEC) has considered progressively available information on Depo-Provera for contraceptive use on a number of occasions. The Committee is of the opinion that the use of the drug as a contraceptive must be regarded as investigational since there are unresolved questions related to its safety. This statement appears in the product information distributed by the company for this drug.

These organisations have also been advised that the ADEC supports the concept of properly controlled clinical trials provided they are designed to help resolve some of the questions raised and provided adequate measures are incorporated in the trial protocol satisfactorily to protect the participants. To date no applications have been made to my Department in this regard.

(3) (a) The Government is not in a position where it can take steps to ensure that due precautions are not relaxed in the situation where a drug is already available and relatively safe and effective for other accepted indications. It is a recognised fact that a doctor may occasionally decide that special circumstances warrant the use of a drug for conditions other than those for which it has been approved. In such circumstances the responsibility for adequately informing the patient or the guardian and for any adverse consequences of the therapy must rest with the practitioner concerned.

(b) Alternative forms of contraception are readily available and the product information relating to these is adequate to enable the medical practitioner to explain the position to his patient. It is a matter for the practitioner to determine what he considers to be the most appropriate method of contraception to suit the particular circumstances of his patients.
(4) Yes. However, it is for the reasons suggested by the honourable member that my Department has encouraged organisations to design properly controlled trials using Depo-Provera as a contraceptive.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Philip the Chimpanzee performed at Perth Entertainment Centre from 5 January to 17 January 1981.
(2) This animal and two other chimpanzees arrived in Perth from San Francisco on 3 January 1981 and left Australia on 21 January 1981.

(3) The Perth Entertainment Centre was registered as a 'B' Class circus under quarantine legislation for the duration of the animals' stay. ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Teaching of Languages Other Than English

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Young Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 30 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In how many (a) private, (b) State and (c) Commonwealth schools and/or other educational institutions are languages other than English taught.
(2) What is the number of students in each of these courses in each State or Territory.
(3) What is the number of teachers in each of these courses in each State and Territory teaching (a) part-time and (b) full-time courses.
(4) What special qualifications do these teachers have.
(5) What is the (a) basic material provided or (b) source of the teaching materials used in each of these courses.
(6) What sum was allocated in each State by the (a) State and (b) Commonwealth Departments of Education for these courses in each year since 1976.
(7) How many teachers are employed by the (a) private schools and by the (b) State and (c) Commonwealth Departments of Education.
(8) Are the classes held during or after normal school hours.
(9) Is there any choice for after-school classes in (a) State and (b) Commonwealth schools.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (3) and (7) Courses in languages other than English are offered at primary and secondary levels in Government, Catholic and independent schools, by part-time and full-time ethnic schools, and by tertiary institutions including the TAFE sector, In addition, some courses are offered by professional associations and by organisations in the private sector. Neither total numbers of students and teachers nor the number of schools and institutions offering courses are known. My Department is at present collating information currently available.

(4) It is generally the case that secondary school teachers of languages other than English have tertiary qualifications and some professional training in language teaching techniques. This, however, is less likely to be so in primary schools, where classes may be taught by teachers who speak a language other than English but without specialist qualifications. Some programs involve participation of members of ethnic communities. In a few cases teachers and/or other assistance are being provided by foreign governments.

(5) The provision of teaching materials for languages other than English is the responsibility of the authority concerned. However the Schools Commission through its Multicultural Education Program has provided funds for the development and production of language teaching materials. Languages for which materials are currently being produced include Italian, Greek and Dutch. Curriculum and material projects have been undertaken by schools and in some States by community groups. The Curriculum Development Centre has also supported the development of materials for community language teaching, and is involved in the Schools Commission Greek and Italian Curriculum Projects.

(6) Since 1978 the Government in accordance with recommendation 45 of the Galbally review has made additional funds available to the States for multicultural education including the teaching of community languages. The total allocation of $5m has been disbursed over a period of three years by the Schools Commission on the advice of State co-ordinating committees. In 1979 the total allocation for that year of $0.5m was directed to supporting the teaching of community languages. In 1980 and 1981 $1.5m and $3m respectively were made available for the further development of community languages for other aspects of multicultural education. General purpose recurrent grants from Commonwealth to State or non-Government schools can be used for foreign language teaching at the discretion of the authorities concerned.
The allocation of State funds to particular areas of education is a matter for the education authorities in each State.
The overall State allocations for the Multicultural Education Program for 1979 and 1980 were as follows:

$ $ New South Wales 194,500 485,500 Victoria 157,500 400,500 Queensland 82,500 206,000 South Australia 51,500 139,000 Western Australia 47,000 133,500 Tasmania 16,500 48,500 Northern Territory . . 24,000 Australian Capital Territory . . 31,100 Projects of National Significance . . 121,000

(8) and (9) Courses provided by the education authorities are in general held during school hours as part of the normal school curriculum. Ethnic school classes are mostly conducted outside normal school hours, although some are 'inserted' into normal school programs. At the present time it is estimated that there are between 1,200 and 1,300 ethnic schools in Australia. This figure does not include an estimated 600 'insertion' classes involving about 6,000 children.

The Government supports the teaching of languages in ethnic schools, and is providing $30 per capita grants to part-time non-profit-making ethnic schools with an open admissions policy. A survey is to be conducted to determine appropriate support for ethnic schools after an initial two-year funding period.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 5 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can the Attorney-General say whether it is a fact that the Registry of the Supreme Court of New South Wales will only accept Appeal documents typed on foolscap size paper.
(2) Can the Attorney-General say whether it is also a fact that the Registry of the High Court of Australia will only accept Appeal documents typed on A4 size paper.
(3) Is the Attorney-General able to say what is the average cost for re-typing an appeal book relating to an Appeal from the Supreme Court of New South Wales to the High Court of Australia.
(4) Will the Attorney-General take steps to ensure that these excessive costs for litigants are removed; if so, what steps.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I understand that documents prepared for use in the Supreme Court of New South Wales are, as a general rule, required to be on foolscap size paper.

(2) Documents prepared for use in the High Court of Australia are, as a general rule, required to be on A4 size paper. However, I am advised that it is the practice in appeals to the High Court from the Court of Appeal of the Supreme Court of New South Wales to allow the reproduction of the Court of Appeal appeal book if special representations are made by the parties on the grounds of cost. In other cases parties have photo-reduced the Court of Appeal appeal book, but I am advised that photo-reduction is unsatisfactory in most cases and that the High Court does not encourage it.
(3) No. The cost would vary according to the size of the appeal book.

(4) The size of documents used in proceedings in the High Court of Australia and the Supreme Court of New South Wales is a matter of pactice and procedure within the responsibilities of those Courts. I am advised that there have been discussions between the two Courts on this matter, but that the problems have not yet been resolved. I hope that it will be possible for these problems to be overcome by agreement between the Courts so that the costs of litigation can be kept as low as possible.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Commonwealth Parliament Offices: Payment of Staff

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 13 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the proposed elimination of the cash mode of salary payment as recommended in the Review of Commonwealth Functions (Hansard, 30 April 1981, page 1844) apply to staff in Commonwealth Parliament Offices.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth Functions (Statutes Review) Bill 1981 contains an amendment to the Audit Act 1901 to provide that any payments of remuneration or allowances to Commonwealth employees shall not be made in cash, unless the Minister for Finance otherwise determines.
The staff in Commonwealth Parliament Offices come within the definition of 'Commonwealth employee' for the purposes of the Bill.

It is expected that a few exemptions will be granted mainly in respect of industrial type payrolls. Many other forms of salary payment are now available including cheque, pay to cheque account, savings bank, approved credit unions and approved building societies. The proposed elimination of cash pays should thus not present great difficulties; it will, however, remove an element of risk to life and property which is present in the cash distribution system.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Young Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 4 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many adult migrant and refugee education teachers are employed in each State on an (a) permanent, (b) temporary, (c) casual and (d) hourly basis.
(2) How many persons in each State are estimated to be in need of English classes.
(3) How many English classes are (a) conducted or (b) financed in each State under the Adult Migrant and Refugee Education program.
(4) How many students are taking part in the Adult Migrant and Refugee Education program in each State.
(5) How many of the students referred to in part (4) were admitted to Australia as (a) immigrants and (b) refugees.
(6) What provisions (a) are or (b) were there to increase staff and funding in this area with more than 100,000 immigrants coming to this country.
(7) What is the standard material used by the students and teachers in the courses for Adult Migrants and Refugees.
(8) Can he say what new curriculum and/or materials are (a) used, (b) being prepared or (c) in the process of being prepared by his Department and/or the Department of Education.
(9) How many persons are employed on curriculum development referred to in part (8).

(10) How many of the persons employed on curriculum development (a) speak fluently a language other than English, (b) have formal qualifications in linguistics or (c) have special expertise or training in the preparation of curriculum materials.

(11) How many of the teachers employed on the Adult Migrant and Refugee Education Program (a) speak fluently a language other than English, (b) have formal qualifications in this specific area, or (c) have special expertise or training in teaching Adult Migrants and Refugees.
(12) Are there any plans to broaden or change the Adult Migrant and Refugee Education Program.
(13) What mechanisms of consultation with the State Ministers and/or Departments of Education regarding the Adult Migrant and Refugee Education Program are there.

(14) Is ultimate responsibility for the program and the employment of teachers vested in the (a) State Department of Education, (b) Federal Department of Education, (c) Schools Commission or (d) his Department.
(15) How many officers are employed on the administrative side of (a) the Adult Migrant and Refugee Education Program, (b) curriculum development, (c) State administration and (d) any other area.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Some 2000 teachers are employed in the Adult Migrant Education Program throughout Australia. The bulk of these are employed on an hourly paid basis. The position regarding permanent teachers varies according to the appropriate mix of full-time and part-time staff needed to facilitate a positive and substantial benefit to stablility, quality and effectiveness of program services. Victoria, Western Australia and Tasmania have no permanent teachers employed in the program. New South Wales has some 123 permanent teacher positions, Queensland 6, South Australia 9 and the Northern Territory 6. Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia employ some full-time temporary teachers and in New South Wales a number of hourly paid staff work on a full-time basis. As staffing arrangements are the responsibility of the States, my Department does not keep detailed statistics of the number of teachers in the categories listed.

(2) There is no direct information available on the number of persons in each State in need of English classes. The Galbally Report estimated from a broad appraisal of 1976 Census data that in May 1978 there were some 400,000 adults in Australia whose fluency in English was 'low'. Currently, there are research projects underway to implement Galbally Recommendation 10 aimed at obtaining information on the English language and related needs of migrants in Australia. Further data will become available from the 1981 Census.

(3) and (4) The Commonwealth provides the funds for the Adult Migrant Education Program in each State (some minor rental charges for the use of schools and halls are not met by the Commonwealth). There is a range of courses provided under the Adult Migrant Education Program which includes initial settlement courses and, as part of the on-going program, day and evening classes, full-time and part-time courses, correspondence tuition, courses at the workplace, specific purpose English courses to meet employment needs and English by television. In addition a voluntary Home Tutor Scheme helps men and women who are unable to take advantage of other learning opportunities.

It is estimated that in 1980-81 some 750 on-arrival courses will be held encompassing some 15,000 students. It is expected that within the on-going program there will be about 105,000 enrolments in 1980-81.
(5) Migrants and refugees are not separately identified in Adult Migrant Education Program statistics.
(6) Funding for the Adult Migrant Education Program nationally has increased substantially in recent years as shown by the following figures:

Ninety-five per cent of the budget for the Adult Migrant Education Program (excluding living allowances) is for salary and salary-related costs of persons employed by States and non-Government bodies conducting services within the program.

(7) and (8) A detailed syllabus has been developed for the on-arrival program and supplied to teachers working in that program. This work has been well received in Australia and commended by international experts.

Pilot materials based on that syllabus have been prepared including slides, cassettes, charts and language skill practice materials, with a view to national production of the materials. The idea has met with limited success and some further development is necessary before national production is possible. The development of further national course material for student and teacher use is at present under consideration.

The State Adult Migrant Education Centres develop and use a range of materials with the benefit of audio visual equipment provided for the program. Particular attention is being given to the development of individualised materials for use by students according to what they see as their own needs.

A course syllabus and accompanying materials have been prepared for use in the courses-in-industry program. A course syllabus and accompanying materials have been developed for the programs run for particular occupational groups, e.g. nurses and motor mechanics and for professionally qualified people.

The trialling of the ASLPR (a uniquely Australian language proficiency rating scale) has been concluded and techniques have been developed for establishing proficiency levels according to the scale (through the observace of actual language behaviour within given situations and settings). The ASLPR is being increasingly used at all levels of the program. It assists classroom teachers to determine the capabilities-and therefore the course requirements for individual students-as well as providing an instrument for broader needs assessment and course planning and development at the State and national levels.

(9) Curriculum development is undertaken by working parties, the membership of which includes staff of the State Adult Migrant Education Services and outside consultants, or by contracted specialists. A joint Commonwealth/States Committee on professional aspects of the Adult Migrant Education Program has been established to oversee curriculum and materials development. The Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs services the working parties, is responsible for liaison, undertakes some editing of the material produced and arranges the production of material. The number of staff involved is two.
(10) No Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs staff are directly employed on curriculum development.
The staff referred to in part (9) above speak a language other than English, have undertaken studies in the teaching of English as a second language and in linguistics.

(11) My Department does not keep statistics on the qualifications of the teachers who are employed by the States. The States have in-service training arrangements for teachers in the program. Under Galbally Recommendation 7, funds have been provided for in-service training and teacher development, especially for the On-arrival program. Two national in-service conferences have been held for Officers-in-Charge and Teachers-in-Charge with funds provided under this Recommendation. Funding has also been provided for local in-service arrangements, initially as a follow up to those conferences, and subsequently to assist the continuing development of teacher skills in planning and conducting courses, developing materials and evaluating outcomes.

(12) The Adult Migrant Education Program underwent change and reshaping following the Government's acceptance of the Galbally Report. Reshaping and development are continuing in accordance with the objectives of the Adult Migrant Education Program, viz:

1. To provide English language learning opportunities for migrants and refugees from non-English speaking backgrounds including specific need groups to meet personal, social and employment needs and to equip them to understand and make use of social institutions including those institutions through which they may wish to pursue educational advancements.
2. To provide information about living in Australia.
(13) There are various mechanisms of consultation regarding the Adult Migrant Education Program:
(i) Consultative committees in each State comprising senior officers of the State Adult Migrant Education Services and DIEA Regional Offices.
(ii) Commonwealth/State meetings of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs officers.
(iii) Commonwealth/State meetings of Ministers for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.
(iv) Joint Commonwealth/States Committee on professional aspects of the Adult Migrant Education Program.
(vi) Consultations between senior officers from the States and DIEA Central and Regional Offices on budget and program matters.
(vii) Joint Commonwealth/State Co-ordinating Committee on the Home Tutor Scheme.
(viii) Joint Steering committees in States to oversee the implementation of studies and surveys.
(ix) Day to day liaison between DIEA Regional Office and the State Adult Migrant Education Services officers.

(14) My Department as my delegate is responsible for arranging the provision of courses in accordance with the Immigration (Education) Act. This co-ordinating and arranging role has recently been confirmed in the Prime Minister's statement on the Review of Commonwealth Functions. The States or other agencies with whom the arrangements are made for the provision of courses are responsible for the employment of teachers and for their terms and conditions of service.
(15) The number of Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs personnel employed on the Adult Migrant Education Program in the Department's Central and Regional Offices, as at 30 April was:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 24 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Further to his predecessor's answer to parts (9), (10) and (11) of Question No. 5359 (Hansard, 22 May 1980, page 3198), what is the definition of the term 'chemical and biological defence' in the two agreements referred to.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The two arrangements referred to are the Technical Co-operation Program, which is administered in Australia by the Defence Science and Technology Organisation, and the Basic Standardisation Agreement, which is administered by the Army. Neither contains a definition of chemical and biological defence. The terms are interpreted by the participating countries in accordance with common usage. The definition of chemical and biological defence which is applicable to Australia's involvement in both arrangements is that stated in the Australian Joint Services Staff Manual Glossary: 'The methods, plans, procedures and training required to establish defence measures against the effects of attack by chemical and biological agents.'

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Service by Australian Army Officers in United Nations Truce Supervisory Organisation in Palestine

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 25 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Minister consider the declaration of Service by a small contingent of Australian Army officers in the United Nations Truce Supervisory Organisation in Palestine during the 1960's and early 1970's as eligibility for repatriation and Defence Service Homes benefits.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The question of providing Repatriation and Defence Service Homes benefits to members of the United Nations Peacekeeping, Monitoring and Observing Forces and to members of similar forces has been considered on many occasions.

Although it was recognised that they would be placed in a position where injury or death could occur in the course of their duties, they were not required to engage enemy forces in military operations and were not considered to be on 'special duty' in a 'special area' as defined in the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act 1962.

Consideration of this matter involves more than service in Palestine. It would also have to include the extension of benefits to all serving Defence members and others involved in peacekeeping forces e.g. those in Cyprus.

However, members of peacekeeping, monitoring and observing Forces are eligible to claim compensation under the Commonwealth Employees' Compensation Act 1930-1970 which has since been replaced by the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971. Special United Nations compensation provisions also applied to their service.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 11 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What procedures are followed in appeals lodged by Federal Members of Parliament on behalf of aggrieved social security recipients or unsuccessful social security applicants against a decision of (a) a Social Security branch office, where the appeal is lodged with the State Director of Social Security and (b) a State Director of Social Security, where the appeal is lodged with the Minister for Social Security.
(2) What is the average time taken to process these appeals.

(3) What was the average time taken in 1980 to process appeals made to the Social Security Tribunal on decisions concerning (a) invalid pensions, (b) age pensions, (c) unemployment benefits, (d) supporting parents benefits, (e) family allowances, (f) widows' pensions and (g) special benefits in (i) Brisbane, (ii) Sydney, (iii) Melbourne, (iv) Adelaide, (v) Perth, (vi) Darwin, (vii) Hobart and (viii) Canberra.
(4) Are Social Security Tribunals in each State required to have as a member of the Tribunal a representative of the medical profession.
(5) Is it a fact that the Social Security Tribunal in Brisbane has been without a representative of the medical profession as a member of the Tribunal for several months; if so, why.
(6) If the Brisbane Tribunal has been without a representative of the medical profession has this resulted in delays of up to 4 to 5 months in processing appeal applications.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Where an appeal is lodged against a decision made by an officer in a Social Security branch office or by a State Director, and that appeal has not previously been considered by a Social Security Appeals Tribunal, the appeal is referred to the Tribunal for registration and is then handled in accordance with the normal procedures governing social security appeals. These procedures require, among other things, that the decision appealed against be reconsidered by the Department of Social Security and then, if the appeal is not to be conceded at this stage, dealt with by the Tribunal.

Where an appeal has previously been considered by a Tribunal which has recommended dismissal of the appeal, since 9 September 1980 the unsuccessful appellant may appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The State Director of Social Security in the case of representations made to him from a Federal Member of Parliament, and the Director-General of the Department in the case of representations to the Minister for Social Security, could still review the decision appealed against where, for example, additional evidence was supplied, notwithstanding this further right of appeal. The Federal Member is, of course, advised of the outcome of the appeal. Representations from Federal Members not involving an appeal are dealt with in accordance with usual departmental procedures.
(2) Statistics on the average time taken to process these appeals are not collected separately from statistics for all finalised appeals dealt with by the Social Security Appeals Tribunals.

(3) Statistics on the average time taken in 1980 to process appeals made to the Social Security Appeals Tribunals are not available by pension, benefit or allowance. The average processing time shown in the table below is for finalised appeals dealt with by the Social Security Appeals Tribunals by State and Territory. The average processing time measures the number of working days between the date of registration of the appeal by the Social Security Appeals Tribunal and the date of the Tribunal's recommendation. Where the Tribunal recommends dismissal of the appeal, the date of the recommendation is the same as the date of finalisation. However, where the Tribunal recommended the appeal be upheld, processing time does not include the period between the date the Tribunal made a recommendation and the date the Department finalised the appeal, for which statistics are not available.

(4) No. A Social Security Appeals Tribunal has a doctor as one of its members only when dealing with medical appeals under the Social Services Act 1947. There is no requirement to have a doctor when a Tribunal is dealing with a non-medical appeal.

(5) A medical practitioner was appointed to the Social Security Appeals Tribunals in Queensland on 27 May 1981 and I expect to make additional appointments soon. A major obstacle in the making of such appointments prior to this was the reluctance of suitable doctors to accept appointment at the then prevailing rates of remuneration. However, after I raised this matter with the Minister for Administrative Services, a new determination was made by the Remuneration Tribunal on 4 May 1981 increasing the sitting fees payable to all members of the Social Security Appeals Tribunals.

(6) The delay in appointing doctors to the Queensland Social Security Appeals Tribunals has unfortunately meant that some medical appeals have not been handled as expeditiously as might otherwise have been the case, but it is not possible to say how many appeals have been so affected. It is important to note however that the right of appeal operates in addition to, rather than in substitution for, the review process which previously operated, and that delays in the appointment of doctors to the Tribunals have in no way delayed this process, which involves the Department of Health and, as appropriate, external medical specialists.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 25 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Government announced that it wishes to give assistance and encouragement to parents attempting to provide education in a normal school for their disabled children as opposed to special schools and sheltered employment; if so, in this International Year of Disabled Persons will this assistance include telephone concessions to families caring for disabled children at home.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government announced on 20 August 1980 that an additional $1m will be provided under the Schools Commission's Special Education Program for extra Staff resources to assist the integration of a further 300 handicapped children into regular schools, to operate from 1981. In addition, priority will be given to funding projects that will result in the movement of as many children as possible from special to regular schools. Government and non-government school systems, and schools, will be eligible to apply for grants for projects. The funds may also be used to:
(a) provide support to enable isolated handicapped children to attend neighbourhood regular schools;
(b) fund projects designed to test new ways of fully or partially assisting handicapped children already integrated into regular schools; and
(c) facilitate the enrolment of handicapped children who are beginning their formal schooling into regular primary schools.
The provisions of this program do not include telephone concessions for families caring for disabled children.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Underspending of Estimates: Department of Employment and Youth Affairs

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 7 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) On what basis were the original 1980-81 appropriations made for division (a) 286-Administrative and (b) 288-Commonwealth Employment Service.

(2) Has there been an underspending in these divisions by the estimate contained in the Department of Finance Information Paper, 'Statement on savings expected in annual appropriations made by Acts Nos. 141 and 142-Appropriations Acts (Nos 1 and 2) 1980-81; if so, what are the reasons.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The original 1980-81 Appropriations made for my Department for Division 286-Administrative and Division 288-Commonwealth Employment Service were those presented to the Parliament in Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1980-81. The Government considered my Department's estimates in the light of its policies in respect of particular areas of expenditure and of general financial and economic objectives.

The general principles applied to the preparation of estimates by my Department are set out in the Directions issued by the Secretary of the Department of Finance under the Authority of the Audit Act 1901. These Directions are long standing and have been endorsed by successive Governments. The relevant general principles are set out in Finance Direction 6.3 and provide in essence that:

(i) Estimates shall represent a realistic assessment of the sums expected to be spent and shall be based on current or known costs. Items of a recurring nature may be estimated on the basis of experience.
(ii) Estimates shall not include amounts in respect of proposals which are so far from firm that it is not possible to form any real estimate of what payment, if any, will be made.

(2) The Department of Finance Information Paper, 'Statement of Savings Expected in Annual Appropriations Made By Acts Nos. 141 and 142-Appropriation Acts (Nos. 1 and 2) 1980-81', sets out amounts by which my Department estimated, at the time of preparation of the Appropriation Bills (Nos. 3 and 4) 1980-81, expenditure under the Appropriation Items concerned would at 30 June fall short of the Appropriation originally made. What actual underspending will occur in respect of those or other Items cannot be stated with certainty at this stage. The estimated savings would reflect for the most part the following circumstances:

(i) Current expectation that events would not occur by 30 June 1981, in cases where financial provision had been made in the Appropriation Acts (Nos. 1 and 2) 1980-81 in the then expectation that they would occur by that date.
(ii) Compliance with Government policy that, as far as practicable, savings be offered as offsets to additional funds sought in the Appropriation Bills (Nos. 3 and 4), 1980-81; and
(iii) The results of efforts by Departmental management to improve efficiency and thereby reduce costs.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Integration of Handicapped Children into Regular Schools

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 8 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the estimate of the Director of Child and Adolescent Psychiatric Services at Melbourne's Austin Hospital, Dr Bruce Tonge, that more than 20 per cent of children under 18 years of age suffer from chronic illness or disability.
(2) If so, does Dr Tonge estimate that this percentage is increasing.
(3) What is the Government's commitment in respect of the integration of handicapped children into regular schools.
(4) Will the total 1980 allocation of $1m for the integration of handicapped children into regular schools be increased for the next school year.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Although I am unaware of the basis of Dr Tonge's estimate, the Australian Health Survey conducted by the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) in 1977-78 revealed that 19 per cent of children under 5 years, 27 per cent of persons between the ages of 5 and 14 years and 32 per cent of persons aged 15 to 24 had a chronic condition (ie. any permanent disability; any illness, injury or impairment which a respondent claims to have had for more than six months; illnesses under control e.g. diabetes, epilepsy).
Because a dissection of the above data by single year ages is not available, the percentage relating to such persons under the age of 18 years cannot be accurately determined.
The ABS plans to repeat the Australian Health Survey in 1983. No later figures for comparative purposes will be available until the survey is completed.

The definition of a chronic condition used in the Health Survey covers a wide range of illnesses and disabilities of varying levels of severity. I presume many of the children of school age who are included could be attending normal schools. The relevance of the Survey to the Government's supplementary program to assist, the integration of handicapped children into normal schools cannot be readily assessed.
(3) The Government's commitment in respect of the integration of handicapped children into regular schools is to provide $1m (subject to normal allowance for price rises) in 1981 for:
(a) projects that will result in the movement of as many children as possible from special to regular schools;
(b) support to enable isolated handicapped children to attend neighbourhood regular schools;
(c) projects designed to test new ways of fully or partially assisting handicapped children already integrated into regular schools;
(d) facilitating the enrolment of handicapped children who are beginning their formal schooling into regular primary schools.
Of these purposes it is intended that priority should be given to the first one, which is concerned with the movement of children from special to regular schools.

Applications from systems and their schools and from non-systemic schools are appraised by panels in the States and the Northern Territory representative of Education Departments, Catholic Education Commissions, Associations of Independent Schools and the Schools Commission. The recommendations of appraisal panels are submitted for my approval. Grants are offered and payments are made to systems and individual schools for approved projects.

(4) For 1982 the Government has maintained expenditure, in real terms, on the integration of handicapped children into regular schools. This expenditure will be more closely related to the special education programs for government and non-government schools by being incorporated as an element of these programs in 1982.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Telephone Calls by Staff: Department of Veterans' Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

(1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a report in the West Australian of 18 July 1979, page 37, that London metropolitan police reduced its telephone bill by $985,000, or about 20 per cent by use of monitoring device which recorded length, time and destination of telephone calls and the extension from which the call was made.
(2) Are personal telephone calls, particularly trunk and STD calls, made by staff of the Department of Veterans' Affairs controlled; if so, in what way.
(3) Has any consideration been given to the introduction of monitoring devices for telephone calls in the Department; if so, what was the outcome of the consideration.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) Telephones are for official use only, although in an emergency private calls may be made. Private trunk calls are booked through the switchboard operator following approval by the officer's section head and the costs of such calls are to be remitted immediately to the Collector of Public Monies. It is not permitted to use STD for private calls. Where the switchboard equipment permits, STD access is restricted to those extensions where access is considered essential to the efficient operations of the officers concerned. All other extensions are barred from STD and details of trunk calls made from any extension are recorded by the switchboard operator. Where the equipment does not permit STD barring, switchboard operators carry out regular monitoring of calls.

(3) Monitoring devices, when available, are installed to record details of calls made and the information received is reviewed by senior staff members. The limited number of monitoring devices available and costs involved prohibit permanent installation on all extensions.

The Department of Veterans' Affairs is conscious of the need for economies in telephone usage and regular reviews are carried out in all areas of operations. Staff are made aware of Departmental policies in this regard and are encouraged to restrict telephone usage to essential business matter.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the annual cost of providing assistance to the Australian motor vehicle industry by (a) direct subsidy, (b) grant, (c) tariff protection, (d) quota protection and (e) other forms of State or Commonwealth assistance.
(2) Is he able to say how many persons are employed by the motor vehicle industry.
(3) What would be the cost of providing an annual pension to all motor vehicle industry employees at a rate equivalent to male average weekly earnings.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lynch The Rt Hon Sir P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) to (e) The assistance package for domestic passenger motor vehicle production is made up of a number of interrelated measures. The protective effect of many of these measures, for example, quotas, local content plan, is difficult to quantify in dollar terms. These difficulties are heightened when estimates of the subsidy equivalent of the protective incidence of the assistance package are aggregated and then evaluated on a 'per employee' basis.

The latest available estimates of assistance accorded to passenger motor vehicle production are contained in the Industries Assistance Commission's draft report 'Passenger Motor Vehicles and Components-Post 1984 Assistance Arrangements', released on 24 February 1981. Discussion of the effect of the assistance package on consumer prices and the allocation of productive resources is contained in Chapter 6 (especially pp 97-103) of the Commission's report. In appendix 8 of the report, the Commission discusses the assumptions under which its analysis has proceeded including some of the limitations of its approach.
(2) The latest available figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics based on the manufacturing census for 1978-79 estimate employment for the motor vehicles and parts industry at 76,664.

The Industries Assistance Commission's analysis of employment in passenger vehicle production is contained on pp 47-48 of the draft report. From evidence received the Commission estimated that in March 1980 about 65,000 persons were employed in the production of passenger vehicles and components. Of these, approximately 60 per cent were employed by the five Plan manufacturers.

The Commission's estimates are broadly consistent with estimates by the Department of Industry and Commerce which indicate around 69,000 persons are currently employed in the industry-38,500 by the five Plan manufacturers, 400 in assembly outside the Plan and about 30,000 in over 700 establishments engaged in the production of automotive components.

These figures cover employment in the manufacturing sector only and do not include employment in related areas such as importing distribution and servicing. Estimates provided to the Commission by the Dealer's Association indicated that in 1979 dealers employed about 70,000 persons. Employment by importers is estimated at 12,800 in December 1980.

(3) The Australian Bureau of Statistics estimate of average weekly earnings per employed male unit is $290.00 for the December quarter 1980. On this basis and the IAC and departmental figures provided in (2) above the annual cost of a pension to passenger motor vehicle manufacturing industry employees would be between $980.2m and $1040.5m.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Taxation on Profit from Elder Smith Goldsbrough Mort Ltd Share Transactions

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hurford Mr C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 28 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the reported $16.5m profit taken by Mr Robert Holmes a'Court and his Bell Group from the trading in shares of Elder Smith Goldsbrough Mort Ltd.

(2) Is it a fact that this profit will not be taxable pursuant to section 26AAA of the Income Tax Assessment Act, because the group has sold or is selling a subsidiary company which holds the Elders shares and is not selling the shares recently purchased.
(3) Is it the Government's intention that this profit should be taxable; if so, what action will be taken.
(4) Is it the Government's intention that this profit should be taxed, what is the reason.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2), (3) and (4) Because the secrecy provisions of the income tax law prevent the Commissioner of Taxation from informing either myself or any other person about the affairs of individual taxpayers, I am not in a position to comment on the tax consequences of the transactions to which the honourable member refers.

I have, however, asked the Commissioner to examine the question of possible weaknesses in section 26AAA of the Income Tax Assessment Act. The matter is one of considerable complexity but I expect to receive a report from the Commissioner soon.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hurford Mr C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 28 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the recent report of the Prices Justification Tribunal on Prices for petroleum products, state that the Tribunal proposes to remove the return on the retailing investment component from the wholesale list price of motor spirit from January 1982.
(2) If so, is it the Government's intention to require that this price adjustment be made.
(3) Will he ensure that the Tribunal is able to conduct the further inquiries needed to enable the new list prices to be determined.

(4) Is the Government proposing to deregulate oil prices by abolishing the Tribunal at a time when oil companies have been seeking 3c per litre more than the Tribunal is prepared to allow and when there is so much more to be done.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Prices Justification Tribunal, in its report of 31 March 1981 into the prices of petroleum products, stated that it proposed to remove the return on retail investment component from the maximum justified wholesale prices of motor spirit in January 1982.

(2), (3) and (4) On 27 May 1981 I introduced legislation into the Parliament to establish a Petroleum Products Pricing Authority. This body will have powers similar to those the PJT currently has in relation to petroleum product pricing, and will be able to consider matters such as the extent to which motor spirit prices include a return on investment by the companies in retail outlets.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Industries Assistance Commission Report on Wheelchairs

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Duffy Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 28 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was the final Industries Assistance Commission report on wheelchairs signed on 23 December 1980 and submitted to the Minister.
(2) If so, when is it expected that the report will be released.
(3) If the recommendations will be dealt with during 1981, will he be mindful of the fact that 1981 is the International Year of Disabled Persons.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) I tabled the report in the Parliament on 26 May 1981 following the Government's decision to reduce the tariff on mechanically propelled wheelchairs from 34 per cent to 20 per cent and the tariff on hand propelled wheelchairs from 36 per cent to 20 per cent, in each case over a period of two years, as recommended by the Industries Assistance Commission.

(3) The Government was mindful of the fact that 1981 is the International Year of Disabled Persons when it considered the IAC report and made its decision thereon. The Government was also conscious of the scheme it announced in the budget to provide aids, including wheelchairs, free of charge to the disabled, subject to specialist medical prescription.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 30 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What proportion of school leavers proceed to full time tertiary education in (a) Australia (b) The United States of America and (c) Japan.
(2) Is he able to say what proportion of students in tertiary educational institutions in (a) Australia, (b) the USA and (c) Japan pay tuition fees.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) A survey carried out by the Australian Bureau of Statistics in May 1980 revealed that in Australia 22.2 per cent of persons who left secondary school in 1979 studied full time in 1980 at a post-school educational institution (including university, college of advanced education and technical and further education institutions).

(b) and (c) Comparable information on school leavers is not readily available for the USA and Japan. The following table, while not relating specifically to school leavers, does show the proportions of persons of particular ages attending tertiary education institutions (excluding technical and further education institutions in the case of Australia) on a full time basis. These figures are the latest available from the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD). Interpretation of the figures should take into account such factors as differences in education systems, the emphasis placed on part time education in Australia (particularly through apprenticeships) and deficiencies in the scope and coverage of the statistics. A description of how the education systems in each of the three countries are classified is contained in 'Classification of Educational Systems-Summary Volume' OECD Paris 1975.
(a) Persons of specified ages enrolled full time in tertiary education as proportions of persons of those ages in the population.
Source: 'Educational Statistics in OECD Countries'-OECD, Paris 1981.

(2) (a) In Australia since 1974, tuition fees have not been imposed at tertiary institutions for vocationally oriented courses, or courses leading to awards. Most students at universities, colleges of advanced education and technical and further education institutions are in this category, the notable exceptions being TAFE students enrolled in adult education courses. The recently announced decision that tuition fees be re-introduced in universities and colleges of advanced education for students undertaking degrees and diplomas subsequent to an initial tertiary qualification except for recognised double degree or diploma combinations and postgraduate students in receipt of Commonwealth Postgraduate Awards or holders of university and college of advanced education postgraduate awards will take effect for new enrolments from the beginning of 1982.

(b) In the USA I understand that it is general practice for tertiary institutions to charge all undergraduate students tuition fees. Recent information indicates that these fees range from approximately $US200 to $US1000 per year at state funded institutions. Annual tuition fees at private institutions range up to $US5000 p.a.
(c) In Japan all undergraduate students pay tuition fees. The scale of fees charged is not readily available.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Young Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 30 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What proportion of the annual expenditure of his Department is allocated for (a) immigrants and (b) refugees, considering that the money allocated under the Galbally Report did not make any specific provisions for refugees.
(2) Were approximately 20,000 refugees allowed into Australia in 1980.
(3) Have there been any specific funds allocated by his Department for the settlement of refugees.
(4) What provisions are there to cater for the specific needs of (a) refugees and (b) the increased number of immigrants, in 1981-82.

(5) For what programs and policies specifically concerning (a) refugees and (b) immigrants is his Department responsible and what sum was allocated to these specific, separate programs in each year since 1977.
(6) What proportion of his Department's expenditure on (a) refugees and (b) immigrants was spent on administrative expenses in each of the same years.
(7) With what other (a) Commonwealth and (b) State departments does his Department share responsibilities for the settlement of (i) refugees and (ii) immigrants.
(8) What consultative mechanisms are there between his Department and the States concerning the settlement of (a) refugees and (b) immigrants.
(9) To what degree are the various States consulted on the number of (a) refugees and (b) immigrants they are capable of settling on a (i) long and (ii) short term basis.

(10) What provisions, such as special funds, etc., exist to help the States to cope with the speedy and successful settlement of (a) refugees and (b) immigrants and what sum was paid for this purpose in each year since 1977.
(11) How many (a) refugees and (b) immigrants are currently staying in the various settlement centres in each State.
(12) How many of the (a) refugees, (b) immigrants or (c) other categories received assisted passage since 1977 and what was the country of citizenship of the recipients.
(13) What projects exist to cater for the speedy settlement of (a) refugees and (b) immigrants in each State.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Programs administered by DIEA to facilitate settlement are designed for immigrants. In this respect refugees are regarded as a category of immigrant. In general, no specific allocations are made for the various categories of immigrants.
(2) 21,692 persons entered Australia in 1980 under the Refugee and related programs.

(3) Apart from programs referred to in (i), funds are available to reimburse voluntary agencies for expenditure on clothing and other necessities provided to needy refugees immediately on arrival. A revolving fund has been established and administered by voluntary agencies (CALFRIC) to provide establishment loans up to a maximum of $600 for refugees. Payment of special benefits by Department of Social Security is payable from day of arrival where required rather than after seven days in the case of certain other immigrants.
(4) This will be taken into consideration in the context of the 1981-82 Budget.

(5) Various programs are administered by DIEA to facilitate the settlement of migrants. Specific programs may be identified from the recommendations of the Galbally Report which the Government accepted in full and is implementing and also from details of votes administered by DIEA within its appropriations.
(6) Total administrative expenses of DIEA are set out in departmental appropriations. No breakdown between the various components of the Department's activities is available.

(7) Department of Social Security, Commonwealth Employment Service, Department of Administrative Services, Department of Education, State Adult Migrant Education Services, State Ministries of Immigration and/or Ethnic Affairs, health authorities and others.

(8) Meetings of Commonwealth and State Ministers for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and meetings of Commonwealth and State officials are held twice a year. Extensive consultative arrangements apply with State Adult Migrant Education Services. There are Migrant Settlement Councils in all States and Territories with Commonwealth and State/Territorial Government representatives on them.

(9) The intake of refugee and other migrants is discussed at each six-monthly meeting of Commonwealth and State Ministers for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs as one of the principal agenda items. There are also regular consultations with the States at official level. Discussions encompass both short-term and long-term considerations.

(10) State Adult Migrant Education Services are responsible for the majority of the Adult Migrant Education Program which is virtually wholly funded by the Commonwealth from funds appropriated to DIEA. Joint funding arrangements are available for State Governments for the employment of interpreters and translators. Details of funds made available for these purposes may be obtained from Budget papers.
(11) As at 11 May 1981, there were the following numbers of refugees and migrants at migrant centres.
In addition, migrant centres provide some accommodation for non-migrants-48 people (mainly apprentices) resided in the centres as at 11 May 1981.
I would draw the honourable member's attention to the fact that some State Government's also run centres which offer accommodation to migrants.
(12) Details can be found in Tables 14 and 23 in the Australian Immigration Consolidated Statistics 1979. A copy has been forwarded to the honourable member.
(13) See (5). The Community Refugee Settlement Scheme has been established to facilitate the successful settlement of refugees directly into the community.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Young Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 30 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many applications for (a) visitors', (b) permanent settlement and (c) temporary resident visas to Australia have been (i) approved and (ii) rejected since 1978 and from which countries were the (A) successful and (B) unsuccessful applications made.
(2) How many persons permitted to enter Australia without a permanent settlement visa since 1978 have permission to work in Australia.
(3) What provisions were there for (a) housing, (b) education, (c) employment, (d) social security, (e) health or (f) other areas for newly arrived permanent or temporary arrivals since 1978.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) Arrival of persons for temporary residence ('T' category).
No. of No. of Total Period

Note: Visitors are not normally permitted to undertake employment here. In applying for entry, visitors are required to make a declaration that they will not seek employment or undertake formal studies during the period of their intended stay in Australia.

Students may undertake vacation employment and/or employment as an integral part of their course and/or in the form of practical experience at the completion of their courses. This is normally permitted where it is necessary to obtain registration or acceptance as a member of a professional body and where this necessary work experience cannot be gained in their own country. They may also undertake some part-time employment as long as this does not interfere with their academic progress.

Temporary residents include high level staff for Australian branches of overseas companies, academics for educational and research institutions, entertainers and sportsmen and certain professional and technical workers with special expertise who are often required in the early stages of establishment of some new developmental enterprises. Figures are not available by category by period of stay but the majority of specialised workers come for short periods. Usually temporary residents are eligible to remain for periods up to four years. The dependants of working age of temporary residents are not prohibited from undertaking employment or studies in Australia. The working holiday maker schemes involve reciprocity and the work is incidental to the holiday.
(3) Migrants entering Australia for permanent residence have the same entitlements as ordinary residents of Australia in regard to the matters raised. In more specific terms:

(a) housing-certain migrants and refugees are entitled to initial accommodation in migrant centres; family reunion categories are expected to be accommodated initially at least by a sponsoring close relative; generally permanent arrivals are eligible for State Government provided housing on the same basis as normal Australian residents, waiting periods varying from State to State;

(b) education-migrants and their dependants have the same access to education as other residents but in addition special programs of English language learning are available for both adults and children from funding provided mainly by the Commonwealth;
(c) employment-the facilities of the Commonwealth Employment Service are available for all migrants and refugees;
(d) social security-permanent arrivals are entitled to all social security provisions on the same basis as other Australian residents-residential requirements apply in certain instances;

(e) health-most medical and hospital organisations have special arrangements for newly arrived migrants ensuring that they can acquire adequate cover from the date of arrival without any waiting period. The Government has decided that migrants and refugees will be eligible for bulk billing for medical services for six months after arrival. Migrants and refugees are subject to health screening before visas are issued;
(f) other areas-an extensive range of programs is available to facilitate the settlement of migrants and refugees including those covered by recommendations of the Galbally Report.
Access to matters covered by (a) to (f) by temporary arrivals varies according to the condition of their entry.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 5 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to my question without notice to him on 9 April 1981 (Hansard, page 1519) in relation to the weakness of section 26AAA of the Income Tax Assessment Act, is he now able to confirm that (a) a $16.5m tax-free profit was made by the Bell group of companies for its sale of shares in Elder Smith Goldsborough Mort Ltd, and that this transaction reveals a weakness in this section of the Act; (b) in November of 1979 the Bell group made a similar tax-free profit of $11m by selling a subsidiary company, Bell Air Charter, which has purchased shares in Ansett Transport Industries Ltd for the Bell group during a takeover attempt and (c) in August 1980 the Bond group used a similar device to make a tax-free profit of $32m by selling a subsidiary, Narla prospecting company, which had purchased shares in the White Industries organisation.
(2) Was he aware of these manipulations of the Act to avoid taxation; if so, should earlier action have been taken to block this blatant tax avoidance.
(3) Will he give an assurance that appropriate action will be taken to strengethen the appropriate provisions of the Act and that this action will be made retrospective.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) As I mentioned in my reply to the honourable member's question of 9 April 1981 concerning this matter, I cannot precisely affirm or deny a particular tax position of an individual taxpayer. That is because the secrecy provisions of the income tax law prevent the Commissioner of Taxation from disclosing information about the affairs of any taxpayer.

(3) As I also said in my answer to the honourable member's question of 9 April 1981, I have asked the Commissioner of Taxation to examine the question of possible weakness in section 26AAA of the Income Tax Assessment Act. The matter isby no means free of complexity but I expect to receive the Commissioner's advice soon.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 5 May 1981:

(2) Will unemployed meatworkers be eligible for (a) retraining under the NEAT Scheme and (b) the Relocation Assistance Allowance given the current recession and the uncertain future in the meat processing industry throughout Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) (a) and (b) Yes. Subject to their meeting the normal criteria for those programs.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Sale of Publicly-owned Enterprises in Australian Capital Territory

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 6 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What gift duty or tax will be payable on the sale of publicly-owned enterprises and facilities in the Australian Capital Territory.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Gift Duty Act 1941 now has no application except in respect of gifts made before 1 July 1979.
Liability for stamp duty depends upon the nature of a transaction including, in respect of the proposed sales referred to, any conditions of sale which may be fixed by the Parliament.
Section 6 of the Australian Capital Territory Stamp Duty Act 1969 provides, however, for exemption from stamp duty of conveyances by or in the name of the Commonwealth.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 6 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did he say in his Press release No. 132 of 25 September 1980, that the Government was going to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act in relation to paragraph 26 (e) relating to the taxing of subsidised rentals; if so, when does he expect to introduce the legislation.
(2) Will the coastal towns of the Pilbara Region, Western Australia, be covered by the amended legislation or will they have to rely on an amendment to section 26AAA of the Act.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government remains committed to an amendment of the income tax law as outlined in my statement of 25 September 1980 and in my further statement of 13 October in which I indicated that the amendment would apply from the beginning of the 1977-78 income year. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hawke Mr R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 13 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does he regard as appropriate the statements contained in the 1979-80 Annual Report of the Department of Productivity that occupational safety and health is an area of considerable concern to the Department and that the social and economic cost of industrial accidents is known to be massive.

(2) Will he outline the reasons underlying the decision of the Committee for the Review of Commonwealth Functions to abolish two national committees operating in the area of occupational safety and health.
(3) Does he intend that the policing of such an important area of employee welfare should be left in the hands of employers in the private sector.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The social and economic cost of industrial accidents is know to be massive, and the Government will play its part in efforts to reduce this toll.

(2) The Committee for the Review of Commonwealth Functions was charged with reviewing functions to determine which properly belonged to the Commonwealth and which might more appropriately be handled elsewhere. Its recommendation to scale down activities in the subject area and transfer residual activities to the Department of Industrial Relations was agreed by Government. The Minister for Industrial Relations will be considering how best to handle the work of the two committees that are to be abolished.

(3) The responsibility for administering safety and health legislation applying to the workforce rests with the States. The Government will be anxious to co-operate with them in this important area of employee welfare.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Social Security: Reviews of Pension and Benefit Entitlements

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 13 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Minister say in reply to my question No. 750 (Hansard, 2 April 1981, page 1339) that reviews of pension and benefit entitlements in other countries are not carried out by field officers but are carried out by mail.
(2) If so, is the form of this review similar to what is known in Australia as a P.E.R. Review.

(3) Is the Minister satisfied that this is an adequate way of checking on pension and benefit entitlements, given that under the Social Services Act persons in Australia in receipt of pensions must subject themselves to the scrutiny of Social Security field officers in order to satisfy certain eligibility requirements.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In reply to Question No. 750 of 10 March 1981 (Hansard, 2 April 1981, page 1339) I said that reviews of pensions payable overseas are generally carried out by mail.

(2) The review known as the P.E.R. review is carried out in respect of pensions payable overseas other than those payable through the Geneva office. In that office a local program similar to the P.E.R. is undertaken. In addition to the scheduled reviews other reviews may be undertaken as and when the need arises.

(3) The Department of Social Security does not have field officers overseas and it does not have staff located in every country where pensions and benefits are payable. The review of pensions payable overseas does, therefore, present problems which do not arise in Australia. However, every effort is taken to ensure that pensioners and beneficiaries living overseas continue to meet the eligibility conditions as laid down in the Social Services Act.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 13 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Do Honours and Masters Qualifying degrees fall within the category of recognised double degree or combination courses, as referred to in the Review of Commonwealth Functions in connection with tertiary tuition fees (Hansard, 30 April 1981, page 1843).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Honours years or Master's qualifying years are undertaken as parts of or as extensions to undergraduate courses and therefore where students undertake these studies in relation to first qualifications they will be exempt from the payment of tuition fees.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 14 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What items will be classed as certain new plant and equipment for the purposes of the reduced investment allowances referred to in attachment F to the Prime Minister's statement on the Review of Commonwealth Functions.
(2) What will be the cost of this change to primary producers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The classification includes all new plant and equipment to which the investment allowance applies. Broadly, the investment allowance applies to plant or articles within the meaning of the depreciation provisions of the income tax law, subject to specifically identified inclusions and exclusions.

The reduced investment allowance rate of 18 per cent will generally apply in respect of expenditure incurred after 30 April 1981 on the acquisition or construction of an eligible unit of property. However, the former rate of 20 per cent will continue to apply where the expenditure is incurred under a contract entered into on or before 30 April 1981, or is incurred in respect of the construction of an eligible unit of property by the taxpayer the construction of which commenced on or before that date.
(2) The increase in income tax payable by primary producers as a result of the proposed reduction in investment allowance is estimated at about $7m in a full year.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 14 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What have been the savings to (a) consumers and (b) primary industry as a result of inquiries by the Prices Justification Tribunal in respect of (i) stevedoring, (ii) spare parts, (iii) fuel and (iv) wool broking.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: A number of PJT inquiries including those into stevedoring, spare parts, petroleum products and wool broking found that prices charged by the companies, or some of the companies, concerned were higher than justified or that proposed price increases were not wholly justified.

In some of those inquiries the PJT determined precisely the justified prices for particular products, but in other cases it indicated the order of price reduction warranted or simply invited companies to review their mark-ups in particular areas of activity.

In the case of petroleum products the oil companies at times have been unable to obtain in particular localities, because of market conditions, not only the prices they had proposed to the PJT but the prices found justified by the PJT.

In view of these and other considerations it is not possible to quantify the savings that may have flowed to consumers or to primary industry as a result of companies' complying with the PJT's findings. Savings to consumers that may have resulted from particular PJT inquiries need to be weighed, against the cost of the PJT's operations, including the direct cost to the Budget, the cost to business in complying with PJT procedures and the wider effects of price regulation on business investment and the market place.
