QUESTION.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 27 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is there a special category of entrepreneurs who gain easier entry into Australia.

(2) If so, (a) what are the required qualifications regarding the financial status of these persons and (b) is it necessary for these persons to have a minimum of $200,000 for investment in Australia.

(3) Was he consulted by the (a) Minister for Health, (b) Minister for Social Security or (c) Prime Minister before entrepreneurs were included in the list of disadvantaged persons eligible for free hospital and medical treatment for six months after arrival in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Provision does exist for the entry of entrepreneurs who will establish and take an active part in running enterprises which will benefit Australia. The benefit may take the form of introducing new technology, improving exports or increasing employment. Persons who enter under these provisions must satisfy the normal character, health and settlement requirements for migration. Entrepreneurs are exempt from reaching a pass score in the economic factors section of NUMAS, Australia's Numerical Migrant Selection System, as the rules governing the appropriate levels of capital and income required for eligibility are sufficient to guarantee economic viability in Australia.

(2) (a) and (b) There are no fixed or minimum financial requirements for entrepreneurs. Entrepreneurs must possess sufficient personal and unencumbered capital to establish the enterprise proposed in their application successfully. The actual amount will depend on the nature and magnitude of the enterprise.
(3) The decision to provide medical and hospital cover for migrants for the first six months in Australia was taken following completion of the usual consultative arrangements.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Veterans' Affairs: Medical Arrangements

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 9 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is there dissatisfaction within the Victorian section of the Department of Veterans' Affairs, in particular, with the medical arrangements.
(2) If so, has the Minister examined the reasons for these complaints which have been detailed by the RSL State President, Mr Bruce Ruxton.
(3) Is there any substance to the complaints: is so, what action has been taken to eliminate the causes for complaint.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am not aware of any general dissatisfaction within the medical arrangements in the Victorian Branch of my Department. However, there has been criticisms of some individual medical opinions given by Department Medical Officers by the Victorian State Executive of the Returned Services League of Australia.

(3) The criticisms are based on a very few selected cases and any general criticism on this basis appear to be unwarranted. On the rare occasion where a complaint is found to be justified the medical officer concerned has been counselled; however in other cases no justification can be found for the complaints.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 May 1981 (Hansard, page 2742) Mr Donald Cameron asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs been drawn to reports that the Maltese Government is considering bulldozing a war cemetery for the purpose of constructing a housing estate? Is the Minister aware that that cemetery contains the remains of several Australian servicemen? Will the Minister give consideration to an Australian Arlington? Will the Minister cause a costing to be done to ascertain how much money would be needed to transfer home the remains of all of Australia's sons and daughters in war cemeteries overseas? In the interim, will the Minister protest to the Maltese Government about this possible desecration?
The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
I am aware of the recent reports in the media that the Maltese Government wants to bulldoze the graves of Commonwealth war dead in Malta. The reports are incorrect.

The Commonwealth War Graves Commission in England, of which Australia and other Commonwealth countries are corporate members, is responsible for the Commonwealth war graves throughout the world, including those in Malta. There are also war graves of nine foreign countries and some 5,000 non-war British burials in the Malta cemeteries.

In 1979, the Maltese Government asked the British to remove the remains of the 7,303 buried in the Capuccini, Pembroke and Pieta cemeteries, and concentrate them in the Mtarfa cemetery where there are 1,440 graves. 200 Australian graves are involved. Considerable extra land would need to be provided at Mtarfa and the cost would run into some millions of dollars.

Australia and the other Commonwealth countries are opposed to the proposed move of the graves except if it can be shown (and it has not so far been done by the Maltese Government) that there was such an overriding and urgent public need for the land to be used for other essential purposes as to justify disturbance of the graves. Australia has been kept fully informed on the negotiations which have been going on with the Maltese Government since the original request was made in 1979. The Commonwealth War Graves Commission has received many requests from relatives to transfer the remains of war dead to their home country. However, the Commission's policy, which was established after the First World War and reaffirmed after the Second World War, is that the graves should not be disturbed except on the grounds of overriding public interest. Agreements have been negotiated with many Foreign Governments on these lines. The Commission is bound to adhere to this policy which was laid down by its Participating Governments, including Australia.

A detailed costing of the transfer of the war graves of all Australian veterans back to Australia and the establishment of a National Cemetery for this purpose, would not be practical or productive in view of the Commonwealth War Graves Commission's policy. There are Australian war graves in over 2,500 cemeteries throughout the World and it is possible that a very large proportion of the relatives of the war dead would strongly object to the disturbance of the remains. All Australian war dead are commemorated in the Australian War Memorial in Canberra. The Australian Government has also established and maintains Gardens of Remembrance in most of the capital cities for the commemoration of those veterans whose deaths were war-related and who are not officially commemorated in civil cemeteries.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 24 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a form letter from the Marketing Manager of the State Government Insurance Office (Qld) referring to the 1981 Budget announcement on superannuation provisions and advising that from discussions with the Taxation Office it seemed that the new amendment would exclude employees drawing a retiring allowance of up to a year's salary or a limited pension in place of superannuation.
(2) If so, will he clarify who is and who is not entitled to tax deductibility and remove any anomalies.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) Under section 82AAT of the Income Tax Assessment Act a person may be allowed a deduction, up to a limit of $1,200 in an income year, for contributions made in the year to a superannuation fund approved by the Commissioner of Taxation under paragraph 23 (ja) or section 79 of the Act. The deduction is not available where, in relation to the person's service in that year, it could resonably be expected that superannuation benefits would be provided on his or her retirement (or for his or her dependants in the event of death) under an employer-sponsored superannuation fund or statutory superannuation scheme referred to in the legislation.

It is not clear from the form letter referred to whether, and to what extent, the persons referred to would be eligible for the deduction, but the Commissioner of Taxation would provide advice to persons concerned once the relevant facts were placed before him.

(2) Is it also a fact that given the recent inflows of portfolio and investment capital, these holdings, and similar holdings in, for example, Conzinc Rio Tinto Australia and Pan Continental, means that the Australian participation in existing or proposed resource projects has fallen below the specific guidelines for Australian participation in the natural resource sector.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

Stock Exchange data also indicate that as at 5 September 1980 four of the top 10 shareholders in MIM Holdings Limited were nominee companies and that these companies held 11.1 per cent of the issued capital of MIM (excluding that held by ASARCO Incorporated).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 3 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When was the decision made to mint the commemorative koala gold coin.
(2) Was the original estimate of demand for the coin approximately 30,000 and the actual demand for the coin approximately 100,000.
(3) What restrictions were placed by the Royal Australian Mint on the total number of coins to be produced.
(4) Was there a closing date for orders for the coin.
(5) How many coins had been sent as at 1 January 1981.
(6) Who was contracted to deliver the coins.
(7) Were arrangements for delivery of the coins cancelled; if so, why.
(8) Was Interstate Parcel Express Company (IPEC) contracted to deliver the coins; if so, when.
(9) Was there a contract in writing between IPEC and the Royal Australian Mint for delivery of the coins.
(10) When did IPEC take delivery of the coins and on what dates and in what quantities were the coins despatched by IPEC.
(11) Is it a fact that periods of more than one week elapsed between the time the coins were received by IPEC from the Mint and the time IPEC despatched them.

(12) Is it also a fact that on at least one occasion IPEC received a large number of coins for despatch, but did not despatch them and, in due course, returned them to the Mint; if so, (a) what period of time elapsed before IPEC returned the coins and (b) did IPEC offer as a reason for returning the coins that they were experiencing security problems.

(13) When was (a) the Controller of the Mint and (b) he informed (i) of the break-in at IPEC's Melbourne depot and the theft of approximately 40 gold coins and (ii) the loss of approximately 30 gold coins in a consignment despatched on 25 November 1980 for delivery to Brisbane (IPEC Docket No. 118/775).

(14) Was a telephone call by my office to (a) the office of the Controller of the Mint and (b) to his office on 20 January 1981 the first information either the Controller or he received about the loss of this second consignment of 30 gold coins.
(15) When did IPEC inform the Controller of the Mint of the loss of the coins.
(16) Did IPEC inform the Queensland Police or Australian Federal Police of the loss of the second consignment of coins; if so, when.
(17) Are the New South Wales Police, Queensland Police and Australian Federal Police now investigating the loss of the second consignment; if so, what is the result of their investigations.

(18) Did his office receive a request from me for him to release a statement to the media (a) confirming the loss of that consignment, (b) explaining the administrative problems which has caused extensive delays to the despatch of coins to those who had ordered them and (c) assuring people who had already paid for coins as early as September 1980 that they would receive their coins although further delays could be expected.
(19) Did he issue a statement, in view of the concern of many persons who had ordered the coins but had not received them at that stage; if not, why not.
(20) Is he now able to say whether the coins lost in IPEC consignments will be replaced.
(21) Have those persons whose coins are among those now missing been informed of that fact by the Mint.
(22) With whom are the coins insured and what was the value of the coins on current market prices as at (a) 1 January 1981 and (b) 25 February 1981.
(23) What is the total current market price of all the missing gold coins.
(24) Has the Mint replied to written inquiries concerning delays in despatching the coins; if so, to how many.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The decision to mint the commemorative koala coin was announced on 10 July 1979.
(2) The Controller of the Mint has advised me that the planning estimate for gold proof coins was 30,000 and actual demand was approximately 120,000.

(3) The number of gold proof coins produced was effectively limited by the Mint's capacity to produce coins of that type bearing in mind the overall production program. No restriction was placed on the production of the uncirculated coin.
(4) The closing date for gold proof coins was 19 September 1980 and for gold uncirculated coins 12 December 1980.
(5) The Controller of the Mint has advised me that at 1 January 1981 39,192 gold proof coins and 195,247 gold uncirculated coins had been despatched from the Mint.
(6) The Controller of the Mint has advised me that IPEC Pty Ltd and Wards Express were contracted to deliver the gold coins.

(7) The Controller of the Mint has advised me that arrangements to deliver the coins were not cancelled but IPEC withdrew from the contract stating that the delivery of gold coins was not compatible with IPEC's normal business. Wards Express continued to deliver gold coins.
(8) and (9) The Controller of the Mint has advised me that a contract in writing for IPEC to deliver gold coins was signed on 16 October 1980.

(10) The Controller of the Mint has advised me that IPEC took the first delivery of gold coins on 21 October 1980 and continued on a regular basis until the last delivery was taken on 17 December 1980. During this period IPEC received from the Mint 22,238 gold proof coins and 9,067 uncirculated gold coins.
(11) The Controller of the Mint has advised me that there were delays of over one week between IPEC's receipt and delivery of some coin consignments.

(12) The Controller of the Mint has advised me that IPEC returned 6,172 coin consignments to the Mint, 72 because IPEC could not complete delivery and 6,100 when the company withdrew from the contract.
(1) All these consignments were returned on or before 23 December 1980. These consignments were accumulated over approximately one month.
(b) The reason given by IPEC for returning the 6,100 consignments referred to above is provided in (7) above.
(13) (a) The Controller of the Mint has advised me that:
(i) he was informed of the break-in to IPEC's Melbourne depot orally in early November and this was confirmed in writing on 8 December 1980 in a letter from ITLC (IPEC's insurance company), and
(ii) advice on the Brisbane coin loss was received on 20 January 1981.
(b) I was informed (i) of the break-in to IPEC's Melbourne depot on 24 December 1980, and (ii) of the Brisbane coin loss on 22 January 1981.
(14) The Controller of the Mint has advised (a) Yes; and (b) Yes.
(15) The Controller of the Mint has advised me that IPEC informed him of the Brisbane loss on 21 January 1981.
(16) The Controller of the Mint has been advised by IPEC that they reported the Brisbane loss to the Queensland Police on 16 December 1980.

(17) The Controller of the Mint has advised me that the Queensland, New South Wales and Victorian Police are actively engaged in investigating both the Brisbane and Melbourne gold coin losses and at this stage the results of these investigations are confidential to the police forces and IPEC. The involvement of the Australian Federal Police is limited to making enquiries in Canberra on behalf of State police forces.
(19) A statement was not issued as the people whose coins had been confirmed as stolen were to be contacted directly by the Royal Australian Mint.
(20) I have instructed the Mint to issue replacement coins to substantiated claims involving missing consignments.
(21) The Controller of the Mint has advised me that all clients whose coins have been reported by IPEC as missing have been informed, in writing, that their coins will be replaced.

(22) It was a condition of the contracts with the carriers that appropriate insurance arrangements be made by them. The particular insurers concerned are a matter between the carriers and those insurers. The market price for the gold coins varies greatly but a guideline price from the larger coin dealers would be in the vicinity of $600 for the proof coin and about $250 for the uncirculated coin. Those prices apply to both dates.
(23) The Controller of the Mint has advised me that the total current market value for all the gold coins reported as missing is approximately $52,000.

(24) The Controller of the Mint has advised me that all written enquiries to the Mint about delays in despatch of gold coins will be answered. At this stage approximately 7,000 replies have been made.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 10 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to reports in certain sections of the Adelaide press that the Adelaide Airport could soon be handed over to the South Australian Government.
(2) If so, is there any substance in the reports.
(3) Does he propose to take any action on this matter, if so, what.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) There is no substance in the reports with regard to Adelaide Airport in particular other than to observe that the Government is continually reviewing its functions to ensure that there is no unnecessary intrusion into areas more appropriate for administration and control by others including the private sector, State and Local Governments.

The Commonwealth's commitment to ensure an efficient and effective national air transport system, its obligations with regard to international agreements relating to civil aviation, and the need to regulate standards to ensure safety, together with the sheer magnitude of the task of operating a capital city trunk route airport, make it unlikely that ownership and control would be passed to a body other than a State Government, City Council or a State Statutory Body.
(3) No action to transfer any State Capital City Airport is currently in hand and certainly would not be contemplated without fullest consultation with relevant State Governments.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 10 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the concern being expressed by residents of Adelaide, South Australia, over the continuous and persistent noise of aircraft utilising Adelaide Airport; if so, (a) will he establish permanent noise monitoring facilities at a suitable location adjacent to or near the end of runways 05 and 23 at Adelaide Airport and (b) make periodical reports of these facilities.
(2) If he will not undertake to do so, what is the reason.

(3) Has his attention been drawn to the number of public meetings held by residents living adjacent to Adelaide Airport who have consistently supported the proposal that an immediate start be made to the establishment of an alternative airport at a more suitable site north of Adelaide, thereby enabling more efficient operation of airlines and obviating inconvenience to residents in the area.
(4) Has he a proposal to establish an airport north of Adelaide; if so, what are the details.
(5) Has he had discussions with the Government of South Australia; if so, what was the nature of the discussions.
(6) Will he set up a committee to investigate the siting of an alternative airport to the current Adelaide Airport.

(7) Will he give an assurance that (a) the current curfew will be maintained at Adelaide Airport and will not be broken except in the case of emergency, (b) there will be no extensions of the current airport beyond its existing boundaries and (c) the introduction of quieter aircraft and the implementation of aircraft control for quieter aircraft movement will be expedited.
(8) Is action proposed to subsidise overseas travellers for the cost of inter-State connecting flights; if so, what are the details.
(9) Will he ensure that Defence Service aircraft will not be permitted to use the Adelaide Airport unless there is some urgent reason which makes use essential.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The information that would be obtained from a permanent noise monitoring facility at Adelaide Airport would not justify the cost of an installation, particularly since the noise levels of aircraft operating in Australia are known.
(3) Yes. I understand that there are a number of residents' groups from areas under the flight paths associated with Adelaide Airport who are pressing for its relocation.

(5) and (6) In December 1980 I met with the South Australian Minister of Transport. Among other things we agreed to set up a South Australian Airfields Committee comprising both Commonwealth and State officials. The task of this Committee will include oversighting the implementation of agreed recommendations of the Joint Government Advisory Committee on Adelaide's Airline-Airport Requirements. Two important points made by that Committee were:

the Commonwealth and State Governments should adopt policies to retain and develop the existing Adelaide Airport as the primary regular public transport airport for the Adelaide region through to the year 2005
for the longer term aviation needs of the region action should be taken to secure the availability of an alternative major airport site in the Two Wells/Virginia area.

(7) (a) At this time, there are no plans to change the curfew at Adelaide Airport. The existing curfew conditions permit operations by jet aircraft in circumstances other than an emergency; for example, for extreme passenger hardship. It is my intention that this provision continue.
(b) There are currently no proposals to extend the airport beyond its existing boundaries.

(c) It is a requirement that all Australian-registered jet aircraft operating, or expected to operate, at Adelaide Airport meet, or will meet, the noise certification standards of the International Civil Aviation Organisation.

(8) No. Intending international travellers to and from Adelaide may take advantage of Australian-originating 'add-on' fares and 'See-Australia' fares. These fares were introduced in 1979 to extend the benefits travelling to and from non-gateway ports. The Australian-originating 'add-on' fares offer a 30 per cent discount off the normal economy fare for domestic travel in conjunction with advance purchase international air travel. The 'See-Australia' fares are available for travel within Australia in conjunction with international promotional fares such as apex or excursion fares at 30 per cent discount off the normal economy fare.

(9) Operations by Department of Defence aircraft at Adelaide Airport are carried out from time to time in order to ensure the most economic use of resources and to enhance efficiency. It is not proposed to embargo use of Adelaide Airport by military aircraft.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Cost of Epidemiological Study of Vietnam Veterans

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 1 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the total estimated cost of the Commonwealth Institute of Health epidemiological study of Vietnam veterans, as at 31 March 1981, and what is the period for which this estimate has been made.
(2) Does this estimate represent a ten-fold increase in cost over earlier estimates.
(3) If the estimated cost has increased, what is the reason for the increase.

(4) Has the Commonwealth Institute of Health identified a control group for the epidemiological study, as at 31 March 1981, if so, (a) what is the size of that control group, (b) in what way are the ages and health profiles of the control group comparable to those of the Vietnam veterans and (c) what steps has the Commonwealth Institute of Health taken to ensure that the control group has not been exposed to chemicals, such as those used in Vietnam whether used by civilians or the military, since the end of hostilities and the spraying program in Vietnam.

(5) Is it a fact that his News Release of 22 March 1981, released in Adelaide, was designed to prepare both the general public and Vietnam veterans for the Government's decision to phase out completely the Commonwealth Institute of Health epidemiological study; if so, will this occur and what other steps is the Government taking to examine and determine the claims of both Vietnam veterans and public servants, who served in Vietnam during the war.
(6) What has been the cost to the Government of the Commonwealth Institute of Health epidemiological study to 31 March 1981.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The estimated cost of the Commonwealth Institute of Health epidemiological study of the Vietnam veterans for the year 1980-81 is $300,000. The original estimate of the total cost of the study was $2m. The eventual total cost will depend on the methodology adopted as a result of the pilot study now in progress.
(b) Age similar to those who served in Vietnam. Health as yet unknown.
(c) Information will be gathered during the course of the study. Appropriate adjustments will be made in analysis if other exposure is detected.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McMahon Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 1 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many persons were on the waiting list for Defence Service Home Loans as at 1 March 1981.
(2) What sum was available for Defence Service Home Loans as at 1 March 1981.
(3) What are the terms of repayment of these loans.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) At 1 March 1981, 2,538 applicants were awaiting settlement of a loan upon the expiration of the waiting period. The loans were due for settlement between March 1981 and December 1981.

(2) New lending is financed mainly from internally generated funds, of which the major element is principal repayments by current borrowers that are received throughout the year. Thus, it is not practicable to nominate a sum available at 1 March 1981 for loans. The Budget estimate of funds to become available for lending in 1980-81 was $111.5 million.

(3) Loans are normally repayable over a maximum term of 32 years by equal monthly instalments. Interest is charged at the rate of 3.75 per cent per annum on the first $12,000 at 7.25 per cent per annum on amounts between $12,001 and $15,000 and at 10 per cent on the amount of the loan exceeding $15,000. The average interest rate on a maximum loan of $25,000 is approximately 6.9 per cent per annum. The normal monthly instalment on a loan of $25,000 is $160.75.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Cost of Abolishing Means Test for Age Pensions

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 8 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the estimated cost at current rates of abolishing (a) the means test for age pensions (i) for women aged 60 to 64 years and (ii) for both sexes aged 65 to 69 years, (b) the partial means test for those persons aged 70 years and over and (c) the means test for service pensioners.
(2) Would approximately one-third of these sums be recovered via the taxation clawback.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) the additional full year cost at the rates current on 8 April of abolishing the income test on age pensions is estimated to be
(i) some $410m for women aged 60 to 64 years; and
(ii) some $390m for men and women aged 65 to 69 years.

(b) the additional full year cost at the rates current on 8 April of abolishing the income testing of pension increases on age pensions for persons aged 70 years and over is estimated to be some $153m.

(c) the Department of Veterans' Affairs has advised that the additional full year cost at the rates current on 8 April of abolishing the income test on current service pensions is estimated to be: $18.1m for those aged 65 to 69 years, $28.7m for those aged 60 to 64 years, $13.1m for those aged 55 to 59 years, and $4.2m for those aged under 55 years.
The additional full year cost of abolishing the income test on pension increases for service pensioners aged 70 years and over is estimated to be $9.7m.

The above figures include the additional cost for male service pensioners and their spouses and also female veterans receiving pensions in their own right. In addition, it is estimated that there are 272,000 surviving veterans (plus 201,300 wives) who have not yet tested their eligibility for service pension. Of this group, it is estimated that 30,000 have already reached age pension age and are included in 1(a). A further 188,000 have not yet reached the qualifying age for service pension. The cost of abolishing the income test in respect of the remainder, who would qualify for service pension, that is 54,000 veterans and 39,960 wives, is estimated at $267.3m in a full year.
These estimates are gross costs, as they make no allowance for the revenue that would be gained from taxation of the payments concerned.

(2) The Commissioner of Taxation has advised that the additional income tax that would be payable if the income test were to be abolished in respect of these payments would be almost one-third of the estimated cost.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Telephone Calls by Staff: Department of Business and Consumer Affairs

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a report in the West Australian of 18 July 1979, page 37, that London metropolitan police reduced its telephone bill by $985,000, or about 20 per cent by use of a monitoring device which recorded length, time and destination of telephone calls and the extension from which the call was made.
(2) Are personal telephone calls, particularly trunk and STD calls, made by staff of his Department controlled; if so, in what way.
(3) Has any consideration been given to the introduction of monitoring devices for telephone calls in his Department; if so, what was the outcome of the consideration.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) Yes. In State offices (other than Western Australia) all extensions except those of senior officers are barred to STD. In the Fremantle office, technical difficulties prevent the barring of extensions to STD, whilst in Perth subscription to the PABX rests with Department of Veterans' Affairs which has been advised that there are no objections to total barring.

In Central Office very few extensions are barred to STD. Personal trunk calls are required to be booked through the departmental switchboard operator. Prior to booking the call the caller must obtain approval from the accountant. The switchboard operator will then place the booking through the trunks operator. After the call, the cost is obtained and a voucher forwarded to the accountant who then debits the caller with the cost of the call. See also (3) below.

(3) Yes. The Department of Business and Consumer Affairs in Canberra is the subscriber to a multi user telephone exchange. It is arranging the installation of extension metering equipment which, when connected, will allow better monitoring by providing information on an individual departmental user basis. In addition, new telephone technology, such as a Stored Programme Control (SPC) PABX, is currently under active consideration by the Department.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the article which appeared in the Age of Saturday 4 April 1981, in which he was reported as having said that it was doubtful that the $75m allocated as additional funds for developing urban public transport by the Government would be distributed, in view of the need to restrain Commonwealth budgetary outlay.
(2) If so, is there any substance to the report.
(3) If the report is correct, were these additional funds to be allocated as part of the Government's election program.
(4) Is there any substance to the claim that Victoria will now lose $22.5m of the additional funds which could have been used to build more trams and trains.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2), (3) and (4) Following the recent Review of Commonwealth Functions, the Commonwealth has decided to discontinue specific purpose grants to the States for urban public transport after 30 June 1981. At the Premiers' Conference on 4 May 1981, the Commonwealth announced that the States' overall entitlements for 1981-82 under the tax sharing arrangements would include a specific adjustment to take account of the termination of a number of specific purpose payments, including $50m for urban public transport.

Whereas the urban public transport program was due to expire in 1982-83, the $50m incremental adjustment to the 1981-82 tax sharing arrangements now forms part of the base for the calculation of total tax sharing entitlements in future years. The new arrangements allow each State to determine how much will be allocated for urban public transport in light of its own assessment of relative State priorities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 29 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the Australian insurance industry's underwriting loss of $73m in 1978-79 and a prediction by the Federal Insurance Commissioner, Mr Kirkpatrick, of a loss exceeding $100m in 1979-80.
(2) What were the non-underwriting profits of the industry during those years.
(3) Is he concerned about the industry's ability to meet its commitments.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The underwriting loss of $73m referred to by the honourable member was incurred by private sector direct underwriters for the calendar year 1979. The underwriting loss for the year 1978-79 was approximately $38m. I am aware of the comment made by the Insurance Commissioner that a predicted $100m underwriting loss for the year ended 30 June 1980 was conservative. Actual figures now available for this period show that private sector direct underwriters incurred underwriting losses totalling approximately $151m.
(2) For the 1978-79 and 1979-80 financial years non-underwriting profits for private sector direct underwriters were approximately $254m and $316m respectively.

(3) It is well known that a very competitive situation has existed in the industry for some time, with resulting pressure on underwriting results, and the industry is having to cope with other factors adversely affecting these results. However I am aware of no reason to suggest that the industry does not have the overall financial strength to meet its obligations. It might be noted that, on the basis of data compiled by the Insurance Commissioner, in the two years 1978-79 and 1979-80 net profit from the insurance business of private sector direct underwriters totalled $317m. I would also draw the honourable member's attention to pages 18 and 19 of the Insurance Commissioner's Annual Report for 1979-80 which indicate that in recent years up to 1978-79 (the latest year for which this information is available) there has been continued overall improvement in the assessed solvency margins of direct underwriters in the private sector.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 30 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that import duty on spare parts is making the cost of repairing many machines an uneconomical practice.
(2) Is the gear-box assembly of a Robin Brush Cutter subjected to full import duty whereas the machine itself has little or no duty placed on it; if so, what is the reason for this.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In the absence of detailed descriptions of the machines and specific parts to which the question refers, it is not possible to answer this question.

(2) Based on information available to the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs, a Robin Brush Cutter, imported as a complete entity, would be classified within item 84.49 of the Customs Tariff, and would be dutiable at 2 per cent. However, a gear-box for the cutter, if imported separately, would be classified within item 84.63.69 and would be subject to duty at rates ranging from 7.5 per cent to 25 per cent depending on the country of origin of the gear-box.

Entry of a gear-box at a concessional rate of 2 per cent may be appropriate under the Customs By-law system. This would need to be discussed with the By-law Branch of the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 5 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the (a) number and (b) total sums of rural loan approvals to fishermen which were refinanced by the Primary Industry Bank in 1980.
(2) Did he state in December 1980 that increases in bank overdraft interest rates would not apply in drought areas; if so, will fishermen be exempted from the recent increases.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Primary Industry Bank of Australia has advised that it approved refinance loans in respect of 17 end-borrowers in the fishing industry during calendar year 1980 to a total value of $1.6m.
(2) The facts of the understanding reached with the banks in December 1980 in relation to bank interest rates in drought-declared areas are:

rises in interest rates following the raising of the official ceiling on small bank advances effective from 3 December 1980 will not apply to those adversely affected by drought in drought-declared areas for the duration of the drought;
those affected in drought areas may include people other than primary producers;
the interest rate concession will be administered by banks on a case-by-case basis on application by individual borrowers to the respective banks;
the arrangements will apply to interest rates on both new and existing loans.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hurford Mr C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 5 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to his answer to part (4) of my question No. 725 (Hansard, 29 April 1981, page 1775) what reasons did the Trade Practices Commission give for threatening to take proceedings for a contravention of section 50 of the Trade Practices Act in respect of the attempted takeover of the Herald and Weekly Times Group by News Limited.

(2) Has his attention been drawn to statements issued at the time of the attempted takeover referred to in part (1) on behalf of the News Limited group making it clear that the group was not dropping its takeover bid because of proposed action by the Trade Practices Commission and that the group did not consider itself to be in breach of section 50 of the Trade Practices Act.

(3) How would the present set of merger criteria detailed in the Act have prevented News Limited from taking over the State operations, includingVictoria, of the Herald and Weekly Times Group where the takeover of that State operation would not give News Limited control or dominance in that market or increase News Limited's control or dominance in that market.

(4) Is he able to say whether it is because of the inability of the post-1977 provisions of the Trade Practices Act to regulate the type of control referred to in part (3), that the Victorian State Government set up its current inquiry into that State's newspaper industry.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In a media release dated 30 November 1979 the Trade Practices Commission stated it had been prepared to take proceedings against News Limited because its proposal to acquire marginally more than 50 per cent of the shares in Herald and Weekly Times Limited would have given it control of that company and consequently one-company dominance in a number of markets.

(2) I am not aware of statements of the kind referred to in the question and a search by my Department of the press clippings it has relating to the attempted takeover did not, I understand, reveal reference to such statements in the press reports. I am informed, however, that News Limited issued a statement on 22 November 1979 which said, in part ''Mr Rupert Murdoch, chief executive of the News group of companies, today announced that in view of events in the last 48 hours, including the unwarranted intervention of the Trade Practices Commission, the News group at this time does not intend to make an offer to all the ordinary shareholders of Herald and Weekly Times Ltd to acquire marginally in excess of 50 per cent of the issued ordinary capital of that company.''.

(4) I am unable to comment on the reasons of the Victorian State Government in deciding to set up the inquiry referred to, other than to note that the Victorian Premier was reported as saying, at the time the inquiry was announced, that the inquiry had not been prompted by the News Limited/Herald and Weekly Times takeover bid.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 6 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has a leaflet entitled 'Perth Airport Western Australia' been distributed by his Department in association with its invitation for public comment on proposed changes to Perth Airport, Western Australia.

(2) If so, is there a claim on page 2 of the leaflet that the Joint Governments' Advisory Committee recommended that Perth Airport be retained and further developed as the sole primary airport for the Perth region.

(3) Did the whole recommendation of the Joint Committee deal with the period 1975-2004 and in fact recommend that Perth Airport be retained and further developed as the sole primary airport for the Perth region and that the Perth Airport master plan be published as soon as practicable and that the master plan should be based on a detailed analysis of airport development options and their impact on the environment and land use.
(4) If so, why was the whole recommendation and the specified time period not put before the general public.
(5) Does the Joint Government Committee's report qualify the statement ''further developed'' in its recommendation by reference to a master plan that has not yet been published.
(6) If so, why is the Government proceeding with a major development in advance of production of a master plan.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (4) The leaflet was published to inform the public of development proposals at Perth Airport and seek comments, particularly on environmental issues. Extracts of the Joint Government Committee recommendation relevant to this purpose were included in the pamphlet. The public has previously been informed of the recommendations of the Committee in a press release in August 1979 and its 'Report on the Aviation Requirements for the Perth Region' which has been made available to the public through the Australian Government Publishing Service.

(5) Not directly. However, it is appreciated that forward planning must precede major development whenever possible, and planning studies are being undertaken in order to determine appropriate sites for development projects on Perth Airport.

It is not anticipated that the findings of the master plan will necessitate a reversal of the decision on the location of the new international terminal complex.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Pollution of the Sea by Oil

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 12 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Assembly of the Inter-Governmental Maritime Consultative Organisation in 1971 adopt an amendment to the International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution of the Sea by Oil, 1954, aimed at providing special protection for the Great Barrier Reef area by regarding the area as if it were a part of the land.

(2) Has this amendment been ratified by 25 IMCO Members, including Canada, France, New Zealand, The Philippines and the USSR in the Pacific, but does it need 42 ratifications for its entry into force,

(3) Have approaches been made by Australia to (a) the United States of America, (b) Japan, (c) the People's Republic of China, (d) other members of ASEAN, (e) other members of the South Pacific Forum or (f) any South American countries to secure at least 42 ratifications; if so, on what occasions and with what responses.
(4) What steps has Australia taken to ratify the amendment.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The amendment has been ratified by 25 IMCO Members including Canada, France, New Zealand, The Philippines and the USSR as notified by IMCO at 10 March 1981. A total of 44 ratifications are required to bring the amendment into force.

(3) No approaches have been made to other countries with a view to securing at least 44 ratifications. It would be inappropriate for Australia to suggest ratification of the amendment to other countries until it has completed its own processes towards acceptance of the amendments.

(4) The Protection of the Sea (Discharge of Oil from Ships) Act 1981 which received the Royal Assent on 14 April 1981 will enable Australia to ratify the Convention. Those sections of the Act relating to the Great Barrier Reef amendment will be proclaimed when the amendment comes into force.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 13 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are sniffer dogs now used by Customs Officers at all international gateways into Australia for the purpose of drug detection.
(2) If so, for how long have the dogs been used.
(3) What success has been achieved by this process.
(4) Has there been an appreciable increase in the volume of narcotics detected by using these dogs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Narcotic drug detector dogs are located at all capital cities with the exception of Hobart. Dogs and handlers from Melbourne are used in Hobart for specific operations until dogs and handlers presently being trained for location at Hobart finish their training.
(2) Dogs were first introduced as follows: Sydney-September 1976; Melbourne-September 1978; Brisbane-December 1979; Adelaide-December 1979; Perth-March 1980; Darwin-November 1980.
(3) Dogs have been used in exercises which have resulted in 311 separate seizures of narcotic drugs. These seizures include separate consignments of:
10.5 kg Heroin at Sydney International Airport,
100.7 kg Marihuana at Sydney International Airport,
90 kg Hashish at Sydney International Airport,

(4) It is not yet possible to detect any appreciable change in the pattern of drug seizures which could be solely attributed to the use of dogs. The Detector Dog Unit is an integral part of the total Customs effort and provides Customs officers with an additional effective method of detecting drugs illegally entering Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veteran's Affairs, upon notice, on 14 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the article 'Agent Orange and the Repatriation Commission' at pages 103 to 117 of Debrief, February-April 1981.

(2) If so, does the author allege suppression by the head of the Department of Veterans' Affairs of information, including a report by Dr Fleming relevant to determinations of claims on the Repatriation Commission by veterans in respect of war-caused disability associated with exposure to herbicides.

(3) Will the Minister (a) have tabled in the House documents provided to the Government by herbicide manufacturing interests and (b) direct that all relevant expert opinions in the possession of the Department of Veterans' Affairs be provided to the Commission and Boards in accordance with sections 24AB, 47 and 48 of the Repatriation Act.

(4) Will action be taken against any person who appears, prima facie, to have breached sections 34 (b), 42, 43 or 86 of the Crimes Act in relation to the judicial functions of the Commission; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) An unidentified author alleges in the article that the Permanent Head of the Department of Veterans' Affairs has refused to have evidence of pesticides summarised and placed on files on pesticide claims, and that as a consequence, medical practitioners have insufficient information to give an informed and balanced opinion on the possibility of disability claims being attributed to pesticide poisoning. The author also alleges that the Department of Veterans' Affairs has refused to release a report said to have been prepared for the Department by Dr Keith Fleming.

The facts are that the Department has been gathering information on the long-term effects of herbicides on human health since well before December 1979 when the herbicides controversy arose in Australia and has been circulating this information throughout the Repatriation system.

The so called 'report' by Dr Fleming is a compilation of extracts from scientific and other articles which were obtained from Mr John Evans of Melbourne, an adviser to the Vietnam Veterans Association, and which, in his opinion, supported the Association's claims. Subsequent independent evaluation of the compilation indicated that the compilation did not present an adequate up-to-date and comprehensive coverage of the scientific literature on the subject.

However, copies of the full texts of the reports and articles quoted by Mr John Evans together with a number of other scientific reports have been distributed to Departmental Medical Officers dealing with claims of health effects from contact with toxic chemicals in Vietnam.
(3) (a) A search has revealed that the Department has received the following papers from what is referred to as herbicide manufacturing interests:
(i) A copy of a paper presented to the United Services Club in Brisbane on 19 March 1980 by the Queensland Manager of Nufarm Chemicals which is entitled 'Do You Want Three Feeds a Day?'

(ii) A copy of a paper presented to the Pesticides Science Group by the Chairman of the South Australian Division of the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Association of Australia on 16 March 1981.

(iii) A letter dated 30 April 1980, addressed to my predecessor, the Hon. A. E. Adermann, M.P., from I.C.I. Australia Limited to which was attached a one page summary concerning the toxicology of the herbicides ''Gramoxone'' and ''Reglone''.

(iv) A letter dated 23 February 1981, addressed to me from the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Association of Australia to which was attached a booklet entitled 'Public Concerns About 2,4,5-T' by W. R. Mullison, Ph.D.
This material is available and could be tabled if required.

(d) My Department seeks to ensure that all relevant scientific evidence is taken into account by Departmental Medical Officers when giving opinions under the terms of section 48 of the Repatriation Act, by providing them with copies of published articles dealing with the possible toxic effects of herbicides and other toxic chemicals. Repatriation Boards and delegates of the Commission are well aware and have been reminded that all of this material is available to them whenever they think it could be relevant to a particular claim.
(4) No person appears to have breached the various provisions of the Crimes Act referred to.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hurford Mr C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 28 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many apprentices are presently employed by the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo, Victoria.

(2) Will the Government ensure that the current level of apprenticeship training at the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo, will be maintained following its sale to private enterprise (Hansard, 30 April 1981, page 1846); if so, how will this be achieved.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lynch The Rt Hon Sir P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) One hundred and four. There are also 21 other apprentices at the factory who are being sponsored by industry and are receiving their basic trade training under the Group One-Year Apprentice Scheme.

(2) It is the Government's aim to ensure the continued operation of the factory, and the Government is of the view that in the hands of a private owner activity in the factory in support of large scale mineral and industrial developments could be expanded, so providing continuing employment and training opportunities. The Government cannot give a guarantee at this stage as to the level of apprenticeship training which will be provided as this would be a matter for the owner. Government incentives generally available to industry to train apprentices would of course be available to a private-sector owner.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Legal Assistance for Persons Charged with Criminal Offences

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 26 November 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does article 14 of the 1966 International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which Australia signed in December 1972 and ratified in August 1980, guarantee that everyone charged with a criminal offence shall be entitled to have adequate time and facilities for the preparation of his defence and to defend himself through legal assistance of his own choosing.

(2) Has the Attorney-General's attention been drawn to the judgment of Justice Murphy in McInnis v. The Queen on 19 December 1979 wherein the view was expressed that the laws and practices of Western Australia do not fulfil these guarantees.

(3) Did the Attorney-General, on 5 August 1980, establish within the Attorney-General's Department the Human Rights Bureau, whose functions are, at the Attorney-General's request, to inquire into any federal infringements of the Covenant and, at the Attorney-General's direction, to discuss relevant human rights issues with State authorities.

(4) If so, has the Attorney-General (a) requested the Bureau to inquire into federal laws and (b) directed the Bureau to discuss with Western Australia the State laws on legal assistance for persons charged with criminal offences.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answers to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Sub-Article 14(3) of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights provides:
'3. In the determination of any criminal charge against him, everyone shall be entitled to the following minimum guarantees, in full equality:
(b) To have adequate time and facilities for the preparation of his defence and to communicate with counsel of his choosing;

(c) To be tried in his presence, and to defend himself in person or through legal assistance of his choosing; to be informed, if he does not have legal assistance, of this right; and to have legal assistance assigned to him, in any case where the interests of justice so require, and without payment by him in any such case if he does not have sufficient means to pay for it . . .'
(2) I am aware of the judgment of Mr Justice Murphy.

(3) I did, on 5 August 1980, establish the Human Rights Bureau with functions, inter alia, of inquiring into and reporting to me in relation to complaints referred by me to the Bureau whether any act or practice under a law of the Commonwealth or a Territory infringes human rights as defined in the Covenant, and under my direction of continuing discussions with appropriate State authorities about co-operative arrangements and relevant issues in the human rights field.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 26 November 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to the Attorney-General's answer to Question No. 5321 (Hansard, 21 April 1980, page 2045), will legislative action be taken by the Government on the following Australian Law Reform Commission Reports: (a) Complaints Against the Police (First Report presented 7 August 1975, Supplementary Report presented 9 June 1978), (b) Criminal Investigation (8 November 1979), (c) Insolvency: The Regular Payment of Debts (4 November 1977), (d) Unfair Publication: Defamation and Privacy (29 December 1978), (e) Privacy and the Census (26 September 1979) and (f) Lands Acquisition and Compensation (12 March 1980); if so, when in each case.
(2) If no legislative action is planned, is other action planned in each case; if so, what.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has supplied the following answers to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The present position in relation to each of the reports listed in the question is as follows:
(a) The Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Act 1981 was assented to on 9 April 1981 but has not yet been proclaimed to commence.

(b) As I informed the Senate on 5 March 1981 (Senate Hansard, page 354), a further draft of the Criminal Investigation Bill has been prepared having regard to the comments on and criticisms of the Criminal Investigation Bill 1977. That draft Bill is now being considered.

(c) The Department of Business and Consumer Affairs has held discussions on this Report with interested parties. Consideration is now being given to what legislative, or other, action may be appropriate.
(d) This Report is still being considered within the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General.

(e) I refer the honourable member to the statement tabled in the Parliament by the Treasurer on 10 September 1980 (House of Representatives Hansard, page 1081). The Census and Statistics Amendment Bill 1981 was introduced into the Parliament on 30 April 1981. The main purpose of this Bill was to amend the Census and Statistics Act 1905 to incorporate those Government decisions on the recommendations made by the Law Reform Commission in its report on 'Privacy and the Census' which require legislative action prior to the conduct of the 1981 Population Census. Legislative action to implement the other Government decisions on the Commission's recommendations requiring such action is still under consideration.
(f) This Report is still under consideration within the Government.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 3 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do the terms of reference of the Campbell Inquiry into the financial industry include rationalising the mode of expressing interest rates.

(2) Are interest rates currently expressed according to (a) a flat rate, for simple interest, per annum, (b) a nominal rate per month and (c) an effective rate for compound interest; if so, is there a need for simplifying the mode of expression of interest from the consumer's point of view.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Its terms of reference would encompass such a matter if the Inquiry thought it an issue requiring comment.

(2) Such differences can arise between various categories of financial institutions and different types of deposit or loan. From the consumers' point of view there presumably would be advantage in having sufficient information available to enable accurate comparison between different rates of interest.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Johnson The Hon L.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 4 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Which of the recommendations contained in the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission Annual Report for 1979-80 has the Government (a) accepted and (b) rejected.
(2) What progress has been achieved in the implementation of the recommendations which were accepted.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: With regard to each of the 7 recommendations the position is as follows:

Recommendation No. 1-Statutory Interest on Solicitors' Trust Accounts-In so far as the Australian Capital Territory is concerned the recommendation has not been accepted. The recommendation could not be adopted without prior consultation with banks and the Law Society of the Australian Capital Territory. In so far as the recommendation concerns participating States it has been brought to their attention.

Recommendation No. 2-Estimates of Expenditure-The recommendation as it relates to Commonwealth funding has not been accepted. The recommendation has been brought to the attention of participating States.
Recommendation No. 3-Grants to Voluntary and Community Legal Services-In accordance with the recommendation the Government has established an on-going funding program for these bodies.

Recommendation No. 4-Grants for Migrant Legal Education-I brought this recommendation to the attention of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and officers of his Department have had discussions in relation to the matter with officers of the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission. With the assistance of these officers the Department has prepared orientation information for newly arrived migrants explaining aspects of the law that are likely to be of concern to them.

Recommendation No. 5-Aboriginal Legal Aid-The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs, to which this recommendation was made, did not agree that a national secretariat of Aboriginal legal services should be established-see Chapter 17 of the Committee's Report tabled on 27 August 1980.

Recommendation No. 6-Provision of Legal Advice-In the Australian Capital Territory the recommendation as it relates to the availability of legal advice has not been formally accepted by the Legal Aid Commission as the Commission has always acted generally in accordance with the recommendation. The Commission has not accepted the recommendation as it relates to voluntary and community based services as it considers that the only community based service in the Territory duplicates the legal advice services provided by the Commission. In so far as the recommendations concern participating States it has been brought to their attention.

Recommendation No. 7-Administrative Review Council-In relation to the Australian Capital Territory similar recommendations to those contained in paragraphs (a), (b) and (c) of the recommendation have been made by the Administrative Review Council-see pages 22 and 23 of The Council's Fourth Annual Report tabled on 18 September 1980. The Government has accepted the recommendations of the Council. In so far as these recommendations concern participating States it has been brought to their attention.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Adermann The Hon A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 4 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the special telephone handset available in Australia using a print out enabling totally deaf people to use the telephone.

(2) As the use of the phone necessitates a similar handset at the receiver's end, will he have his Department investigate the possibility of installing at least one receiver in the State Branch of each Commonwealth Department so that the totally deaf might have an access service previously denied to them.
(3) Would this be an appropriate Government initiative for 1981, the International Year of the Disabled Person.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Special telephone handset equipment for the totally deaf called the Porta Printer II has been available to the public through a private company, Intercept Communications, P.O. Box 297, Camberwell, Victoria 3124, priced in the range $800-$1,000. Telecom Australia permitted its connection to the telephone network and, I am advised, some 80 units have been sold to date.

A recent upsurge of demand for the equipment in the United States of America has exhausted supplies, including items earmarked for Australia. Alternative equipment, the Porta Printer Plus, could be available through Intercept Communications by mid 1981. One of these printers has already been leased by Telecom for evaluation and testing for com- patibility with the Porta Printer II. Telecom's intention, as part of its contribution to the International Year of the Disabled Person, is to act as a distributing agent for the unit.

(2) and (3) The Government is concerned to improve the opportunities and access to services of disabled people wherever practicable. Telecom has prepared a booklet, entitled 'International Year of Disabled Persons 1981-Telecom Australia's Program of Activities', which includes information about handsets for the deaf. Several thousand copies have already been distributed, both inside and outside of Telecom, and to relevant Government Departments and Authorities.

The Government currently has under consideration the question of policy on practical steps that Departments should take to assist the disabled. I will advise the honourable member in due course of the outcome with respect to the provision of receivers in Departments that can be accessed by the totally deaf.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Aboriginal Affairs: Transfer of Functions

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 25 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Government planning to distribute some of the functions of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs to any other department or statutory authority.
(2) If so, (a) which functions are to be transferred and (b) to what Department and/or authorities will they be transferred.
(3) When is it intended that the process will be completed.
(4) Has the National Aboriginal Conference been consulted on this matter; if so, what opinion was expressed by it.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) Responsibility for Aboriginal housing grants (other than those to the States) is to be transferred to the Aboriginal Development Commission. States Grants for Aboriginal Housing are to be integrated in the Commonwealth/State Housing Agreement and administered by the Department of Housing and Construction. Funding of the Sacred Sites Protection Authority will be transferred to the Northern Territory Government.

(4) The National Aboriginal Conference was informed of the proposed transfer of Aboriginal housing grants (other than those to the States) to the Aboriginal Development Commission and the Chairman of the Conference indicated last November that his Executive's view was that it would be appropriate for the deadline of 1 July 1981 to be extended to allow the Aboriginal Development Commission more time to consolidate its present functions and to plan future developments. The Minister has informed the NAC that he recognised its concern, and that a joint DAA/ADC Steering Group has been established to ensure that the ADC will have adequate resources to manage the programs to be transferred. This transfer with effect from 1 July 1981 is a firm Government commitment designed to assist Aboriginal people to achieve greater management and determination of their own affairs.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: United States Defense Department Personnel Based in Australia

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 15 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the article headed 'America has 1,000 defence personnel here' published in the Australian of 22 January 1981.
(2) If so, is there any substance to the figures attributed to the United States of America Embassy in that article regarding the numbers of US Defense Department personnel based in Australia.
(3) Is there also any substance to the estimates in that article that there are more than 200 professional staff for commercial defence contractors and the Central Intelligence Agency.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) and (3) Those figures quoted in the article which were provided by the US Embassy in December 1980 concerning US Department of Defense personnel in Australia at that time are accurate.
