QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morrison The Hon W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 26 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the proportion of defence expenditure spent on defence facilities for each year from 1975-76 to 1979-80 and what is the estimated expenditure for 1980-81.
(2) Did the November 1976 White Paper on Defence propose an increase in defence expenditure on defence facilities from 6.2 per cent in 1975-76 to over 7 per cent in 1980-81.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) 1975-76 6.2 per cent; 1976-77 5.6 per cent; 1977-78 4.9 per cent; 1978-79 3.6 per cent; 1979-80 3.2 per cent; 1980-81 3.5 per cent (estimated).

(2) As I have explained to the Parliament on several occasions, the Government's overall economic objectives have required adjustments to the pace of proceeding with the objectives in the 1976 White Paper. Indeed, the 1976 White Paper emphasised that the provisional allocations for Defence Outlay in the period 1976-81 were subject to review and adjustment according to actual timing of project developments, Budget consideration and the circumstances prevailing at the time that major decisions need to be taken. The planning, in the 1976 White Paper, to increase defence expenditure on Defence facilities to over 7 per cent of total Defence expenditure in 1980-81 must be seen in this context.

In addition to the need for general restraint on public expenditure as part of the Government's overall economic strategy, factors such as the timing of decisions on facilities for the Australian Defence Force Academy and the New Tactical Fighter and the need to consider the recommendations of the report 'Accommodation for Married Servicemen', by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure, inevitably affected previously planned achievements.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 25 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did he say in answer to my question No. 273 (Hansard, 4 March 1981, page 442) that Bankcard interest rates which are quoted at 18 per cent per annum, are not compounded daily, and that a true rate of interest of 19.7 per cent per annum does not occur.
(2) If so, what interest would Bankcard charge on a debt of $2,000, if the principal sum to be repaid had not been reduced at the end of a 12 month period.
(3) Would this figure be identical to that which would have been the case if Bankcard had quoted an effective rate of interest on 19.7 per cent per annum.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. In answer to Question No. 273 (Hansard, 4 March 1981) I stated that I had been advised that Bankcard credit charges are not compounded daily, that is, interest is not charged on interest.

(2) The interest charged by Bankcard depends upon whether the debt is generated by a cash advance or a purchase of merchandise. I am advised that if a debt of $2,000 is generated by a cash advance on 1 January and is not reduced over the ensuing twelve month period the interest charged for that period would be $358.98 which is an effective rate of 17.95 per cent per annum. If the debt is generated by a purchase of merchandise the interest charged would vary between $331.78 and $359.39, depending on the length of the interest free period; this is an effective rate varying between 16.59 per cent and 17.97 per cent per annum. It should be noted, however, that these examples assume a departure from the condition upon which a Bankcard is issued, that a card holder may make a payment of at least 5 per cent of the amount owing at the end of each settlement period. If this condition were met the amounts of interest quoted above would be reduced accordingly.

(3) No. However I am advised that if the interest charged were to be compounded daily, which as I have indicated is not the case, it would produce an effective rate of 19.7 per cent per annum. Such a compounding would result in an annual interest charge of $394 compared with the amounts referred to in the answer to the second part of this question. For the sake of completeness let me stress that I am advised that there is no compounding effect of any kind in the computation of Bankcard interest. After an initial credit charge of 1.5 per cent for extending credit on merchandise purchases (which would normally be applied on the second monthly statement in which the balance outstanding in respect of a particular purchase appears) and for cash advances Bankcard interest is computed on reducing principal at daily rests basis. The total interest component (including the 1.5 per cent credit charge referred to above) included in amounts owing is segregated and disregarded for the purpose of interest calculations. I understand that this differs from many methods of computing interest in Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 25 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to an article headed 'Problems with Photocopying' in the Booksellers Fair advertising supplement in the Age, 23 March 1981, page 2.
(2) Is it a fact, as alleged in that article, that the Government has decided to charge import duty and sales tax on imported school work books.
(3) If so, would this action conflict with the Florence Agreement.
(4) What is the full title of the Florence Agreement, when was it signed and or ratified by Australia, and what is its purpose.
(5) What is the Government's attitude towards the payment of import duty and sales tax on imported school work books.

(6) Has his Department, or any statutory authority under its control, made any investigation of the claim that import duty and sales tax will probably cause the cost of imported school work books to double; if so, is there any substance to this claim.
(7) If an investigation has not been made, will he now cause it to take place.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) No. Until recently work books, which are accepted as being combined exercise and text books, were generally classified under Item 48.18 of the Customs Tariff which is the item for exercise books and were dutiable at the rate of 25 per cent.

The 25 per cent duty rate for exercise books was imposed on 28 September 1979 following the Government decision on the report by the Industries Assistance Commission on Paper Products dated 16 May 1979.
Following a legal challenge and subsequent discussion it was agreed that the tariff classification of work books should be modified as follows:

Work books designed essentially for writing in by users in which the printed text comprises a minor and clearly incidental aspect of the book will, as before, continue to fall to Tariff Item 48.18 and be dutiable at 25 per cent.

Work books designed primarily to pose question and answer exercises with provision for answers therein will be classified under Tariff Item 49.01, which is the item for textbooks, and be entered free of duty.
Work books comprising text material together with question and answer exercises will also continue to be entered under Tariff Item 49.01.
In relation to the question of sales tax the following ruling currently applies:

Books either imported or locally produced, which deal with educational subjects of a kind taught in non-profit schools or universities and which contain sets of questions or problems to be answered or worked out in spaces provided have been ruled exempt from sales tax under Item 51(1) First Schedule, Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act.

(4) The full title of the Florence Agreement is the UNESCO Agreement on the Importation of Educational Scientific and Cultural Materials. Its primary objective is to encourage the free flow of educational, scientific and cultural materials. Australia has not formally ratified the Florence Agreement; however it has in practice sought to give effect to the spirit of the Agreement's aims and objectives.
(6) No such investigation has been made.

(7) No. The Government does not make changes in rates of duty on imported goods without first seeking advice from the Industries Assistance Commission. In this case the IAC submitted its report recommending a 25 per cent ad valorem duty, and the recommendation was accepted by the Government.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McMahon Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 25 March 1981.

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many (a) men and (b) women, previously on unemployment benefits, have transferred to Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme (TEAS) benefit during (i) 1978 and (ii) 1979.
(2) How many applications for TEAS benefits from, (a) men and (b) women previously on unemployment benefits, have been processed, as at 1 March 1981.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

Statistics of unemployment beneficiaries transferring to TEAS therefore are not available.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

CRA Limited-$6,800,000; Pancontinential Mining Limited-$2,600,000; Mary Kathleen Uranium Limited -$870,000; Queensland Mines Limited-$878,000.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Federal Engine Drivers and Firemen's Association of Australasia

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 26 March 1981:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade and Resources, upon notice, on 1 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Uranium Advisory Council's Annual Report for 1979-80 state that he has indicated that the Council may expect its advice will be made public in due course, when referring to the Harrisburg Three Mile Island Accident Report.
(2) Has the report been stated to be confidential both by his office and by the Secretary of the Uranium Advisory Council; if so, why.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 2 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What sum did the Budget estimates provide in total Commonwealth Government assistance to State Governments for disaster relief in 1980-81 and what sum has been expended as at 1 April 1981.

(2) Has his attention been drawn to the fact that Mr Fred Murdoch, Executive Director of Willis, Faber and Dumas, an international insurance company of London, United Kingdom, on a recent stopover in Brisbane, expressed surprise that Australia did not have a natural disaster insurance scheme.
(3) Is he able to say whether Britain, Switzerland and New Zealand each have disaster insurance schemes.
(4) Did the then Treasurer and Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party in 1976 pledge the Government of the day to a natural disaster insurance scheme.

(5) Has his attention been drawn to Mr Murdoch's proposal for a scheme that would include (a) agreement between Government and insurance companies on the upper limits of liability, (b) the establishment of a low premium to allow subscription by low income earners, (c) the pooling of all premiums in a central fund open to annual audit and (d) provision for re-insurance internationally against levels of liability exceeding those anticipated.
(6) Will his Government consider this proposal in view of the frequent disasters suffered in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) $12,802,000 was provided in the 1980-81 Budget for Commonwealth assistance to the States under the natural disaster relief arrangements. As at April 1981, $37,435,364 had been provided in the form of advances and payments to the States in 1980-81.
(2) I am aware of Press comments along the lines mentioned that have been attributed to Mr Murdoch.
(3) I understand that national schemes or other arrangements exist in those countries for insurance cover to be provided against certain but not necessarily all forms of natural hazard.

(4) In his Press release of 4 March 1976 the then Treasurer announced that the Government had agreed, in principle, to the introduction of a natural disaster insurance scheme, and had approved the establishment of a working party of officials to formulate a detailed scheme in consultation with the insurance industry and, as necessary, with the States. In December 1976 a discussion paper based on the working party's report was tabled in Parliament for the purpose of seeking public comment on a possible natural disaster insurance scheme. Following a detailed assessment of this matter, including comments received from the States, the insurance industry and other interested parties, the Government concluded that a natural disaster insurance scheme of the type outlined in the discussion paper would not be a cost-effective way of assisting in solutions to the problems identified and that a number of practical measures dealing more directly with the problems and involving less Government intervention would be more appropriate. Work on this matter is proceeding. Further background on the Government's decisions in this area is contained in my press release of 17 January 1979 and in a Policy Information Paper which I tabled in Parliament on 4 June 1979.
(6) No. Suggestions broadly along these lines were considered in the course of the detailed assessment which preceded the Government's decisions mentioned in (4) above.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blewett Dr N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 7 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are negotiations currently in progress between officers of his Department and the tobacco industry about compulsory labelling on packets, of tar, nicotine and carbon monoxide levels of cigarettes.
(2) Has the tobacco industry's maximum offer been only (a) minimal banding and (b) indicating low, medium or high tar content.
(3) Is his Department prepared to accept this offer as final.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In accordance with the Government's decision to accept Recommendations 40 and 41 of the Report of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare: 'Drug Problems in Australia-an Intoxicated Society?', consultations with the tobacco industry are proceeding concerning implementation of plans for the printing of tar and nicotine yields on cigarette packets; the establishment of upper limits for tar and nicotine yields of cigarettes; and the progressive reduction of permitted levels of tar and nicotine in cigarettes.

Although action is presently underway to obtain agreement with industry on a uniform testing methodology for determining the carbon monoxide yields of cigarettes, proposals for implementation action are being developed only in relation to tar and nicotine yields, at this stage, in the terms of the Government's decision referred to above.

(2) and (3) Consultations with industry, involving detailed consideration of a number of complex issues, are continuing. Following these consultations, it is envisaged that proposals as regards implementation will be submitted to me for consideration.
Under these circumstances, it is inappropriate for me to comment further.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Telephone Calls by Staff: Department of Health

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a report in the West Australian of 18 July 1979, page 37, that London metropolitan police reduced its telephone bill by $985 000, or about 20 per cent by use of a monitoring device which recorded length, time and destination of telephone calls and the extension from which the call was made.
(2) Are personal telephone calls, particularly trunk and STD calls, made by staff of his Department controlled; if so, in what way.
(3) Has any consideration been given to the introduction of monitoring devices for telephone calls in his Department; if so, what was the outcome of the consideration.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) Yes. Departmental instructions to staff advise that private calls are to be kept to a minimum and only made with prior approval of an authorised officer. Private trunk calls must be booked through the switchboard operator and the cost reimbursed to the Department.

Metering devices, where installed, are read on a regular basis and unusual levels of telephone usage are investigated. Selective STD barring is used where technically feasible, and investigations are proceeding as to the possibility of introducing selective barring on equipment at other locations.

(3) Yes. Metering equipment is extensively used and a device which analyses calls is in use at one regional office. Having regard to other control measures in use such as metering and STD access barring, and plans to extend barring where technically feasible and funds are available, it is not considered that further use of call analysers with their need for additional resources to examine monitored data, would be cost effective in my Department at this stage.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the various recommendations of the Royal Australian Institute of Architects in regard to energy conservation.

(2) If so, have steps taken toward implementing the Institute's recommendation that the Commonwealth Government establish an Energy in Buildings Advisory Panel to advice on (a) energy conservation and (b) the research and educational aspects of energy conservation; if steps have been taken, what are the details.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Various recommendations of the Royal Australian Institute of Architects in regard to energy conservation have been brought to my attention. I have exchanged correspondence with the Institute on a number of occasions, outlining the Government's position and the role of the Department of Housing and Construction.
(2) No steps have been taken to establish an Energy in Buildings Advisory Panel, as a number of Commonwealth bodies are already active in this area.

An Interdepartmetal Committee on 'Energy Conservation in Commonwealth Buildings Throughout Australia and Other Buildings in the ACT' was established in February 1981. It is required to recommend a co-ordinated program to conserve energy in existing and future buildings throughout Australia owned or occupied by the Commonwealth, and to encourage, or, if necessary, recommend legislation for the adoption of energy conservation matters in private sector buildings in the ACT.

An Energy Secretariat has been estalished within the Department of Housing and Construction to examine ways to conserve energy in Commonwealth Government buildings, and the Department is co-operating with the Department of National Development and Energy to develop cost effective energy policies for the built environment.

In addition, organisations such as the National Energy Advisory Committee (NEAC) and the National Energy Research Development and Demonstration Council (NERDDC), provide advice on priorities and policies in energy conservation, research development and demonstration and a proportion of NERDDC funds has been allocated to this work in fields related to energy in the built environment.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 29 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the recent occurrence of the disease encephalitis in the north of Western Australia.
(2) How many cases of this disease have been identified in this area during the last 12 months.
(3) How many of these cases were amongst Aboriginal people in this period.
(4) What steps will the Government take in response to the occurrence of this disease.
(5) Have the populations of these remote areas been adequately warned of the current danger associated with mosquito bites in the transmission of this disease.
(6) What special efforts have been made to advise the remote Aboriginal communities of the current dangers of this disease.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. My Department has been in contact with Western Australia State Public Health Department concerning this outbreak.
(2) There have been seven serologically confirmed clinical cases.
(4) The Western Australia State health authorities have implemented mosquito vector control measures to minimize the further spread of the disease. This is the only method available.
The Federal Government allocated, in addition to the normal funds for encephalitis research and control to the State, a special allowance of $10,000 to combat this outbreak.

(5) and (6) Yes. The State Public Health Department with technical and monetary support from the Commonwealth promoted a health education program in the affected area including remote Aboriginal communities.

(2) Is he able to say whether, despite such written assurances from Maryvale Forest Pty Ltd, (a) employees of Iwasaki Sangyo are currently carrying out repairs to the boundary and internal fencing of the Maryvale Forest Pty Ltd and (b) 200 bullocks mustered on the Iwasaki property have been fattened on the Maryvale Forest Pty Ltd property and were offered for sale at the Rockhampton saleyards, Queensland, on 22 April 1981.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's questions is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) (a) Both Maryvale Forest Pty Ltd and the Iwasaki company have provided written advice that employees of Iwasaki Sangyo are not currently undertaking fencing repairs on or within Maryvale Forest Pty Ltd's property. The Iwasaki company is currently undertaking fencing of its own property, which has a common boundary with one of the Maryvale Forest Pty Ltd properties.

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the base interest rate on trading bank advances of over $100 000 currently 15 per cent.
(2) Is he considering a Reserve Bank recommendation that interest rates on housing loans should be increased to 12.5 per cent.

(3) If so, would this increase on advances under $100 000 be necessary if the Reserve Bank released 1 per cent of Statutory Reserve Deposit funds to ease present bank liquidity problems during the tax rundown period.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I understand that most major trading banks currently have a 'prime' rate of 15 per cent per annum for advances drawn under limits of $100,000 and above. (3) See answer to (2). However, the release of Statutory Reserve Deposit Funds to trading banks would not in itself affect the interest rate at which trading banks or, more importanlty, savings banks can lend for housing.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: National Servicemen: Discharge on Grounds of Exceptional Hardship

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 5 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many national servicemen serving in the Defence Force on 7 December 1972 left the service prior to the date on which they would normally have been discharged.
(2) How many of those referred to in part (1) were discharged on the grounds of exceptional hardship.
(3) What grounds constitute exceptional hardship.
(4) Is it possible for a member of the Service to be discharged on the grounds of exceptional hardship without his or her knowledge that this was the reason for their discharge.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Data is not readily available to provide the statistics requested. A lengthy manual search of many thousands of personal files would be necessary.

(3) The term 'exceptional hardship' appeared within the provisions of the National Service Act, 1951 but was not legally defined. Discharge on this ground depended on the circumstances of each case in accordance with the provisions of the Act, specifically, Sub-section 35B (5A).

(4) No. Exceptional hardship is not a current prescribed reason for discharge from any element of the Australian Defence Force. Discharge on compassionate grounds may be approved following application by a member.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 12 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the current position with regard to production and sales of the Mulloka Sonar and have funds been allocated to provide a sales effort for this project.
(2) Is it intended that the Mulloka be fitted in the Australian-built follow-on destroyers.
(3) To which vessels is it now intended that Mulloka will be fitted.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Mulloka is in the pre-production phase, in which one complete system is being manufactured. Full production is planned to commence in late 1981. No funds have been allocated for sales purposes, but a sales agreement with an Australian firm is under consideration by my Department.
(2) Mulloka is being considered as the sonar fit for the Australian-built follow-on destroyers. A decision on the sensor and weapons fit for the ships will be made later this year.

(3) It is currently intended to fit production Mulloka systems in 5 RAN River Class Destroyer Escorts, HMA Ships Swan, Torrens, Derwent, Stuart and Parramatta. The prototype system is fitted in the sixth River Class ship, HMAS Yarra.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 13 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is preference in Australian Government employment granted to war veterans; if so, under what circumstances.
(2) If preference is granted, does it apply equally to Vietnam veterans and veterans of World War II.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Under section 47A of the Public Service Act and Regulation 130 of the Public Service Regulations, where an applicant who is a returned soldier and an applicant who is not a returned soldier are placed equal in the order in which offers of appointment or temporary employment are to be made, the applicant who is a returned soldier is offered appointment or employment before the other applicant.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 13 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many officers of the Attorney-General's Department have been fully, or to a significant extent, occupied by the Westinghouse uranium cartel litigation and United States of America antitrust policy as it relates to uranium during each year since 1977.
(2) What has been the cost to the Australian Government of these activities in (a) salaries, (b) travel and administrative costs and (c) legal fees.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has supplied the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No officers of the Attorney-General's Department have been fully occupied by the uranium cartel litigation. The number of legal officers involved in work connected with these proceedings or general antitrust policy as it relates to uranium has varied as the need has arisen. As many as 5 officers have been engaged at a particular time.
(2) (a) The cost of officers' work on antitrust matters has not been separated from the cost of performance of their other functions.

(b) Antitrust issues were amongst the matters dealt with on visits I made to Ottawa and Washington in September 1978 and April 1980. In April 1980 I also attended the Commonwealth Law Ministers Meeting in Barbados where I delivered a paper on some aspects of antitrust enforcement. Officers of my Department accompanied me on those visits.

In addition, one officer returned to Australia via America after a visit to the OECD on other matters. He spent two days in Washington on antitrust matters. Domestically officers have made two trips to Sydney and three trips to Melbourne in connection with the administration of the Foreign Proceedings (Prohibition of Certain Evidence) Act 1976 as it applied to these foreign proceedings.
(c) The details of legal fees paid in this matter were contained in an answer on 29 April 1981 to Senate Question 454-see Senate Hansard, page 1524.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 13 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will he elaborate on the circumstances in which paid study leave is to be denied to Commonwealth Public Servants (Hansard, 30 April 1981, page 1850).
(2) Will he agree to extended leave without pay to enable public servants who have already embarked on courses of study, to complete their course requirements.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The intention behind the Government's announcement is to ensure that study leave is granted only when there is direct benefit to the Service through the acquistion of specific identified skills and increase in staff efficiency. The Public Service Board is actively promoting this policy.

(2) It is not intended that officers already committed to courses of study should be precluded from completing their courses and transitional arrangements are available. Procedures exist for public servants to take extended leave without pay for study or private purposes. Each application is considered on its merits.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 14 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a claim by James Grant, Executive Director of UNICEF, that breast feeding promotion can save a million infants a year in the 1980s.

(2) Is the International Baby Food Action Network (IBFAN) with the World Health Organisation (WHO) and other authorities preparing a code of marketing for breast milk substitutes to be presented to the World Health Assembly in May 1981.
(3) Has the code been opposed by the International Council of Infant Food Industries (ICIFI) whose 15 companies produce 85 per cent of the $US2 billion baby milk market.

(4) Is he able to say whether the Washington Post, in January 1981, exposed industry links with publications and research foundations seeking third party support and smearing critics as Marxists and Reds.

(5) Is he also able to say whether consumer and health professional groups in India foiled moves for bilateral weak codes of ethics after financial inducements were offered to medical officials who then supported an ICIFI-drafted code.
(6) Will the Government support an international code and expose publicly irresponsible companies and their promotion.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware of recent reports in the Australian press that UNICEF officials have stated it is likely that at least a million children in the developing world die each year from inadequate artificial feeding. A successful breast feeding promotion would certainly prevent some of these deaths.

(2) During the last two years, a draft International Code of Marketing of Breastmilk Substitutes has been developed by WHO and UNICEF, in co-operation with member countries of the World Health Assembly and with industry and consumer bodies. The fourth draft of this Code was presented to the Thirty-fourth World Health Assembly in May 1981.

(3) to (5) I am aware that there has been considerable opposition from a number of sources to the development and acceptance of the draft Code, some reports of which have been published in the Australian press. However, in the absence of detailed information concerning the specific instances referred to by the honourable member, I am unable to comment further.

(6) Australia supported the draft International Code of Marketing of Breastmilk Substitutes that was adopted by the World Health Assembly on 22 May 1981. No further action is proposed at this stage in relation to the honourable member's suggestion.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on 14 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the current estimated value of all land and premises in the Glebe Estate, NSW.
(2) What has been the total Commonwealth Government outlay on the Estate in each year since its purchase.
(3) How many dwellings (a) have been rehabilitated in each year since the inception of the Estate project, (b) are now in the process of rehabilitation and (c) have yet to be rehabilitated.
(4) What is the estimated cost of rehabilitating the dwellings that remain in their condition at the date of purchase by the Commonwealth.
(5) How many dwellings in the Estate are currently (a) occupied, and what is the total number of tenants and (b) vacant.
(6) What is the annual value of total rental payments to the Commonwealth for the occupied dwellings in the Estate.
(7) How many tenants in the Estate are in receipt of rental rebates.
(8) What is the annual cost of the rental rebates provided.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Glebe Estate was valued at $23m by the Australian Taxation Office in November 1978.
Since the valuation will be a key factor in negotiations with the NSW Government on the transfer of the Glebe Estate it would not be appropriate for the Commonwealth to release the current valuation.
(2) Total outlays include expenditure on rehabilitation, repairs and maintenance, ex gratia payments for rates and administration costs, but no Project Office staff salaries.
(b) 40 dwelling units are currently with contractors for major rehabilitation works and about 20 dwellings for minor rehabilitation works.
(c) At the end of June 1981, approximately 370 dwellings will still require rehabilitation.

(4) The cost of completing rehabilitation of the Estate would vary depending on the standard of finish and the extent of work done. In view of the negotiations with the NSW Government on transfer of the Estate it would not be appropriate for the Commonwealth to release an estimate of the cost of completing rehabilitation.
(5) (a) At 1 May 1981, 539 dwellings were occupied, providing accommodation for approximately 2,500 people.
(6) Rent revenue from the Estate for 1979-1980 was $841,000. Estimated revenue for 1980-1981 is $890,000.
(7) At 1 May 1981, 331 tenants (61 per cent of all tenants on the Estate) received rental rebates.

(8) The annual cost of the rental rebate scheme is approximately $300,000. This represents the difference between the rent received and revenue that would be received if all tenants paid the assessed rental.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Payroll Deductions for Health Fund Payments

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 28 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Will he ensure that payroll deductions for health fund payments will be made available to recipients of Commonwealth superannuation payments; if not, what is the reason?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Superannuation pensions are paid in each State by the Department of Social Security and in the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory by the Department of Finance, acting as paying agents for the Commissioner for Superannuation. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 2 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that the universal occupational code, the Australian Standard Classification of Occupation (ASCO), is currently being prepared to rationalise labour market statistics.
(2) Will ASCO be used by the Australian Bureau of Statistics in the future production of unemployment statistics; if so, will they be available on a regional basis.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Standard Classification of Occupations (ASCO) is being developed jointly by the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs and the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) to replace the current occupation classifications which suffer from a number of serious deficiencies.

(2) The Statistician has advised that in the labour force survey, unemployed persons who had worked for two weeks or more in a full-time job in the previous two years are classified according to the occupation of their last full-time job. The ASCO will be used for these unemployment statistics as soon as practicable, but is not expected to be available for some considerable time.

Following the next reselection of the labour force survey sample, to be based on results of the 1981 Census of Population and Housing, it may be feasible to provide some statistics of unemployment on a regional basis, but any occupational classification would not be very detailed.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Defoliants and Pesticides Effect on Vietnam Veterans

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 30 April 1981 (Hansard, page 1807) the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) asked me a question, without notice, concerning any discussions and exchanges of information between the Australian and United States Governments on the impact of agent orange and other chemicals on servicemen in Vietnam.

ANSWER.PARA: I undertook to provide more detailed information to the honourable member. The following is in answer to his question:

I am advised that arrangements have been made between the Department of Veterans' Affairs and relevant United States agencies to exchange unclassified information on the progress of studies in Australia and the United States, as well as new scientific data having a bearing on the issue. In view of recent Swedish studies that suggest a correlation between exposure to phenoxyacid herbicides and increased risk of lymphoma, the United States Veterans' Administration has asked to be kept informed of any decisions which may be made in Australia in respect of Vietnam veterans' claims in relation to malignant lymphoma. I am advised that there has been no expression of concern by the United States Government to the Australian Government in respect of any precedent that Australian investigations into the alleged effects of agent orange on Vietnam veterans may have in establishing any liability by the United States Government.

There have been high level discussions between Australian and US officials, and the Minister for Veterans' Affairs will be visiting the United States in June this year to discuss issues of concern to Vietnam veterans with officials of the United States Veterans' Administration, veterans organisations, and other organisations involved in this area. These issues include the epidemiological study which will be investigating whether there were any effects on Australian servicemen of agent orange and other chemicals used in Vietnam, and similar studies underway in the United States.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: International Labour Organisation Convention: Aboriginal Employment

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 26 November 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: On what occasions, at what level and with what results has there been Federal-State (a) consultation and (b) correspondence on the possibility of providing a legislative basis for National and State Employment Discrimination Committees established to give the provisions of International Labour Organisation Convention No. 111-Discrimination (Employment and Occupation), 1958, which was ratified by Australia on 15 June 1974 and which entered into force for Australia a year later. (Hansard, 20 October 1977, page 2289).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The possibility of the establishment of the National and State Employment Discrimination Committees on a statutory basis was raised at the Ministers for Labour Meeting in September 1980. At that meeting Ministers were advised that, following receipt of advice from the National Labour Consultative Council on the Council's views on the desirable form of such legislation, the Commonwealth would seek consultations with the States.
While there has been some correspondence which referred, in passing, to the Government's consideration of this matter it has not been raised in correspondence with the States in a substantive way.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade and Resources, upon notice, on 3 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that his Department is increasingly ignoring the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Trade and Commerce on the Australian Trade Commissioner Service, by recruiting persons from within the Australian Public Service rather than from the private sector.
(2) Is the current salary structure for Trade Commissioners appropriate compared with the salaries of business executives of equivalent position in the private sector.
(3) Is he able to say whether morale within the Australian Trade Commissioner Service is at an all time low; if so, has this contributed to recent resignations by experienced members of the Service.

(4) Is it a fact that the Lynch Committee has frozen a number of Trade Commissioner vacancies at overseas posts; if so, will cutbacks of this kind benefit Australian exporters when commercial intelligence on world opportunities is badly needed and vital to export performance.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Not in my judgment. The honourable member might wish to refer to the Senate Hansard of 27 September 1979, at pages 1032 and 1033, where the recommendations contained in the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Trade and Commerce on the Australian Trade Commissioner Service, and the Government's responses thereto, are recorded.

(2) The salary structure for Trade Commissioners is directly related to the rates of pay for Second and Third Divison positions in the Public Service which cover a wide spectrum of executive positions within the public sector. The rates of pay for Second and Third Divison positions are presently under review by a Full Bench of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and any increase forthcoming from that review will also be applied to Trade Commissioners.

(4) In his statement to Parliament on 30 April 1981 on the outcome of the Review of Commonwealth Functions, the Prime Minister said, inter alia, that, 'significant room for staffing reductions exists in our diplomatic missions overseas. The staffing of the London and Washington posts overseas will be cut by 232 and by 75 staff respectively . . . '. The way in which this decision is to be implemented, insofar as the Trade Commissioner Service is concerned, is presently being investigated but it can be assumed that the intent will be to minimise the effect on Australian exporters. In addition to the number of staff serving under the Trade Commissioner Act has been reduced by just over 2 per cent as a result of decisions flowing from the Review of Commonwealth Functions. This may require a re-distribution of staffing resources but such re-distribution would be directed towards maximising overall efficiency including the provision of commercial intelligence to the Australian business community.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hawke Mr R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 4 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many new courses commenced in the Commonwealth school to work transition program in 1980.
(2) How many additional places did the additional courses provide.
(3) What was the average cost to the Commonwealth per place.
(4) What proportion of those additional places was taken up by unemployed young persons.
(5) How many additional places are expected to be provided in 1981.
(6) How many young persons experiencing transition problems are expected to be found places in next year's courses.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Preliminary data available from the States concerning new courses commenced under the Transition Program in 1980 indicate that 247 courses began in the TAFE sector.

A major purpose of the Program in schools is to assist development of appropriate changes in curriculum, including the development of alternative courses for young people whose needs are not adequately met by traditional courses. While these measures are expected to encourage more students to continue longer in secondary education, the major effect so far has been to improve the capacity of schools to deal adequately with the needs of students already in the schools. It is not possible to specify a particular number of courses or places provided in schools from Commonwealth funds. However, it is estimated that at least 4,000 students in secondary schools were undertaking courses receiving significant financial support under the Program.
Funding for the Program is approximately equally divided between school based and TAFE programs.

(2) Courses in TAFE institutions provided for about 4,400 students. Many thousands of students in schools benefited from developments supported under the Program in 1980. These include development and extension of alternative course offerings and work experience programs, improvement of career guidance and education, programs of city visits for country children, provision of vocational course equipment and facilities, teacher development and transition curriculum development.

(3) The average cost to the Commonwealth of providing these courses in TAFE in 1980 (excluding Commonwealth benefits and allowances paid to students and trainees) was of the order of $1,500 per student. It should be noted that courses varied in length from twelve weeks to forty weeks, depending on arrangements in individual States and institutions.
(4) Sample data suggests that about three-quarters of trainees in TAFE courses under the Program were receiving Unemployment Benefit before commencing courses.

(5) It is expected that about 6,000 places will be provided in courses in the TAFE sector under the Program in 1981. This is 1,600 more than in 1980. The range of activities established in schools will continue and develop. At least 8,000 students in secondary schools are undertaking courses receiving financial support under the Program.

(6) See reply to (5) above. Most participants in courses funded under the Program either have experienced or are regarded as likely to experience transition problems. Activities in the school sector will significantly affect many thousands of students, although few will be enrolled in new places which can be specifically identified as being fully funded by the Commonwealth.
A good part of activities funded by the Commonwealth under the Transition Program supplements similar activities funded by the States.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hurford Mr C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 5 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that a number of Goverment departments and statutory bodies, including (a) Treasury, (b) Finance, (c) Industrial Relations and (d) the Industries Assistance Commission, are having difficulty in recruiting suitably qualified staff.
(2) Is this fact borne out by the amount of re-advertising of certain Government positions being arranged by his Department.
(3) Is this problem particularly acute in the field of quantitative economic analysis.

(4) Is this seeming lack of expertise available for the public sector within Australia caused by a brain drain to overseas countries and a loss of trained personnel to the private sector; if so, is he concerned by this trend.,

(5) How does this loss from the public sector reconcile with the view of the Prime Minister expressed in the House during the question period on 26 February 1981 when he referred to the privileged position of the Public Service in comparison with other employees around this country (Hansard, page 232).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Public Service employs specialist staff in a wide range of fields. From time to time departments experience difficulty in recruiting suitably qualified staff in particular specialist fields.

(2) At the time the question was asked the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs was experiencing difficulty in recruiting staff to its Bureau of Labour Market Research and to steno-secretarial positions.
(3) The economics area generally is one in which recruitment difficulties are being experienced at the moment.

(4) There is currently a shortfall in the supply of qualified personnel graduating from tertiary institutions in some specialised categories, such as economics. Private sector employers, competing for the same scarce resources, are also experiencing recruitment difficulties in these fields. While a proportion of resignations from the Service represents trained personnel transferring to the private sector there is no evidence to suggest that this trend is on the increase. There is also no indication of a significant ''brain drain'' overseas from the Public Service.
(5) The present situation is primarily the result of an overall shortage of specialised staff and not the conditions of employment of Commonwealth public servants.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 10 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did he announce on 15 May 1978 that the Code of General Principle concerning Occupational Safety and Health in Commonwealth Government employment would be implemented in Commonwealth departments and factories and would thereby give a lead to both private industries and State Government industries.
(2) If so, is he able to say to what extent the Code has been adopted in private industry.
(3) Into what number of foreign languages has the Code been translated.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The Government has also approved 37 Codes of Practice as recommendations to be read in support of the Code of General Principles.

(2) The States have the constitutional responsibility in respect of occupational health and safety in private industry. Four State Governments have adopted the Code of General Principles with minor revisions in respect of their own employees. The Commonwealth has no detailed knowledge of the extent of adoption of the code by private industry. It is believed, however, that there is an increasing awareness both in the State Governments and private industry of the financial and humanitarian benefits to be gained from the implementation of properly structured and implemented occupational safety and health programs.

(3) There has been no co-ordinated action to prepare translations of the Code of General Principles which is basically a management guide. However, the Commonwealth is aware of the language problems facing some migrants which could contribute to accidents at the workplace and funds have been provided in the past to combat this problem. Audiovisual aids and handbooks have been produced in up to nine languages.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 2 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the management of Telecom Australia maintain a policy of scaling down its telegram service; if so, does it do so (a) by increasing costs vis-a-vis costs for telex and telephone services, and decreasing services and (b) with the Government's support.

(2) Is it a fact that some areas of the Brisbane Metropolitan area are not serviced by telegrams in that telegrams cannot be messenger delivered to those areas; if so which areas, and for what reason.
(3) Was the minimum charge for a telegram of 12 words in (a) 1976, $1.44, (b) in 1977, $1.80 and (c) in 1978, $3.30.
(4) What is the current charge for a 12 word telegram.
(5) During this period, by how much has the total number of telegrams handled nationally diminished.
(6) Has a cost increase of more than 300 per cent over 4 years occurred while telegram handling has fallen by approximately 60 per cent during the same years; if so, are these factors related.

(7) Is it a fact that prior to July 1979, telegrams had to be issued for delivery within one hour of lodgement, but since July 1979, telegrams must be issued for delivery in (a) metropolitan and larger country areas, within 4 hours, (b) smaller country centres where messenger delivery is available, as early as practicable on the day of lodgement, and (c) other places, as soon as possible depending on local arrangements.
(8) Have telegram services to the public deteriorated; if so, does he propose to recommend changes to the service.
(9) If he will not recommend changes to this service, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. Tariffs and standards provided on all Telecom's services, including the public telegram service, are designed to reflect as far as practicable the cost of providing, and the demand for, each of those services.

(2) Yes. There are nine localities in the Brisbane metropolitan area where no messenger delivery is available, namely-Brookfield, Upper Brookfield, Bellbowrie, Anstead, Pullenvale, Moggill, Pinjarra Hills, Belmont and Chandler. These are lightly populated fringe areas with very little demand for telegram services. Other offices in Brisbane provide either a four hour or same day messenger delivery service.

(3) (a) and (b) Yes. (c) In 1978 the minimum rate was $1.80 for telegrams addressed to a telex number or for delivery by mail. The charge of $3.30 was for a 12 word telegram requiring messenger delivery.

(4) Addressed to a residential or business address-$4.30; addressed to a telegraphic code address-$3.30; addressed to a telephone number-$3.00; addressed to a postal address for delivery by mail-$2.50; addressed to a telex number-$2.00.
(5) The number of telegrams handled in 1979-80 was 5.4 million-a decline of 7.5 million since 1975-76.

(6) The charge for a 12 word messenger delivery telegram has risen from $1.84 in 1976 to $4.30 in 1980-an increase of 133.7 per cent. The current minimum charge for a telegram addressed to a telex number, however, is only $2.00-an increase of 38.8 per cent. Although increased charges have undoubtedly had an effect on the demand for the public telegraph service, the effect of the increased use and availability of high quality telephone, telex, data, facsimile and other communications services has been of equal significance. This reflects a world wide trend.

(7) (a) Prior to 1979 the service standard for ordinary rate telegrams was 30 minutes from time of lodgement to issue for delivery. Since 1979, the standard at most metropolitan and large country offices is 4 hours from time of lodgement to the actual delivery time. These standards are the maximum, rather than minimum, delivery times to be met in 90 per cent of cases. (b) and (c) Yes. In all cases, delivery times for telegrams which are telephoned or telexed to addressees are very much lower.

(8) and (9) The level of service has changed very little in recent years except for the general unavailability of a weekend delivery service outside metropolitan areas. Telegrams may still be lodged across a telegraph or post office counter during business hours and by telephone or telex on a 24 hour basis from virtually anywhere in Australia. Messenger delivery is limited to business hours outside the metropolitan areas where porterage fees apply after hours, but telegrams can be delivered over a 24 hour period anywhere in Australia by telephone or telex. Higher standards of service would need to take account of the demand for and cost of providing the service.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Integration of Handicapped Children into Regular Schools

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 7 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When were copies of the Schools Commission's notes on Commonwealth programs for schools, 1981, sent to Members' and Senators' offices.
(2) Does an attachment to that circular 1/81 contain guidelines for the administration of funds available for the integration of handicapped children into regular schools in 1981.

(3) Does the attachment state that applications for grants under that special education program for the integration of handicapped children into regular schools must be lodged with State offices of the Schools Commission, or the Northern Territory Department of Education, by Tuesday, 21 April 1981.
(4) Is it usual procedure for the Schools Commission to inform directly individual schools of the existence and conditions of these programs.
(5) Has the Commission directly contacted individual schools to inform them of the details of this program; if not, why not; if so, when.
(6) If notification of schools of this program has been left to the State Government Departments of Education, what action has the Queensland Department of Education taken in this regard.
(7) What recommendation has the Commission made in respect of funding this aspect of the special education program.
(8) Is it a fact that the Commonwealth Government has no commitment to continuation of this aspect of the program, at least at the present level of funding.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (4) and (5) It is usual procedure for the Schools Commission to set out the existence and conditions of programs concerning special education in the publication, 'Notes on Commonwealth Programs for Schools.' These guidelines are circulated to State and Northern Territory Education Departments, non-government school systems and all non-government schools. In the case of government schools, it is left to the initiative of the State or Territory Education Department concerned to decide the extent to which any particular school is informed of the contents of the Program Notes.

The publication, 'Notes on Commonwealth Programs for Schools', was circulated to all non-government schools and their system authorities on 10 March 1981. The publication was also forwarded on the same date to the Education Departments of the States and the Northern Territory.
(6) As indicated in (4) and (5) above, it is a matter for State or Northern Territory Education Departments to determine the extent to which any government special school is involved in this program.

(7) In its Report for the Triennium 1982-84 the Schools Commission has recommended that support for integration programs in 1981 be continued through the 1982-84 triennium to assist the integration of handicapped students into regular schools, and to enable isolated handicapped students to attend their neighbourhood schools where living at home is an alternative to a residential school. It is intended that the funds be administered through a joint program approach and on a project basis, in consultation with government and non-government education authorities in the States and the Northern Territory.

(8) For 1982 the Government has maintained expenditure, in real terms, on the integration of handicapped children into regular schools. This expenditure will be more closely related to the special education programs for government and non-government schools by being incorporated as an element of these programs in 1982.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What specific commitments for expenditure, excluding normal recurring costs of running the Department such as salaries and administrative costs, does the Department of Finance have for (a) 1980-81 and (b) 1981-82.
(2) What sum is involved in each commitment and what is the purpose of the commitment.

(3) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the fact that when a similar question was answered by a number of Ministers in 1976, it was claimed that obtaining the information would involve collection of detailed information from a diversity of records and sources, and would therefore require unjustifiable use of staff resources.
(3) Has the development of forward estimates in the Department of Finance now been advanced to a stage where a similar reply is no longer valid.

ANSWER.PARA: In addition to the attached projects carried out under the auspices of my department, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation has considerable involvement with fishing industry related research in Western Australia. Details are set out below:
Program included research relevant to the rock lobster industry and involved expenditure of $3,557,620 in the period 1976-77 to 1977-78.

Research was related to the future of the rock lobster industry. Expenditure in the period 1978-79 to 1979-80 was $992,226. Support from the Rural Credits Development Fund for this program amounted to $27,988 in 1979-80 and $18,839 in 1980-81.

Program involved operation of research vessels on the North West Shelf and also investigation of the relationship between South Australian and Western Australian stocks of salmon. The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation oceanographic research vessel Sprightly undertook research off Western Australia for approximately five months each year from 1975-76 to 1977-78. The overall cost of this vessel in this period was $806,700 in 1975-76, $758,700 in 1976-77 and $468,500 in 1977-78. It is not possible to identify the Western Australian component of these costs.

The Department of Science and Technology is also involved, through the public interest provisions of the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Act, with a three year research and development project grant amounting to $225,000 for the production of freshwater crayfish in Western Australia. The grant was announced in February 1981.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 29 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have arrangements been made by the Commonwealth Government to charter the ocean racing yacht Anaconda II for use by South Australian fishing inspectors.
(2) If so, is the charter rate $1,250 per day.
(3) If the charter rate is not $1,250 per day, what is the daily charter rate.

(4) What are the terms of the charter and, in particular, can the Commonwealth Government become liable to the yacht's owner for any sum additional to the basic charter rate as a result of its use of the yacht.
(5) How many crew are required to operate the yacht, what are their qualifications and is the cost of their wages and personal insurances included in the charter rate.
(6) How many fishing inspectors and other officials are carried on the yacht.
(7) Are any persons carried when the yacht is on Government service other than paid crew and public servants on duty; if so, who and for what reason are they carried.
(8) What durations of voyage are (a) undertaken or (b) contemplated in the use of the yacht.
(9) Are all Department of Transport, public service and other regulations complied with in this use of the yacht.
(10) What are the (a) maximum and (b) most economical speeds under power of Anaconda II.
(11) Is he able to say what is the maximum speed of a typical Japanese tuna fishing vessel.
(12) What is the approximate value of Anaconda II as is, complete with all equipment.

(13) What is the rationale for the use of Anaconda II for this purpose and, in particular, why is use being made of a (a) sailing vessel rather than a motor vessel and (b) very large ocean racer rather than a smaller vessel designed for seagoing work with a small crew but which still has ample accommodation and endurance.
(14) Were tenders called for this charter; if not, why not.
(15) If tenders were called for this charter, was that involving Anaconda II the lowest; if not, why was the lowest tender not accepted.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Anaconda II was the vessel selected by the South Australian Government in consultation with the Commonwealth Government for the deployment of Australian fishing zone observers aboard Japanese vessels operating off South Australia.

(4) The vessel is required to carry four observers to locate and board licensed Japanese tuna longliners operating off the South Australian coast in order to obtain information on the size composition and biology of the Japanese catch and technical information on their fishing operations. Under the terms of the contract, the Commonwealth is not liable to the yacht's owner for sums additional to the basic daily rate.

(5) Eight crew consisting of experienced local seamen were on board for the first voyage lasting 13 days. The charter rate was all inclusive. Wages and personal insurance are matters for the crew and vessel owner.
(6) Three observers and one Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation biologist.
(7) The only personnel carried on the vessel for the two voyages were Commonwealth and State officers together with the crew.
(8) (a) Voyage 1 undertaken from 23.4.81 to 5.5.81. (b) Voyage 2 undertaken from 21.5.81 to 28.5.81. No further voyages are contemplated.
(9) All Commonwealth requirements were complied with in the use of the vessel.

(11) Speeds vary according to the operation being undertaken, e.g. 9-10 knots for speed setting line, 3-5 knots for speed retrieving line. Tuna longline vessels are normally stationary (adrift) for approximately 4 hours daily. In the observer operation the question of pursuit does not arise. Boardings of vessels by observers are facilitated by the master of the foreign vessel.
(12) It is understood that the initial construction cost was $100,000, but replacement value is now conservatively estimated at $500,000.

(13) It was the cheapest arrangement. Few suitable vessels were available for charter in South Australia with sufficient range, size and deep seagoing capabilities for operations in the Great Australian Bight. The tuna season was at its height and local fishermen were unwilling to make their vessels available for a charter fee that would be well below the returns they could obtain from fishing.

Of the three vessels available for the charter, two were motor vessels priced at $2,000 per day. The Anaconda II although a sailing vessel, met the requirements for the charter, especially for deep seagoing work and its capacity to accommodate crew and observers at least cost. There were no reports of the Anaconda II having difficulty in satisfactorily completing all the necessary manoeuvres to enable observers to perform their tasks amongst the Japanese vessels.

(14) Following consultation with the South Australian Tender Board, it was decided not to call tenders because of the time that would be lost in arranging charters to meet the deadline for the commencement of the exercise.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Northern Territory Disabled Persons: Education Projects

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tambling Mr G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 6 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What financial appropriations have been allocated by his Department for use in the Northern Territory for projects to assist the disabled during 1980-81.
(2) For what specific projects has this sum been allocated.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) During 1980 and 1981 funds are being made available for disabled young people in the Northern Territory under programs administered by the Commonwealth Schools Commission and under the Transition from School to Work Program.

Under the Commonwealth Schools Commission's programs, allocations to the Northern Territory for 1980 included $119,000 for government special schools, and $13,500 for residential institutions. Allocations for 1981 include $123,500 for government special schools, $14,500 for residential institutions and $10,500 for the program for the integration of handicapped children into regular schools. In addition, in 1981, the Northern Territory will share in a new program of assistance for the severely handicapped but individual State and Territory allocations are not yet available.

Under the Transition from School to Work Program, projects to attract funding are initiated by the Northern Territory authorities and are submitted to the Commonwealth for approval. In 1981 $3,200 has been earmarked to help improve the prospects of handicapped students by giving increased attention to literacy and numeracy skills in school and by offering work experience placements. However it is expected that disabled young people would also benefit from projects of a more general nature. Under the Transition Program the Northern Territory received a total of $95,599 in 1980 and has received $112,860 so far in 1981.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 7 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Government required reduction of the Commonwealth Public Service on several occasions since November 1975.

(2) If so, how many public servants, and at what level, (a) have been affected on each occasion during this period and (b) will be affected following the implementation of the Review of Commonwealth Functions.

(3) Is it a fact that there has been a disproportionate reduction in the lower levels of the Public Service, and that one of the unforeseen results of the reductions has been an increase in the percentage ratio of 2nd Division Officers.
(4) What will happen to 2nd Division Officers in those areas where their function has been abolished or transferred to private enterprise or to a State Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) (a) The table below shows the number of full time Public Service Act staff at 30 June from 1975 to date, by Division:

(These figures have been corrected retrospectively for transfer into and out of Public Service Act coverage that occurred prior to 30 June 1980 e.g. for transfers to the Northern Territory Public Service.)

(2) (b) Implemention of the Government's decisions announced in the Prime Minister's statement of 30 April 1981 is expected to result in reductions in the order of 16,000 to 17,000 in the number of Commonwealth Government employees. It is estimated that some 7,000 to 8,000 of the reduction will be Public Service Act employees. Details of savings at the various levels are not available at this stage.

(3) The table illustrates changes within the Second, Third and Fourth Divisions for the period 30 June 1975 to 30 June 1980. The changes in the relevant proportions of the Second, Third and Fourth Divisions of the Service can be attributed to a number of factors such as different work arrangements, the nature of the work done, the impact of technological change, as well as staffing reductions.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Participation in Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting: Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 7 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many (a) 2nd Division, (b) 3rd Division and (c) 4th Division officers of his Department are engaged (i) full-time or (ii) part-time in administrative, policy or other preparations for the forthcoming Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Melbourne.
(2) How many officers of his Department are expected to attend the Meeting.
(3) What is the expected cost of their attendance at the Meeting, including salaries, overtime, accommodation, travel and other expenses.
(4) What other expenses does he expect his Department to incur as a result of Australia's participation in, and conduct of, the Meeting.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (4) This will be the largest meeting of Commonwealth Heads of Government yet held and will be by far the largest meeting at this level ever to take place in Australia. At least 41 countries, represented for the most part by Head of State or Head of Government with accompanying delegations of Ministers and officials, are expected to attend.

Over the last decade the practice has developed of holding the Meeting in different member countries of the Commonwealth. Recent Meetings have been held in Singapore, Ottawa, Kingston, London and Lusaka. If smaller countries such as Singapore, Jamaica and Zambia can fulfil their obligations as Members of the Commonwealth of Nations, it is right that Australia should, too.

Much needs to be available in the way of facilities and equipment for a meeting of this level and size. Much of the equipment being provided, whether for example in the security area or for Conference Centre furnishings, will have a future government use. Decisions on the acquisition of equipment are made with future use in mind.

There are currently 4 Second Division, 27 Third Division and 13 Fourth Division personnel engaged full-time in my Department on preparations for the forthcoming Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting. Some of these are seconded from other departments.
Some additional staff will be taken on full time in preparation for the Meeting but the exact numbers will be determined as needs are identified.

A number of officers have as required been employed part time on preparations of an administrative and policy kind for the Meeting. Their numbers have varied and will continue to do so in accordance with need.

My Department's current estimate of expenditure on CHOGM is $12m. The greatest individual expenditure, about $6m, relates to security in Victoria. A substantial portion of this $6m will comprise transfer of funds from the Commonwealth to the State of Victoria to offset increased operating costs of the Victoria Police Force in providing the required security during CHOGM. Also included in the $6m for security is expenditure on security communications equipment such as portable radio transceivers and television surveillance equipment. Much of this equipment will have a Commonwealth use after the Meeting. Other major items of expenditure include residential accommodation, transport, fitting out of the Meeting venue, furniture, and the operating costs of the Task Force which has been established to handle the arrangements for the Meeting.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 14 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the current rate of interest at which funds are made available by the Rural Credits Department of the Reserve Bank of Australia to the Australian Wheat Board.

(3) What proportion of its total borrowings is the Australian Wheat Board likely to draw from the Rural Credits Department of the Reserve Bank of Australia in 1981-82.
