QUESTION.SPEAKER: Dawkins Mr J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 27 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are schools involved in the education of handicapped persons eligible for funds under the school to work transition program.
(2) If so, what funds have been made available in each State for these schools during (a) 1980 and (b) the period 1 January to 26 May 1981.
(3) If these schools are not eligible to receive funds under the program are there any other programs under which the Commonwealth provides assistance for the employment of handicapped persons.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) As a general program of assistance for the development of transition education programs for young people, Transition Program funding is provided to the States following Commonwealth approval of broad State 'package' proposals for schools and TAFE institutions rather than for specific areas of disadvantage such as handicapped persons. Under the Program guidelines the Commonwealth seeks to encourage education authorities in the States to take account of the needs of particular disadvantaged students, but it is for these authorities to determine priorities amongst individual proposals within the broad 'package' proposals approved by the Commonwealth. While it is not possible to identify all school projects specifically concerned with the handicapped, there have been a number of such projects funded and it is evident that the needs of the handicapped are being recognised by the responsible authorities.

(3) In addition to Transition Program funding, it is possible for handicapped persons attending special schools and classes to benefit from an employment point of view through the Commonwealth's Special Education Program administered by the Commonwealth Schools Commission. This program aims to improve the quality and coverage of educational services for handicapped children by supplementing the funding of special schools and classes. While these funds are not specifically directed to assistance for the employment of handicapped persons, they may be used for work experience and vocational training programs conducted by special schools and regular schools in which there are special classes. Within the Commonwealth's Special Education Program there is a Children in Residential Institutions element which funds projects designed to improve the educational prospects and to broaden the general experience of children living in institutions. It is possible for such projects to be concerned with transition, work experience and vocational training.

As far as programs outside the education area are concerned, the Departments of Social Security and of Employment and Youth Affairs administer programs and services designed to assist the employment of handicapped persons. Subsidies under the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act and rehabilitation assistance through the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service are administered by the Department of Social Security. Through the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs disabled persons registered for employment may receive assistance under the National Employment and Training System to gain the skills necessary to obtain employment. Employment subsidies are provided for on-the-job training. A number of work preparation/training programs are funded and assistance for individuals to undertake formal training is available.

(2) Are students to be considered as new enrolments for the purpose of being obliged to pay fees in 1982 if (a) they enrol prior to 1 January 1982, (b) they are registered as post-graduate students before 1 January 1982, (c) they had previously commenced post-graduate studies, discontinued them, and subsequently recommenced them after 1 January 1982 or (d) the tertiary institution obliges all post-graduate students who have commenced courses prior to 1 January 1982 to re-enrol.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Young Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 4 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Will he explain what is meant by the Government's announcement that eligibility for the Adult Secondary Assistance Scheme will be restricted to those needing qualifications for employment (Hansard, 30 April 1981, page 1843).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government's decision, following the Review of Commonwealth Functions, that eligibility under the Adult Secondary Education Assistance Scheme will be restricted to those needing qualifications for employment will mean that as from 1 January 1982, only applicants who have indicated an employment objective for which completion of matriculation level studies is considered to be essential or highly desirable will be eligible for consideration under the scheme. Acceptable employment objectives will include those requiring completion of a tertiary qualification for which matriculation is a pre-requisite. It will be necessary in future for the employment objective to be stated on the application form.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Young Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 4 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have changes been proposed to the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme eligibility rules; if so, will students who previously have been granted independent status on the grounds of having lived in a de facto relationship for 2 years, or 1 year if there was a child involved, continue to be granted independent status.
(2) Will students who have previously claimed a dependent spouse allowance on the grounds of a de facto relationship continue to be able to claim that allowance.
(3) Will students who have previously been granted a living away from home allowance on the grounds of being over 21 years continue to be eligible for that allowance.
(4) Will students be able to claim dependants' allowances for a de facto spouse in 1982.

(5) Are parents in receipt of a supporting parents benefit, who qualify for independent status on the grounds of having lived in a de facto relationship, able to earn $5,100 before the means test is applied; if so, with the abolition of a de facto relationship as grounds for independent status, will adjustments be made to ensure this higher non-means tested income will still apply to supporting parents.
(6) Has the Government any intention of changing the regulations that allow students to claim independent status by totalling their workforce participation over the previous five years.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, following the Review of Commonwealth Functions there has been some modification of the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme (TEAS) eligibility rules which generally will take effect as from 1 January 1982. The general intention is also that students who have already qualified under the rules which have now been modified will continue to do so. Consequently, the decision, that participation in a de facto relationship will no longer qualify an applicant for independent status, will not affect those students who have already qualified for independent status in this way. Those granted independent status on this basis prior to 1982 will retain that status.
(2) Yes, subject to their continuing to comply with the normal conditions of eligibility.

(3) The decision that students will no longer be able to qualify for the living away-from-home rate if, being 21 years of age or more, they choose to live away from home will also take effect as from 1 January 1982. Students who have already qualified under the age 21 provision will continue to qualify on the same grounds after 1981 subject to their continuing to comply with other normal requirements.

(5) The provision whereby a sole parent, with a dependent child (or children) and who has independent status under TEAS, may be in receipt of $5,100 before the means test on personal income is applied is subject only to whether or not the child is wholly or substantially dependent on the applicant. It does not necessarily require that the applicant should be in receipt of supporting parent's benefit nor to have been involved in a de facto relationship. Students who have already qualified for this provision will continue to do so after 1981, while new applicants as from 1 January 1982 will be assessed against the ongoing requirements for independent status.

(6) No. Students will continue to be eligible to apply for independent status if they have been employed full-time in the workforce for periods totalling two years out of the previous five. However, one of the decisions following the Review of Commonwealth Functions was that periods of registration for employment which do not involve the receipt of unemployment benefits may now be taken into account in determining the two year qualifying period for independent status, provided the student was unemployed and in Australia and available for full-time work. This relaxation of the rules will take effect as from 1 January 1982.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Johnson The Hon L.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 26 November 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: What recommendations made since December 1977 by the Homeless Persons Advisory Committees (a) have been accepted, (b) have been rejected or (c) are still under consideration by the Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Since 1977, the State Homeless Persons Advisory Committees, which have now been abolished, commented on a wide range of issues and on various Commonwealth Government programs. It is not appropriate to respond to the question in terms of recommendations accepted, rejected or under consideration, because: (i) in addition to the 77 recorded separate recommendations from the various State Committees, some of which have been provided by more than one State Committee, an unknown number of recommendations were made orally in discussions with the former Minister and officers of the Department; (ii) in the nature of Advisory Committees, the expression of views and discussion of issues is as important as (was) the submission of formal recommendations.
Important issues raised by the Advisory Committees include:
amendment of the Homeless Persons Assistance Act to broaden the range of services provided to homeless people;
facilities and services to be provided to categories of homeless people other than the chronically homeless;
an expansion and increase in recurrent subsidies provided under the Homeless Persons Assistance Act; and
an expansion in the allocation of capital funds to the Homeless Persons Assistance Program.
The major initiatives in services for homeless people which reflect the recommendations of the Advisory Committees are:
the Homeless Persons Assistance Act was amended in 1979 to remove all references to a prescribed period, which previously limited the operation of the Act;

the Youth Services Scheme for homeless youth, which is funded jointly by the Commonwealth and State Governments, provides emergency accommodation as well as counselling and referral services to homeless young people up to the age of 18 years;

the regulations of the Homeless Persons Assistance Act have been amended to increase the level of food and accommodation, and meal subsidies paid to voluntary organisations providing these services to homeless people;

the Government's allocation of $10m to a three year capital funding program for homeless persons, with special provisions for homeless young people. I have already announced the first stage of this program and will make a further announcement of projects approved for funding in the near future.

Bell LOH Pilot error-No action recommended
F111C Birdstrike-No further action recommended by Court of Inquiry

(2) There is no policy requiring the replacement of a lost aircraft or other major equipment. Therefore, no calculation is made or needed to consider individual attrition replacements.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of the Prime Minister: Special Arrangements for Disabled Persons

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 24 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In view of the fact that 1981 is designated as the International Year of Disabled Persons, what special arrangements has his Department made to assist disabled persons.

(2) Do any special arrangements made include (a) increased employment of disabled persons and (b) improved access for disabled persons to any building or other facility occupied by his Department; if so, what are the details.
(3) What budgetary allocations were made in 1980-81 to facilitate any special arrangements for disabled persons in his Department.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has given its full support to the International Year of Disabled Persons. The situation with the Public Service Board and departments generally is as follows:

(1) The Government and the Public Service Board have a policy of equal employment opportunity in the Australian Public Service. That policy is in keeping with the Government's endorsement of 'access to all aspects of community life' as one of the themes of IYDP. The policy of equal employment opportunity applies to disabled people seeking employment, or already employed, in the Australian Public Service.

Disabled people employed in the Public Service receive the same rates of pay, have the same job classifications, have the same terms and conditions of employment and have the same promotion opportunities as their non-disabled peers in comparable jobs.

1981 marks the end of a decade of active involvement by the Public Service Board to ensure that disabled people have equality of opportunity in the Australian Public Service. The full list of steps taken by the Board is quite extensive. I will forward to the Honourable Member a resume of these initiatives, together with other material produced by the Public Service Board on the employment of disabled people in the Australian Public Service.

As part of its commitment to the IYDP the Public Service Board is consolidating and extending its recruitment-based activities to ensure that people with disabilities continue to achieve equal access to the Service. The Board has produced special recruitment literature and posters which aim to imform disabled people that they can apply for jobs in the Public Service and expect to get 'a fair go'. Special recruitment activities, using this new literature, have been planned for 1981. The Public Service will also continue to provide work therapy opportunities for up to 200 rehabilitees in 1981 under the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service's work therapy scheme. The Board's activities to promote equal access to the Public Service and the recruitment of disabled people is an integral part of its equal employment opportunity program, a program which will continue well beyond 1981.

The Public Service Board is concerned that equality of employment not be viewed solely as a matter involving recruitment and placement of disabled people. Other important facets of equal employment opportunity, in which departments have an important role to play, include induction and orientation, access and job site modification, personnel development and training and rehabilitation of disabled staff. Permanent Heads of all departments have given the Board their full and active support for the implementation of EEO for disabled staff in this and future years.

To assist departments to focus on the needs of their disabled staff the Board is also conducting a series of seminars for senior managers on the employment of people with disabilities. The seminar series commenced in May and will continue on a monthly basis during 1981 and into early 1982.

Departments have already taken steps to improve the employment position of their disabled staff. For example, the Department of Industrial Relations is consulting with its disabled employees concerning access, modification of amenities, training and career opportunities. It is also fostering a greater consciousness amongst its staff of the problems faced by disabled people, modifying amenities to reduce difficulties for disabled employees and training staff in the supervision of disabled employees.

The Department of Employment and Youth Affairs, which is heavily involved in IYDP through the Government's programs for the employment of disabled people in the broader community has been expending considerable effort to modify the working environment, to obtain aids and provide induction, training and developmental programs for its disabled employees.

In the Department of Defence a special video program has been produced showing disabled staff at work in the Department. The video promotes positive attitudes towards the employment of disabled people. The Department of Transport is also planning an education program to inform staff about the disabled, their rights as individuals and citizens and the causes and prevention of disablement.

The Department of Housing and Construction, as part of its commitment to IYDP, has undertaken a survey of staff to determine the number of disabled people employed, the nature of the disability and the difficulties they face in the work environment. This survey indicated that 6.4 percent of its staff were disabled. The Department of Capital Territory is also undertaking a survey of its staff.

2(a) The Public Service Board, the employing authority in the Australian Public Service, has Special Placement Officers in each of its Regional Offices to assist in the recruitment and placement of disabled people. Special Placement Officers are able to arrange modified selection tests which take into account the applicant's disability e.g. for blind applicants tests can be administered in braille or on tape, for deaf applicants an interpreter can be provided.

In 1980 the Special Placement Officers assisted 802 disabled applicants, of whom 251 were placed in employment. 20 percent of disabled applicants gained permanent jobs in the Public Service. This compares favourably with non-disabled applicants where only 15 percent were permanently appointed to comparable positions. Departments which took a substantial number of special placements during 1980 included Defence, Education, Employment and Youth Affairs, Home Affairs and Environment, Social Security and Veterans' Affairs, together with the Australian Bureau of Statistics and the Australian Taxation Office. All departments accept, wherever possible, disabled new entrants referred to them by the Special Placement Officers.
The steps being taken by the Board to further increase the numbers of disabled people employed in the Public Service are detailed in (1) above.

2(b) There is a long-standing policy of ensuring that public buildings constructed by the Commonwealth permit reasonable access by disabled people and comply with the Australian Standards relating to Design Rules for Access by the Disabled. Access for disabled people has been provided in such buildings as the Family/Children's Court building and the Public Service Board's McLachlan Offices in Canberra. The Australian Defence Force Academy will include in certain areas special facilities for the disabled. The provision of facilities for disabled people is included in the refurbishment program for the Administrative Building, occupied by the Departments of Foreign Affairs and Attorney-General's.

In its capacity as the central property authority, the Department of Administrative Services, in conjunction with the Department of Housing and Construction, is implementing a strategy for access modifications to Commonwealth-owned buildings. This involves a survey of over 500 buildings to identify any necessary modification work. Details on the Government's activities were provided by my colleague Mr McVeigh in answer to question 483 on 26 March 1981 (Hansard Page 1062).

(3) Departmental IYDP programs are being funded within their overall 1980-81 budget allocations. The Commonwealth however has provided substantial funds as part of its commitment to IYDP. They include provision of:
$1m (over two financial years) for a national publicity and community information campaign.
$500,000 to the Australian Council for the Rehabilitation of the Disabled (ACROD) for the establishment of a national headquarters in Australia.
$400,000 in the Children's Services Program for innovative projects for disabled children and their families.
$250,000 in 1980-81 to the Department of Housing and Construction to commence access modification works in 27 Commonwealth-owned buildings.
$700,000 in 1980-81 towards the provision of a range of aids to daily living under the new program of aids for disabled people.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: International Year of Disabled Persons: Federal Public Service

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Invalid Pensions: Electoral Division of Perth

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McLean Mr R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 4 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many persons in the electoral division of Perth were granted an invalid pension in (a) 1978-79 and (b) 1979-80.
(2) Have there been any changes since 1 January 1980 in the interpretation of Section 23 of the Social Services Act regarding the assessment of eligibility for an invalid pension; if so,
(a) what changes have taken place and
(b) from what date did the changes become operative.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Department of Social Security does not maintain as part of its regular statistical collections statistics of grants of invalid pension by electoral division. The number of invalid pensions granted in Western Australia was 3399 during 1978-79 and 2991 during 1979-80. The number of persons in the electoral division of Perth in receipt of an invalid pension was 2380 at 30 June 1979 and 2440 at 30 June 1980.

(2) There has been no change in the eligibility criteria for invalid pension since 1 January 1980. In order to qualify for an invalid pension a claimant must be permanently incapacitated for work to the extent of at least 85 percent or be permanently blind. Determination of whether this qualification is met is made in conformity with established medical criteria which take into account the degree of the claimant's impairment together with relevant facts about the applicant such as age, sex, education, lack of skills and personal disabilities. In reaching its decision, my Department is guided by the opinion of the Department of Health.
However, during the period in question there have been changes in the procedures for processing invalid pension applications.
New claim forms and associated documents have been introduced (the former Minister for Social Security advised the Senate of the introduction of the new claim form on 20 February 1980).

Additionally, on a State by State basis, a system was progressively implemented over the period January to September 1980 under which medical reports prepared by Commonwealth Medical Officers are reviewed by senior medical officers in the Department of Health. This procedure was designed to ensure consistency in the application of the criteria throughout Australia.

Further, on 7 May 1981 the Minister for Health and I issued revised guidelines for use in the assessment of eligibility for invalid pension. These clarify the eligibility criteria stated above and are publicly available.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice on 11 March 1981:

ANSWER.PARA: There are three classes of pension applicants necessitating provision of documentation by the Department of Defence in support of their applications. These classes are:
(a) Service personnel applying for retirement benefits, on other than invalidity grounds, to the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits (DFRDB) Authority;
(b) Service personnel applying for retirement benefits, on invalidity grounds, to the DFRDB Authority; and

The majority of such pension applications are those to the DFRDB Authority relating to retirements on other than invalidity grounds. During the period from 1 January 1981 to 12 May 1981 the average time between date of discharge and receipt of the necessary documents by the DFRDB Authority was:

In cases of retirement on invalidity grounds, more detailed documentation is required before the DFRDB Authority can commence its consideration of the applications. This documentation includes Service Medical Board reports and details of the Service member's skills, qualifications and experience.

Generally, a longer time is required than that taken to provide documentation for retirements on other than invalidity grounds, and some delays occasionally occur due to the complexity of individual cases.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

(2) When will the (a) Public Trustee Ordinance and (b) Mental Health Ordinance be completed.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes; Where the Curator of Estates of Deceased Persons, a statutory officer under the Administration and Probate Ordinance 1929, is appointed by will to act the Supreme Court may grant him an order to collect and administer the estate of any deceased person leaving property within the Australian Capital Territory.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 12 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the statute adopted by the Australian National University pursuant to the Australian National University Amend ment Act 1979 reflect the policy and intentions of the Government in seeking a reduction of services and amenities fees for students who do not wish to have part of the fees they have paid appropriated for socio-political purposes; if not, will the Government frame further legislative amendments to ensure that its requirements are met.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The purpose of the Student Organisations (Amenities and Services) Statute is to prescribe the amenities and services on which fees monies compulsorily collected from all students may be spent. Where the Council of the University makes compulsory fees monies available to a student organisation for the provision by that organisation of amenities or services, then it is the duty of the Council to ensure that the monies are applied only in respect of amenities and services that are not of an academic nature, that are of direct benefit to the University, and that have been declared in a University statute to be amenities or services in respect of that organisation.

The current provisions of the Australian National University Act enable the University to charge lower fees to students who indicate their wish not to join particular student associations, but do not require the University to do so. It has been the Government's wish for the University to act to see that students who join a particular student organisation pay a separate membership fee, the proceeds of which are to be directed towards supporting voluntary activities which are not eligible for support from the proceeds of the compulsory fee for amenities and services payable by all students. Such an arrangement would present a clear distinction between the students who choose to join an organisation and those who do not.

The Government, after reviewing the operation of the 1979 amendments at the Australian National University during 1980, decided to introduce further amending legislation which has now passed both Houses of Parliament. The purpose of this legislation is threefold. First, it makes income derived from the application of compulsory student fees moneys subject to the same conditions as the fees themselves. Second, where both compulsory fees moneys and other moneys are applied with the effect of producing income, that income must be apportioned according to the applications. Third, the administrative expenses of student organisations must also be apportioned, so that only activities devoted to the provision of student amenities and services can be a charge on compulsory fees moneys. With the enactment of this legislation, the Government is confident that compulsory fees moneys cannot be used by student organisations directly or indirectly for the funding of socio-political activities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 31 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the testimony before the United States of America House of Representatives Subcommittee on Military Construction Appropriations in 1979 to the effect that the US Navy has requested $2.5m to construct at North West Cape a ground terminal for the Fleet Satellite Communications (FLTSATCOM) System and the Defence Satellite Communications System (DSCS).
(2) Is it a fact that an agreement has been made between the Australian and US Governments that North West Cape is to be a ground terminal for the FLTSATCOM system.
(3) If so, is the ground station to be constructed at North West Cape for the FLTSATCOM system the same terminal as that previously announced for the DSCS at North West Cape.
(4) If it is not the same terminal what is the formal designation of the new FLTSATCOM terminal and when is it to become operational.

(5) Has a contract been let for the supply of AN WSC-3 UHF radio equipment to the Royal Australian Navy and are WSC-3 radio sets to be installed on all units of the Fleet and most RAN shore establishments.

(6) Is he able to say whether the AN WSC-3 UHF satellite communications equipment produced by E-Systems Inc. (ECI Division) of St Petersburg, Florida, USA, was developed specifically as part of the US Navy's Fleet Satellite Communications System.

(7) Are the RAN'S new AN WSC-3 radio sets to operate through the US Navy's FLTSATCOM satellites; if so, will FLTSATCOM ground terminals other than that at North West Cape be used for controlling satellites used by the WSC-3 radio equipment installed on RAN vessels.
(8) If other FLTSATCOM ground terminals are to be used, where are they located.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The appropriation request for $2.5m relates to the construction associated with the installation of the GSC-39 V(1) satellite communications ground terminal (formerly designated MSC-61), at North West Cape. I informed Parliament in March 1979 that installation of this terminal had the Government's support. The terminal will be part of the Defence Satellite Communications System (DSCS III), not the Fleet Satellite Communications System (FLTSATCOM).
(2), (3) and (4) There are no plans for an additional FLTSATCOM terminal to be installed at North West Cape. The station has had a FLTSATCOM receive-only terminal in operation for several years.

(5) A contract was placed with E-System Inc. (ECI Division) of St Petersburg, Florida, USA in April 1980 for the provision of AN/WSC-3 (RAN V1) UHF transceivers and ancillary equipment. These radios will be fitted in most RAN ships and shore establishments. It should be noted that the USN's AN/WSC-3 equipment and the RAN's AN/WSC-3 (RAN V1) equipment are similar but not identical radios.

(6) Both the AN/WSC-3 and AN/WSC-3 (RAN V1) radios are intended for use on normal line of sight tactical radio circuits. It would not be correct to say that they were developed specifically as part of the FLTSATCOM system.

(7) Some ancillary equipments have been ordered for the AN/WSC-3 (RAN V1) equipment to permit access to FLTSATCOM satellites to provide communications interoperability at sea with ships of our allies. The ground stations which control access to the communications channels on the FLTSATCOM satellites are located at Norfolk Virginia, Honolulu, Guam, Stockton California and Naples Italy. The ground terminal at North West Cape can only receive messages from FLTSATCOM satellites, not transmit them. Nor can it control them.

(8) The FLTSATCOM system is a US system and the US places its ground stations (and mobile stations) according to its own needs. With regard to the Australian equipment, there are no plans for accessing the FLTSATCOM system other than those referred to in the answer to part 7.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Royal Australian Air Force Drivers: Exposure to Malathion Vapour

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 1 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was there an incident involving 2 Royal Australian Air Force drivers in Mt Isa, Queensland, on 7 November 1980 which necessitated their hospitalisation following their exposure to Malathion vapour from corroded drums; if so will he now table in the House the following documents: (a) BSDAR 2126/133EQ Ptl (8) of 19 November 1980, (b) DI(AF)SUP 10-4 Report AMSDAR 1/80 of 19 November 1980, (c) BSFBN SIG MOP H470 of 4 August 1980, (d) BSFBN 2119/111/EQ Ptl (51) of 5 January 1981, 2SD 704/3/Pl Ptl (9) of 27 January 1981 and (f) DEFAIR QM767/DMOVT-AF of 24 January 1981.
(2) If he will not table these documents, what is the reason.
(3) What was the reason for the transfer of the Maldison (Malathion) from Sydney to Darwin.

(4) Has any further action been taken, other than that outlined by Group Captain L. D. Wilkinson in his report dated 4 March 1981, Ref. 2122/1/2493 Ptl (13), to ensure proper precautions to safeguard service personnel against the hazards of toxic chemicals.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Yes. Two RAAF drivers were held overnight at Mt Isa hospital on 7 November 1980 for observation after exposure to Malathion. They were subsequently treated as out-patients at the Base Medical Flight, RAAF Base Darwin between 13 and 16 November 1980, during which time, blood specimens were taken for analysis. When last seen by the Senior Medical Officer RAAF Darwin on 16 November 1980, the drivers were free from any symptoms of effects from the exposure. The documents requested can be tabled and I will arrange for this to be done as soon as possible. However, the names of two non-commissioned officers involved in this incident have been blanked out of these documents because a formal inquiry into this matter was not convened and the individuals were not given the protection of the Air Force Rule of Procedures 125A (B).
(3) The Malathion was required by RAAF Darwin for use by the Hygiene Section for insect control.

(4) All drums of Malathion held are being inspected for possible corrosion. The general matter of pesticide use in the Defence Force is monitored by the Pesticides Sub-Committee of the Medical Services Advisory Committee. A comprehensive Joint Service Manual on the handling and use of pesticides is being produced by this Sub-Committee.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many officers or employees in his Department have been (a) on strike and (b) engaged in go slow, work to regulations or other restrictive work actions, in each of the last two years.
(2) How many manhours were involved in these actions.
(3) Were any officers or employees on strike action paid by the Commonwealth during the strike; if so on what occassions.
(4) Were any pay reductions or disciplinary actions taken in respect of officers or employees on go slow, work to regulations or other restrictive work actions, if so, on what occassions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Department does not keep records on whether an individual officer or employee has been on strike or engaged in any restrictive work actions. However, it is possible to identify several groups of employees who have engaged in such activities during each of the last two years. These groups include employees at Williamstown and Garden Island Dockyards, foremen, storemen and packers, and a substantial number of officers in the Clerical grades. It is therefore possible to estimate the number of officers or employees who have been on strike or who have engaged in restrictive work action at approximately 6500.

(2) During the year ended 31 March 1980, 182,605 manhours were lost through strikes. During the year ended 31 March 1981, 474,459 manhours were lost through strikes. Of the latter figure 222,092 manhours were lost in one dispute, concerning the manning of the Plate Preservation Line at Williamstown Dockyard. Because of the nature of restrictive work actions it has not been possible to ascertain the number of manhours involved in them.
(3) No officers or employees have been paid for any periods during which they have been on strike.

(4) Most employees whose conditions of employment are governed by Public Service Arbitrator's Determination No. 44 of 1955 normally receive a naval work adjustment allowance. This allowance currentlly ranges between $3.60 and $9.40 per week. When these employees, most of whom are employed at Williamstown and Garden Island Dockyards, engage in any restrictive work practices this allowance is not paid. On occassions, management has insisted that employees perform work that is under ban or limitation. Upon refusal the pay of the individuals concerned has been stopped.

A total of 16 APS Staff of the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority were engaged in strike action during 1980 and 3,507 Commonwealth Teaching Staff were involved in 1979.
(b) 113 officers and employees of the Department were involved in go slow actions during 1979; no staff were involved in go slow action in 1980.

Go slow action by Departmental officers and employees totalled 413 manhours.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 28 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that at a meeting of State and Commonwealth Welfare Ministers the Minister refused to commit the Commonwealth Government to maintenance of present spending levels in respect of pre-school and other early childhood programs.
(2) When was the last increase in the special assistance grant for children in care.

(3) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the view expressed by some State Welfare Ministers that because of inadequate unemployment benefits for persons under 18 years of age, extra demand is placed on State resources and services for this group.
(4) What commitments will the Government make in respect of Commonwealth spending levels for pre-school and other early childhood programs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The level of funds to be made available for children's services in 1981-82 will be considered by the Government in the Budget context. However, I indicated that expenditure by this Government on children's services, other than expenditure on pre-schools, had greatly increased in real terms since 1975-76.
(2) I assume that the 'special assistance grant' mentioned is in fact 'special needs subsidy' payable to certain services subsidised under the Children's Services Program.
Special needs subsidy is paid to assist day care services to rebate the fees of low income families.
Special needs subsidy is payable under the general provisions of the Children's Services Program for family day care, and under the provisions of the Child Care Act for centre based services.

Under the general provisions, each family day care scheme receives Commonwealth special needs subsidy equal to the amount of fees foregone as fee rebates, up to a maximum total amount which is calculated on the basis of $7 per week for each equivalent full time child income.

The current rate of $7 per week used to calculate the maximum was introduced in 1977. A scheme can apply to the Minister for increased Special Needs Subsidy payments if it finds that the maximum amount does not cover the costs of fee rebates. Such increased payments are approved at ministerial discretion after an assessment of need. These arrangements also apply to day care centres funded under the centre based day care arrangement with the State governments.

Under the Child Care Act, payments to centres are made on the basis of the numbers of certain categories of children specified in Section 12 of the Act. Since 1975, each centre has been eligible to receive 25c subsidy per hour per child three years and over, and 40c per hour per child under three years.

(3) The question of the appropriate level of unemployment benefit for people under the age of 18 is bound up with the broader question of the assistance available for them in unemployment, education and training. This has been under study in the context of the review of ways of increasing the opportunities available for young people in education, training and employment.

The welfare and education implications for State governments as well as possible effects on State financial responsibilities, are relevant to consideration of possible changes in this area. State governments have been consulted as part of the review and the matter has been discussed by the Council of Social Welfare Ministers.

(3) If he will not increase these resources, what is the reason.

(4) Has his attention been drawn to reports in the press that the Prices Justification Tribunal will be abolished or merged with the Trade Practices Commission; if so, is there any substance to these reports, and particularly to the report that he would not be unhappy if the Tribunal were abolished.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I understand that Professor Friedman made a statement to the effect stated in the question.

(2), (3) and (4) The Government is committed to the principle of free and fair competition throughout the Australian economy including, where appropriate, regulation of monopoly power. The Govenment has reviewed, inter alia, the operations of the Trade Practices Commission and the Prices Justification Tribunal and its decisions were set out in the Prime Minister's Statement to the Parliament on 30 April 1981 on the Review of Commonwealth Functions.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Universities and Colleges of Advanced Education: Total Enrolments

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 29 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What progress has been made in pursuing the recommendations contained in the report of the Committee of Review into the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme (the Williams Committee) that universities and colleges of advanced education should strive for more accuracy in recording the number of their total enrolments.
(2) Are the numbers of effective full-time students at these institutions being satisfactorily recorded and is the Government satisfied that the numbers are accurate.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reply to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Committee of Inquiry into Education and Training established in 1976 under the chairmanship of Professor Sir Bruce Williams recommended, R6.25, ' . . . a considerable improvement in the accuracy and comprehensiveness of advanced education statistics to make possible comparative studies that should guide any further decisions on rationalisation.' This was one of a number of Williams Committee recommendations referred to the Tertiary Education Commission for consideration.

At present different measures are used to calculate the number of equivalent full time students, 'student load', for the university and advanced education sectors. For universities student load is measured in terms of the weighted student unit (WSU) which is calculated by measuring the academic program for each student against the normal program for a full time student in each course. Higher degree enrolments are given special weightings. For colleges of advanced education student load is calculated by giving a weight of 1.0 to full time students and 0.5 to part time and external students.

There are difficulties in accurately calculating student load in colleges of advanced education because the measures currently being used tend to overstate it. The Tertiary Education Commission, in Volume 1 Part 1 of its Report for the 1982-84 Triennium, has advised that it considers that since most part time students in advanced education, and particularly external students, undertake less than one-half of a full year's work, the real student load generated by a part time enrolment is likely to be closer to 0.4 than 0.5 of the load of a full time student. The Commission has taken this into consideration in formulating its recommendations on the advanced education sector.
The development of a WSU type measure is under consideration by the Joint Committee on Advanced Education Statistics.

(4) The sample was forwarded to AGAL.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 12 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What percentage of funds allocated for long service leave for service personnel is payment in lieu of leave.
(2) Do service personnel have a right to long service leave.
(3) If so, is it practice to reject applications for leave when eligibility for leave has been reached.
(4) Is long service leave actually a form of retirement pay under existing legislation.
(5) Is an entitlement for pay in lieu established progressively as qualification periods for long service leave are completed or is this entitlement only available at retirement.
(6) Does a serviceman seeking to take long service leave entitlement have any recourse to review by an independent person or authority where this leave is refused.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There is no allocation of funds for the payment of long service leave to serving members. Members receive normal salary while on long service leave. However, funds are allocated for the payment in lieu of long service leave.
(2) A member may be granted subject to Service convenience long service leave once he has completed 10 years admissible service.

(3) Long service leave is generally approved. However, an application may be rejected when the taking of long service leave by a member is not in the interests of the Service or because of manning requirements.

(4) No. Long service leave is a period of rest and recuperation, whilst on service, after a minimum of 10 years service. Pay in lieu of long service leave can be taken only for unexpended credits at discharge.
(5) An entitlement to long service leave accrues progressively during a member's service. Payment in lieu of long service leave can only be made to a member when he separates from the Service.

(6) Should a member's application for long service leave be denied, he may submit a request for reconsideration of his application through the normal Service channels. In addition, the member has recourse to the long established Services Redress of Wrongs system, and to the Office of the Defence Force Ombudsman, if he is not satisfied with the results of a request for reconsideration.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 12 May 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What costs have been associated with the construction of the hydrographic survey vessel at Williamstown Dockyard, Victoria.
(2) Have significant alterations to the design of this vessel during construction created serious delays in deliver.
(3) What have been the additional costs incurred by the design alterations.
(4) What has been the (a) cost and (b) cause of the period of delay resulting from design and operational problems in the multi-pitch screw hydraulics.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The following answer is provided to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: This answer presumes that the honourable member is referring to the Oceanographic Research Ship HMAS Cook presently under construction at Williamstown. The hydrographic survey vessel HMAS Flinders was also constructed at Williamstown; however that vessel has been in operation for the last seven years.

(1) The cost of the Oceanographic Research Ship HMAS Cook is $30.886m at December 1980 prices. The estimated project cost in September 1974, construction commencement date, was $17.5m. The total net real price increase amounts to $2.031m of the increase of $13.386m. The balance of the increase, i.e., $11.355m, has occurred due to inflationary factors.

(2) No-the design work package for this ship was completed prior to 1974. Minor design changes have been included in the shipbuilder's work package subsequent to that date; however these have not delayed the completion of the ship.
(3) An increase in real costs of $0.188m (approx) to implement 111 design changes. Balanced against this cost figure is a saving of $0.141m which resulted from implementation of four design changes.

(4) The cause of the period of delay in completion of the ship can be attributed to the inability of the main machinery contractor to satisfactorily instal the main propulsion machinery in the ship to meet specification contract requirements.

Reimbursement of costs associated with rectifying the machinery deficiencies, together with the shipbuilder's consequential costs resulting therefrom, e.g., additional docking, delays to other scheduled docking, dockyard services, are being actively investigated by the contractual authority; the Department of Administrative Services.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 14 May 1981:

(2) What sums are lodged in the account.
(3) Are there any outstanding claims against the account.
(4) On termination of the account (Hansard 30 April 1981, page 1844) what use will be made of the funds.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Enemy Subjects Trust Account was established on 6 October 1939 in accordance with the provisions of section 14 of the Trading with the Enemy Act 1939 to receive and deal with the proceeds of disposal of property formerly owned by Enemy Subjects.

(2), (3) and (4) Funds which became available earlier have been distributed over the years, including two general distributions to eligible ex-prisoners of war and their dependants. ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Defence Force Review Tribunal: Report on Salaries and Conditions

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 14 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the report by the Defence Force Review Tribunal on Salaries and Conditions of Members of the Defence Forces been completed.
(2) If not, has the time taken for the review been excessive and will he seek to have the finalisation of the Report expedited.
(3) Has an amount of $103m been deducted from the appropriation for the Defence Forces accounts savings, as a result of the Report not being available when initally anticipated.

(4) Will he ensure that the operative date of any beneficial changes to service conditions and salaries will be backdated, in order that Service personnel will not be financially disadvantaged by delays in the preparation or approval of the Tribunal's recommendations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) I do not consider the time taken for the review to be excessive. The Committee of Reference for Defence Force Pay was given its terms of reference on 22 July 1980. The Committee submitted to me an interim report on 31 October 1980 on the work value aspect of the reference recommending an increase in Service remuneration on grounds of work value change. This recommendation has been approved and implemented.

Additionally, in December 1980, the Committee of Reference was tasked with an examination of appropriate allowances for Special Action Forces. The report on this subject was presented on 6 March 1981. Without doubt, this intervening but extremely urgent reference delayed to some extent continuance of the work required by the earlier reference.

Despite these strictures on the time of the Committee, two members of which are full-time members of the Arbitration Commission a further report is expected to be forthcoming by about the end of July 1981.

(3) The amount of $103m (initially $110m) was included in the Defence Budget estimates for 1980-81 by Department of Finance, as an Allowance to meet prospective increases in wage and salary rates of both Service and civilian personnel within Defence.

The actual additional estimate for the salaries sought by Defence for 1980-81 is $91.795m to cover mainly increases flowing from national wage case decisions and work value increases so far awarded to both Service personnel and civilians.

(4) The interim increase recommended by the Committee of Reference, which is mentioned in 2. above, was effective from 22 July 1980. This was the date terms of reference for the inquiry were given to the Committee of Reference. In the report accompanying the recommendations, the Committee of Reference stated that it should not be inferred that 22 July 1980 will be the operative date for the final work value assessment or for other recommendations made necessary by the terms of reference. That final date of effect is to be a matter for separate consideration.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 14 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the fact that since the release of the recent Prices Justification Tribunal (PJT) report on petrol prices, the extent of discounting petrol has increased markedly in New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland.
(2) Is it a fact that South Australia motorists have not shared in the benefits of the resultant lower level of pertrol prices.

(3) Is he satisfied that petrol resellers and motorists in South Australia are not being discriminated against by the oil companies; if not, will he (a) instruct the body replacing the PJT to investigate immediately this discrimination by the oil companies in South Australia and (b) continue to monitor petrol pricing throughout Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. Indeed I have noted reports that some oil companies intended to withdraw discounts, following the release of the PJT report of 31 March 1981 on petroleum product prices. I am not able to confirm or deny the accuracy of those reports nor to say whether market conditions will enable companies to withdraw those discounts.

(3) According to ABS figures (catalogue No. 6403.0) the average retail price of super grade petrol in Adelaide during the March quarter of 1981 was higher than in other State capitals. In the previous quarter the reverse applied.

(4) Prices determined by the PJT for the oil companies are maximum justified prices. They differ between States only to the extent of differences in State taxes or other charges levied on petroleum products.

Oil companies are not obliged to charge the maximum justified prices and, where competition is keen, they might not be able to obtain the full justified price. Actual prices to resellers would reflect both the strength of competition of any State price controls that may apply.

The Petroleum Products Pricing Authority will take over from the PJT the respnmsibility for monitoring prices charged by the oil companies. It will have powers as proposed in the Petroleum Products Pricing Bill which I introduced into Parliament on 27 May 1981.

As the Commonwealth's jurisdiction over prices is limited to the corporate sector, effective action to monitor retail petrol prices, including the margins applied by non-corporate resellers, is a matter for State Governments to consider.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Johnson The Hon L.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 26 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Domestic Fallout Shelter Guide 1980 issued by the natural disasters organisation within his Department supposed to provide guidance to Australians in the event of nuclear accident or the explosion of nuclear weapons in Australia.
(2) If so, (a) is the Government satisfied with the adequacy of the guide and (b) what additions, amendments or alterations can be made to improve the guide.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The booklet was produced to give those who may wish to plan for protection from radioactive fallout following a nuclear explosion some guidance on domestic shelters which could be constructed at moderate cost.
I am satisfied that the booklet is adequate for that purpose.

The booklet was produced as part of the Natural Disasters Organisation's ongoing public information program. Relevant material is constantly being reviewed and pamphlets produced, in conjunction with appropriate authorities on a range of disaster subjects.

Information on nuclear health matters is presently being gathered under these arrangements. This information could form part of a more comprehensive booklet which would include information about fallout shelters and any other relevant material which is ready for dissemination at the time.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Fry Mr K.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 26 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the recently announced alliance between the United States of America and Japan have any impact on Australian foreign policy and defence planning.
(2) If the alliance leads to a re-arming of Japan, what implications will this have for Australia and what would be the effect on Australian foreign affairs and defence policy.
(3) Did the United States Government consult with the Australian Government before announcing this alliance.
(4) Has the USA any obligation, either legal or moral, to consult with Australia on such a matter.
(5) If the Australian Government was consulted, what response did it give.

(6) If the Australian Government was not consulted on this matter, (a) is this a cause of concern for the Australian Government and (b) what guarantee is there that the USA will consult Australia on any future foreign policy initiative involving countries in the area.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) An alliance between the United States and Japan has not been announced recently. In the joint communique issued by Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki and President Ronald Reagan on 8 May, it was stated that 'the Prime Minister and the President, recognising that the alliance between Japan and the United States is built upon their shared values of democracy and liberty, reaffirmed their solidarity, friendship and mutual trust'. Although there has been debate in Japan about the interpretation of the word 'alliance' in this sentence, in particular as to whether it committed Japan to a new or altered security relationship with the United States, the Government of Japan has made it clear that its relationship with the United States remains as it has been.

(2) The joint communique further states that 'the Prime Minister and the President reaffirmed their belief that the Japan-United States Treaty of Mutual Cooperation and Security is the foundation of peace and stability in the Far East and the defense of Japan. In insuring peace and stability in the region and the defense of Japan, they acknowledged the desirability of an appropriate division of roles between Japan and the United States. The Prime Minister stated that Japan, on its own initiative and in accordance with its constitution and basic defense policy, will seek to make even greater efforts for improving its defense capabilities in Japanese territories and in its surrounding sea and air space, and for further alleviating the financial burden of US forces in Japan. The President expressed his understanding of the statement by the Prime Minister.'

These positions outlined in the communique do not alter our perception of Japan's defence and security policies nor of Japan's relations with the United States. The Government sees cooperation under the Japan-United States Treaty of Mutual Cooperation and Security as a vital part of the defence of the Asia/Pacific region, as are the separate arrangements under ANZUS. It is in Australia's interest that the defence relationship between Japan and the United States remain a harmonious one.

(3), (4), (5) and (6) As suggested in answer to questions (1) and (2), no event as suggested by those questions took place which required specific consultations with Australia by any other government. In both formal and informal consultations with the United States on security issues in the Pacific area, discussion would include, as appropriate from time to time, subjects related to Japan. Similarly, established patterns of consultations with Japan on matters of common international concern include subjects such as Japan's, and our own, relations with the United States.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Fry Mr K.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 27 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What proportion of the annual Defence budget is spent on the acquisition of new equipment.
(2) What are the implications for the Army and Air Force, in terms of new equipment, from the decision to replace HMAS Melbourne with another aircraft carrier or carriers.
(3) For how many years will the proportion of the Defence budget allocated for purchase of capital equipment be tied up in paying off a new aircraft carrier.
(4) Does he favour an aircraft carrier rather than a mix of conventional submarines and small surface ships for the protection of Australia; if so, why.
(5) Is HMAS Melbourne being replaced by another aircraft carrier so as to enable Australia to project a visible presence in the South Pacific and Indian Oceans.
(6) Will other powers in the area interpret the replacement of HMAS Melbourne in the terms referred to in part (5).
(7) Is the career structure of the Royal Australian Navy centred around serving on an aircraft carrier.
(8) Has Australian thinking on a replacement for HMAS Melbourne been influenced by United States of America Naval doctrine.
(9) How many Oberon-class submarines could be purchased from the sum necessary to replace HMAS Melbourne with another aircraft carrier.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The proportions of total Defence expenditures spent on capital equipment over the financial years 1975-76 to 1979-80 are 8.3 per cent, 12.8 per cent, 13.2 per cent, 15.5 per cent and 16.4 per cent respectively. On 19 February 1980 the Prime Minister announced in Parliament details of a defence program which is expected to raise the proportion of expenditure on capital investment to over 25 per cent of the defence vote by 1984-85.

(2) The acquisition of new major capital equipment is considered primarily in the context of its contribution to the development of defence force capabilities as a whole. Planning for the development of Army and Air Force capabilities will necessarily take account of concurrent development of the RAN.

(3) None. In any one year the major equipment component of the Defence Budget comprises financial allocations for a range of equipment approved in earlier years and for new equipment to be approved in the Budget year.

(4) Studies to assist the selection of an aircraft carrier design are continuing. Conventional submarines and small surface ships are not alternatives to the anti-submarines helicopters which will be deployed with any new carrier. The carrier is to have potential for operating short take-off and vertical landing (STOVL) aircraft. The Government will consider in 1983 whether or not to acquire STOVL aircraft, in the light of aircraft costs, capabilities and other relevant factors.
(5) See my answer (4) above. A new carrier would, as do HMAS Melbourne and other major ships of the RAN, conduct operations in the Pacific and Indian Oceans.

(6) I cannot comment accurately on how neighbouring states might interpret Government decisions on Australian defence force development. I should expect them to see a decision to acquire a helicopter carrier as a military matter rather than, as the question implies, a political one.
(7) No. Service with the aircraft carrier is not a prerequisite for advancement in the RAN.
(8) No. Decisions on Australian defence force development are based on Government assessments of Australian defence needs.

(9) See my answer to (4) above. No useful answer can be given to this question. The eventual cost of a new carrier will depend on the type of ship selected and the range of capabilities that it might include. The Oberon submarine is no longer in production.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Visits by United States Attack Submarines

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 3 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will he update the record of visits by attack submarines of the United States Navy provided in answer to Question No. 508 (Hansard, 5 May 1981, p. 2004).
(2) Is he able to say which of the submarines visiting since 1979 have been Los Angeles class attack submarines.
(3) Have the visiting submarines cooperated with Australian Orion P-3C aircraft in surveillance activities in the Eastern Indian Ocean area; if so, on what occasions.
(4) Have the visiting submarines conducted exercises with RAN units and/or RAAF aircraft; if so, (a) on what occasions and (b) which Australian units were involved on each occasion.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The following visits to HMAS Stirling by nuclear powered submarines have taken place in 1981:
(2) USS Los Angeles, USS Baton Rouge, USS Groton, USS Omaha, USS Philadelphia, USS Memphis.

(4) a and b Yes. The occasions on which RAN and RAAF units have exercised with visiting submarines since 1979 have been prior to or on completion of the visits by the USS Tautog in August 1980, USS Gurnard in March 1981 and USS Pintado in May 1981. RAAF Orion aircraft participated on all three occasions, and HMAS Perth participated also in exercises with USS Pintado.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Sound Surveillance System on Christmas Island

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 3 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the article by Joel S. Wit entitled 'Advances in Antisubmarine Warfare' in the Scientific American, February 1981, Volume 244, Number 2; if so, does a map appearing on page 37 indicate the presence on Christmas Island of a Sound Surveillance System (SOSUS) shore facility connected with the US anti-submarine warfare program.
(2) Does the facility shown on the map actually exist; if so, is it under Australian or United States control.
(3) In view of the SOSUS offshore arrays near Indonesian waters and the SOSUS shore facility, has Australia access to intelligence gathered on the movements of Soviet and other nations' submarines.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
