(3) I will not comment further on the accuracy or otherwise of details about underwater sensor systems contained in the Scientific American article. Australia obtains intelligence about the movement of other nations' submarines from various sources.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 3 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the loans made available under the tertiary student loan scheme announced by the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions (Hansard, 30 April, 1981, page 1843) be (a) free of interest or (b) subject to the low rate of interest.
(2) Over what periods will repayments be set.
(3) What procedures will be followed in attempting to secure repayments of loans made under this proposed loan scheme to supplement or replace the TEAS.
(4) Will the Government obtain the services of debt collecting agencies to ensure repayment of loans.
(5) What security will be required of the student in obtaining a loan.
(6) Will loans be taken out at the beginning of a term to last for the duration of the term, or will they be obtained at the beginning of the school year for the duration of that year.
(7) Will students entering their second or third year of studies be required to have paid back the loan for the previous year before proceeding or before obtaining a new loan.
(8) What will be the financial indebtedness of a student who secures loans for 3 years of studies and fails in the last term of those 3 years and is unable to continue his or her education.
(9) Is the purpose of providing loans to assist students in (a) the progressive payment of tertiary education fees or (b) meeting expenses incurred while studying for a degree or diploma.

(10) If the purpose of the loan is that referred to in part (9) (b), will students who are not successful in the course of study for which they have received loans, still be required to repay the loan; if so, will the loan scheme add serious financial indebtedness as a penalty to a student's failure to achieve success at his or her studies.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (10) At this stage the details of the proposed student loans scheme have not been finalised and it is not possible, therefore, to provide specific answers to the parts to this question. I shall make a fuller statement on the scheme later in the year after negotiations with banks and tertiary institutions have been completed.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 4 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Prices Justification Tribunal say in its report published on 31 March 1981 entitled Inquiry into Prices of Petroleum Products, at page 25, that the Tribunal accepts that a review (i.e. of the Tribunal's criteria and procedures for dealing with petroleum product prices) is desirable and accordingly, following the completion of this Inquiry, it will prepare a statement on the criteria, procedures and information requirements for future pricing proposals and that this statement will be made available to the industry and to interested parties for comment before decisions to implement the proposals are taken by the Tribunal; if so, what stage has been reached by the Tribunal in this review of procedures for future out product pricing proposals.
(2) Will he ensure that the new mechanism to be established to maintain the Government's petroleum product pricing policy will continue with and complete this review as promised by the Tribunal.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes-the Prices Justification Tribunal has this matter under consideration.
(2) Yes-It will be the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority's responsibility to continue the work and complete the review.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Commonwealth Funding for Colleges of Advanced Education

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Young Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 4 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to the Government's announcement that consideration would be given to funding activities of single purpose colleges of advanced education where they have been amalgamated with or into larger institutions to the satisfaction of the Commonwealth Government by the end of 1981 (Hansard, 30 April 1981, page 1843), is it a fact that Commonwealth funding for 30 single purpose CAE's will cease as single purpose institutions from the end of 1981.

(2) Are a number of institutions listed in Attachment D to the Ministerial Statement on the Review of Commonwealth Functions (e.g. Hartley CAE, Salisbury CAE, Alexander Mackie CAE, Guild T.C., Nursery School T.C., Sydney Kindergarten T.C., Sydney T.C., SCV Coburg, Melbourne and Toorak, and Brisbane Kindergarten T.C.) already being amalgamated into larger institutions; if so, why are these institutions listed.

(3) If the campuses listed in Attachment D to the ministerial statement amalgamate with, or into, larger institutions by the end of 1981 in a way which results in genuine amalgamations with one governing body and a real saving of resources, will they receive full Commonwealth funding.
(4) How does the Government define a real saving of resources.
(5) Will the Government undertake to guarantee that the total number of student places available in CAE's will not be reduced as a result of the amalgamations.
(6) What guarantees will the Government give to students that there will be provision for them to complete the courses in which they have enrolled.
(7) How will the Government fund courses previously offered by CAEs where they are transferred to neighbouring universities.
(8) Has the Government allocated $5m in 1982 and 1983 to facilitate this rationalisation; if so, is this to be a $5m grant in each of years 1982 and 1983.
(9) Has the Government rejected the recommendation of the Tertiary Education Commission for $10m to be allocated during 1982-83 to assist with the rationalisations; if so, why.

(10) Will the amalgamation of CAE's with universities affect access to CAE level courses due to the more stringent entrance requirements of the universities; if so, what action will the Government take to ensure that this does not occur.
(11) To what extent will the University of Western Australia and Murdoch University be expected to collaborate and share resources.
(12) Has the Government estimated the cost of pursuing the rationalisations proposed; if so what is the estimated cost.
(13) What criteria is the Government using to justify the rationalisation of engineering in Victoria.
(14) Has the Government undertaken a labour power study of the needs for engineers in Australia as a whole and the effect of the proposed rationalisation on the supply of engineers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) As I explained in my Statement on Commonwealth Education Policy and Financial guidelines to the Commonwealth Education Commissions, the Government intends to reach agreement with each State concerning rationalisation measures by the end of 1981. If this cannot be done, the Commonwalth will not be prepared to continue recurrent funding for the colleges concerned after the end of 1981 and if the State Governments wish these colleges to continue as separate entities they will have to make their own separate financial provision.

(2) Some institutions in Attachment D were already being amalgamated and in other cases proposals had been made but not necessarily finalised. The Government wished to confirm and accelerate the process of consolidation.

(4), (5), (6) and (7) The Government is concerned to ensure that the funds available for higher education are used in the most efficient and effective manner. The detailed arrangements for these matters will be considered by the Government following the receipt of the reports I have asked the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission to provide by 30 June and 31 August.

(8) Yes. An amount of $5m p.a. has been earmarked within the general recurrent grants for advanced education in the years 1982 and 1983 as additional resources for CAEs which are able to expand their effort in the technologies and business studies.

(13) and (14) The Government's decision to rationalise engineering courses in Victoria is based on advice from the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission which took account of the findings of the Partridge Committee in Victoria in relation to engineering education and of a working part set up by the Victorian Post Secondary Education Commission to extend the work commenced by the Partridge Committee. I am advised that the working party considered the numerical needs for engineering education in Victoria and recommended that the engineering schools of Melbourne, Monash, RMIT, Swinburne and Footscray could, if necessary, meet all those needs. In its Volume I Report the CTEC has explained the difficulties associated with predicting long-term trends in manpower needs but concludes that in view of the large number of engineering schools in Victoria and the small size of some of them, some rationalisation is required on grounds of quality.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 4 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an article in the Canberra Times of Tuesday, 12 May 1981, entitled 'Superannuation Scheme Changes Proposed', which indicates that a large Commonwealth department has canvassed a proposal to determine Public Service superannuation entitlements on length of service rather than age.
(2) Is there any substance to the report; if so, has the Australian Government Retirement Benefits Office or the Department of Finance responded to the proposal.
(3) If either have responded to the proposal, what were the terms of the response.
(4) If neither has responded to the proposal, what is the (a) reason and (b) Government's attitude to the proposal outlined in the article.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) and (3) As the result of a routine request by the Public Service Board for items to be discussed by the Joint Council of the Australian Public Service, an officer submitted to his Department a proposal ' . . . that the existing Superannuation Scheme be altered or expanded to provide for retirement on a 'length of service' basis in place of, or in addition to, the current 'age' basis . . .'. The Department forwarded the officer's proposal to the Australian Government Retirement Benefits Office which referred it to the Department of Finance. Subsequently, the officer was informed by his Permanent Head that he considered that the proposal could not be pursued at this time. The Department of Finance was also informed of the Permanent Head's views. Accordingly, no response was required.

(4) (a) See (2) and (3) above. (b) The basis of retirement of public servants is not determined by the Superannuation Act 1976, but by long-standing provisions now incorporated in the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act 1979. There is no proposal before the Government to change arrangements under which public servants, like the great majority of other employees throughout Australia, become eligible to retire, or are required to retire, on the grounds of age rather than length of service.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 9 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What is the estimated cost of reducing the retiring age for receipt of the age pension to 60 years.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I refer the honourable member to my answer to House of Representatives Question No. 903, asked on 25 March 1981 by Dr Klugman and answered in the Hansard of 29 April 1981 (page 1982). In my answer I outlined the difficulties in estimating the cost of lowering the pensionable age, and provided estimates of the cost of paying an income test free pension to men aged 60 to 64 years at November 1980 pension rates and December 1980 numbers.

Similar estimates have been prepared based on the estimated number of persons, pensioners and beneficiaries at June 1981, and pension rates applicable from May 1981. The additional cost of paying an income test free pension to residentially qualified men aged 60 to 64 years is now estimated to be about $580 million in a full year. This cost is additional to the estimated $320 million annual cost of existing payments to male invalid and service pensioners and unemployment and sickness beneficiaries aged 60 to 64 years.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Colleges of Advanced Education: Recurrent Funds

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Dawkins Mr J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 10 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did he say in his statement on Commonwealth Education Policy of 4 June 1981 (Hansard, pages 3111-28) that in determining the level of recurrent funds for 1982-84 for colleges of advanced education the Government has taken account of such savings in respect of institutions which have been or will be consolidated during the triennium.

(2) If so, (a) what was the total amount of the savings estimated with respect to all institutions, (b) what were the individual savings estimated in respect of each institution proposed for consolidation and (c) by what sum were the recurrent funds for colleges of advanced education reduced to take account of those savings.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) In determining the level of recurrent funds for 1982-84 for higher education the Government endorsed the approach taken by the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission to rationalisation but decided to accelerate the process. As I explained in my statement on Commonwealth education policy of 4 June 1981, the Government intends that the consolidation of institutions should result in a real saving of resources. The Government has not been prescriptive in its guidelines to the CTEC and consequently will need to await CTEC advice before taken final decisions, which could vary from State to State and from institution to institution. The CTEC will be reporting on progress by 30 June and finally in its Volume II Report by 31 August 1981.
